# Introduction to Job

## Part 1: General Introduction

### Outline of Job

1. Job is introduced (1:1–2:13)
    * Job is blameless and wealthy (1:1–5)
    * Yahweh allows Satan to test Job (1:6–2:10)
1. Three friends speak to Job (3:1–14:22)
    * Eliphaz, Bildad, and ZopharJob replies to each
1. They speak to him again (15:1–21:34)
    * Eliphaz, Bildad, and ZopharJob replies to each
1. They speak a third time (22:1–31:40)
    * Eliphaz and BildadJob replies to each
1. Elihu speaks to Job (32:1–37:24)
1. Yahweh answers Job out of the whirlwind (38:1–41:34)
1. Job is humbled before Yahweh (42:1–6)
1. Yahweh rebukes Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar (42:7–9)
1. Yahweh prospers Job again (42:10–17)

### What is the Book of Job about?

The Book of Job is about a man named Job who experienced disaster even though he was faithful to Yahweh. Job speaks with three friends and asks why Yahweh lets him experience trials and losses. The book teaches that we cannot understand all of Yahweh’s ways, and when we suffer, it is more important to trust Yahweh than it is to understand the reason for the suffering.

### How should the title of this book be translated?

The Book of Job is named for Job, the main character in the book. His name is not related to the English word “job.” Translators might use the traditional title of “The Book of Job” or just “Job.” Or they may choose a clearer title, such as “The Book About Job” or “The Book About a Man Named Job.”

### Who wrote the Book of Job?

We do not know who wrote the Book of Job. Many people suggest that Moses composed or compiled the book, but it may have been written after the time of Moses.

## Part 2: Important Religious and Cultural Concepts

### Does sin cause suffering?

When a person sins against Yahweh, it can cause the person to experience suffering. People in the ancient Near East generally believed that a person suffered because they or their ancestors sinned against God. This is what many religions teach. However, the Book of Job shows that a person may suffer even if he or she has not sinned. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

### Were Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar really Job’s friends?

Job 2:11 refers to Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar as the friends of Job. But they did not comfort Job. Instead, they tried to persuade Job to say something about God that Job believed was not true. So we might wonder if it is right to translate the word as “friends.” They did care about Job and they wanted to help him. However, what they said did not help Job because they did not understand the truth about God.

### When did the events in the Book of Job take place?

We do not know when the events in the Book of Job took place. It seems to be set around the time of Abraham and Isaac in the Book of Genesis. However, some verses are similar to ones in the Books of Proverbs and Isaiah, which are set much later.

## Part 3: Important Translation Issues

### What style of writing is in the Book of Job?

The writer starts and ends the Book of Job by telling what happened to Job in narrative form. He wrote the other parts in poetry form. In the ancient Near East, writers often used poetry to discuss matters of wisdom.

### Is the Book of Job difficult to translate?

The Book of Job has many uncommon words and phrases, making parts of it hard to understand translate. For this reason, translators may decide to translate this book after they have translated other books of the Bible. However, since the writer did not connect Job with a specific time or place in history, the translator may decide to translate this book before other Old Testament books.

# Job 1 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

This chapter introduces a story about a man named Job who lives during a time long before the author.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Wealth

Job is very rich. During his time, a man’s wealth is measured by the number of animals he owns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

### Feasts

Job is a very godly man and celebrates Yahweh’s provision by having feasts. It must be remembered that Job lives prior to the law of Moses, so his religious practices are different than the Hebrew people after Moses. The events of this book occur about the same time as the life of Abraham. Therefore, this book corresponds more with Genesis 12–50 than the rest of the Old Testament. (See:[[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/godly]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/lawofmoses]])

### Job’s faith
Satan believes that Job’s faith is based on Yahweh’s blessings. He challenges Yahweh to remove these blessings from Job’s life because he thinks that Job will no longer trust in Yahweh if this happens. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]], [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/bless]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])

# Job 3 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem.

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses several rhetorical questions in this chapter. The purpose of these rhetorical questions is to show Job’s earnest desire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: opened his mouth
Note: This idiom means he began to speak.

Quote: May the day on which I was born perish, the night
Note: Job speaks of that day and night as if they were people. Alternate translation: “I wish that I had never been born”

Quote: the night that said, ‘A boy has been conceived.’
Note: This expression intensifies the statement of Job’s grief by going even further back in time from his birth to his conception. Alternate translation: “the night that said, ‘A boy has been conceived’ perish.”

Quote: the night that said
Note: Here the night is spoken of as if it were a person who could speak. The translator may choose, however, to translate it in a less metaphorical way. Alternate translation: “the night about which people said”

Quote: A boy has been conceived
Note: This may be put into active form. Alternate translation: “his mother has conceived a male child”

# General Information:\n\nThe expressions in these verses are all wishes that the day of Job’s birth would no longer exist. This may imply that the day, although in the past, still existed somehow. The UST translates them as expressions of sadness about what that day was like.

Quote: May that day be dark … neither may the sun shine on it
Note: These two clauses describe the darkness of the day of Job’s birth, thus repeating Job’s regret that he had been born.

Quote: May that day be dark
Note: This is a wish for that day to not exist any longer. Alternate translation: “may that day disappear”

Quote: May darkness and the shadow of death claim it for their own
Note: Here darkness and the shadow of death are spoken of as if they were people who could claim something as their own possession. The word “it” refers to the day of Job’s birth.

Quote: the shadow of death
Note: Here a shadow represents death itself. Alternate translation: “death like a shadow”

Quote: May a cloud live over it
Note: Here a cloud is spoken of as if it were a person who could live over the day of Job’s birth. Alternate translation: “May a cloud cover it so no one can see it”

Quote: everything that makes the day black
Note: This refers to things that block out the sun’s light and create darkness. Here “black” represents darkness.

Quote: terrify it
Note: “terrify that day.” The day is spoken of as if it were a person who could be terrified by the darkness.

Quote: may thick darkness seize it
Note: This darkness is again spoken of as if it were a person who could grasp and hold the night. Alternate translation: “may thick darkness make it disappear”

Quote: thick darkness
Note: Alternate translation: “deep darkness” or “complete darkness”

Quote: May it not rejoice
Note: The word “it” refers to the night of Job’s birth or conception. The night of Job’s conception is spoken of as if it were a person who should not rejoice. Alternate translation: “May that night vanish from the calendar”

Quote: may it not come into the number
Note: That night is spoken of as if it were a person who could walk. Alternate translation: “may no one count it in the number”

Quote: may that night be barren
Note: The night of Job’s birth is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “may no child be born on that night”

Quote: may no joyful voice come into it
Note: Here that the night of Job’s birth is spoken of as if it were a time when it was still possible for someone to be happy. Alternate translation: “may no one hear the happy cry at the birth of a son”

Note: Here the voice stands for a person who is happy. Alternate translation: “may no one be happy in it ever again”

Quote: those who know how to wake up Leviathan
Note: Job is probably referring here to sorcerers and magicians, who he believes might be able to even provoke Leviathan in spreading chaos. Leviathan was an animal well known in Ancient Near Eastern mythology, which was thought to be responsible for all kinds of destruction, disorder, and chaos.

Quote: May the stars of that day’s dawn be dark
Note: This refers to the planets that are often visible just before dawn. Alternate translation: “May the stars that appear before that day’s first light be dark”

Note: The day of Job’s birth is spoken of as if it were a person looking for something. Alternate translation: “May that day hope for light, but have none”

Note: The dawn is spoken of as if it had eyelids as a person has. Alternate translation: “nor see the first light of the dawn”

Note: A woman’s womb is spoken of as if it were a container with doors. Alternate translation: “because that day did not close my mother’s womb”

Note: The day of Job’s birth is spoken of here as if it were a person who could hide something.

# General Information:\n\nThis passage contains four rhetorical questions, which Job asks in order to really make a series of statements.

Note: “Why did I not die at birth?” Job poses this question in order to curse the day of his birth and to express his anguish. Alternate translation: “I wish I had died the day I was born”

Note: Job means to say that he should not have been born alive. Alternate translation: “I wish I had died when I came out of the womb.”

Note: This refers to dying.

Note: Job’s mother’s breasts are spoken of as if they also were people who could welcome a newborn baby. Alternate translation: “I wish there had been no breasts for me to nurse.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Job begins talking about what would have been true if he had never been born.

Note: Here Job uses a question to make a statement. Alternate translation: “I do not understand why God allows a person to keep living when the person would be very happy to be buried in the ground”

Quote: one who rejoices very much and is glad
Note: The phrase “rejoices very much” means basically the same thing as “is glad.” Together, the two phrases emphasize the intensity of gladness. Alternate translation: “one who is extremely happy”

Quote: when he finds the grave
Note: This is a polite way of referring to dying. Alternate translation: “when he is dead and can be buried”

Quote: the grave
Note: Here the grave represents death.

Quote: Why is light given to a man whose way is hidden, a man whom God has hedged in?
Note: Job asks this question in order to make a statement. Alternate translation: “God should not give life to a man and then take away his future and confine him.”

Quote: Why is light given to a man
Note: Here light represents life. Alternate translation: “Why does God keep a man alive”

Quote: whose way is hidden
Note: Here Job speaks of his future, which he does not know in advance, as if God had hidden it from him.

Quote: a man whom God has hedged in
Note: Here being in difficulties and dangers is spoken of as if it were being confined within narrow limits.

Quote: For my sighing happens instead of eating; my groaning is poured out like water
Note: Job expresses his anguish in two ways.

Quote: my sighing happens instead of eating
Note: Alternate translation: “Instead of eating, I mourn”

Quote: my groaning is poured out like water
Note: Moral qualities and emotions such as grief are often spoken of as if they were water.

Quote: the thing that I feared has come on me; what I was afraid of has come to me
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “what I feared most has happened to me” or “my worst fear has come true”

Quote: I am not at ease, I am not quiet, and I have no rest
Note: Job expresses his anguish in three separate phrases. Alternate translation: “I am very anxious” or “I am emotionally and physically tormented”

# Job 4 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is the advice of Job’s friend, Eliphaz.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Eliphaz’s advice
Eliphaz tells Job to curse Yahweh. The advice Eliphaz gives to Job is bad advice. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Eliphaz uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Job that he is wrong. These questions help to form Eliphaz’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Eliphaz
Note: Eliphaz is a man’s name.

Quote: Temanite
Note: A Temanite belongs to the tribe of Teman.

Quote: will you be impatient?
Note: Eliphaz asks this question in order to make a statement. Alternate translation: “you will surely be impatient.”

Quote: will you be impatient?
Note: Alternate translation: “will that annoy you?”

Quote: But who can stop himself from speaking?
Note: Eliphaz asks this question to say that no one who sees a friend suffering can remain silent. Alternate translation: “No one can restrain himself from speaking (to a friend in such a state as you find yourself)” or “I must speak to you, (seeing that you are in a state of grief).”

Quote: See, you have instructed many; you have strengthened weak hands
Note: This verse states a single idea in two different ways.

Quote: you have strengthened weak hands
Note: Here “weak hands” represents people who need help. Alternate translation: “you have helped others when they needed help”

# General Information:\n\nThe writer uses parallelism in each of these verses to make one idea using two different statements to emphasize: (1) the support that Job has given others in the past, (2) the effect on him of his present troubles, and (3) his piety before God.

Quote: supported
Note: Someone who has been encouraged is spoken of as if he were kept from falling down.

Quote: falling
Note: Here becoming discouraged is spoken of as if it were falling down.

Quote: you have made feeble knees firm
Note: Here discouragement is spoken of as if it were a person whose weak knees could not keep him upright.

Quote: But now trouble has come to you
Note: Here trouble is spoken of as if it were an object that could come to a person. Alternate translation: “But now you suffer from disasters”

Quote: you are weary
Note: Alternate translation: “you are discouraged”

Quote: your fear
Note: Alternate translation: “the fact that you honor God”

Quote: Is not your fear your confidence, and the integrity of your ways your hope?
Note: Eliphaz asks these questions in order to tell Job that it is because of his sin that he is suffering. Alternate translation: “Everyone thinks that you honor God; everyone thinks that you are an honest man. But these things must not be true, because you do not trust God any longer.”

Quote: your fear
Note: Eliphaz means Job’s fear of God. Alternate translation: “your fear of God”

Quote: your ways
Note: Here “your ways” represents “your conduct,” “how you behave.”

Quote: Who has ever perished when innocent?
Note: Eliphaz uses this question to prompt Job to search his life for sin (and God’s righteous judgment) as the cause of his loss. Alternate translation: “No one has ever perished when innocent.”

Quote: when were the upright people ever cut off
Note: This question also means to make a statement, and may be put into active form. Alternate translation: “No one has ever cut off an upright person” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: cut off
Note: Here being cut off represents being destroyed.

Quote: plow iniquity … sow trouble … reap
Note: Here the actions of plowing and sowing represent causing trouble for other people. The action of reaping represents suffering the trouble that one has himself caused.

Quote: By the breath of God they perish; by the blast of his anger they are consumed
Note: The writer explains a single idea using two different statements. This is a form of Hebrew poetry used for emphasis, clarity, teaching, or all three.

Quote: the breath of God
Note: This may represent the action of God giving a command.

Quote: the blast of his anger
Note: This expression suggests the heavy breathing that a person sometimes does through his nose when he is very angry.

Quote: breath … blast
Note: The second builds on the first. They make the same point by using meanings that increase the result. “By the puff of God’s mouth they die; the rushing wind of his anger devastates them.”

Quote: perish … are consumed
Note: The second phrase builds on the first. They make the same point. “By the puff of God’s breath they die, the rushing wind of his anger devastates them.”

Quote: they are consumed
Note: Here being consumed or eaten represents being killed.
# General Information:\n\nThe writer uses parallelism in these verses, conveying a single idea using different statements to emphasize God’s destruction of wicked people.

Quote: The roaring of the lion, the voice of the fierce lion, the teeth of the young lions—they are broken.
Note: Here a lion’s roar, his voice, and his teeth being broken are used as pictures of the wicked being destroyed.

Quote: they are broken
Note: This may be put into active form. Alternate translation: “something breaks them”

Quote: The old lion perishes for lack of victims; the cubs of the lioness are scattered everywhere
Note: Eliphaz uses the picture of an old lion dying of hunger and of a lion’s family being scattered as metaphors for the wicked being destroyed.

Quote: the cubs of the lioness are scattered
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “something scatters the cubs of the lioness”

Quote: Now a certain matter was secretly brought to me … my ear received a whisper about it
Note: These phrases express the same idea in a different way. They convey the idea that Eliphaz heard a message whispered to him. This repetition is a form of Hebrew poetry used frequently for emphasis, teaching, or clarity.

Quote: visions in the night
Note: Alternate translation: “dreams”

Quote: when deep sleep falls on people
Note: Alternate translation: “when people sleep very deeply”
# General Information:\n\nThe writer uses parallelism in these verses, conveying a single idea using different statements to emphasize Eliphaz’s fear.

Quote: fear and trembling came upon me
Note: Here fear and trembling are spoken of as if they were objects that could come to a person. Alternate translation: “I began to be afraid and to tremble”

Quote: the hair of my flesh stood up
Note: This indicates great fear.

Quote: the hair of my flesh
Note: Alternate translation: “the hair on my body”
# General Information:\n\nThe writer uses parallelism in verse 17, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize a question about the purity of man before God.

Quote: A form was before my eyes
Note: Alternate translation: “Something was before my eyes,” “I saw something”

Quote: and I heard
Note: Alternate translation: “then I heard”

Quote: Can a mortal man be more righteous than God?
Note: Eliphaz poses this question so that Job will consider, “Do I regard myself as more righteous than God?” or “Am I justified before God?” Alternate translation: “A mortal man cannot be more righteous than God.” or “A mortal man cannot be righteous before God.”

Quote: Can a man be more pure than his Maker?
Note: This question has the same purpose as the previous question. Alternate translation: “A man cannot be more pure than his Maker.” or “A man cannot be pure before his Maker.”

Quote: his Maker
Note: Alternate translation: “his Creator”

Quote: those who live in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust
Note: This is a figurative way of describing human beings, who were created out of the dust of the earth and whose bodies are like houses, which are made of clay and have dirt foundations.

Quote: who are crushed sooner than a moth
Note: Possible meanings for this metaphor are: (1) “who God destroys as easily as he crushes a moth” or (2) “whose lives are as short as the life of a moth.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# General Information:\n\nThese verses continue the earlier use of parallelism, here emphasizing in different ways the idea that people die suddenly without having achieved wisdom and without concern from others.

Quote: Between morning and evening they are destroyed
Note: This refers to the idea of something happening quickly.

Quote: they are destroyed
Note: This may also be put into active form. Alternate translation: “they die”

Quote: Are not their tent cords plucked up among them?
Note: This may be put into active form. Alternate translation: “Have not their enemies plucked up their tent cords from among them?”

Quote: their tent cords
Note: Here tent cords represent a tent. Sometimes a person’s home and family are pictured as his tent, which can also represent all his possessions. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Job 5 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of the advice of Job’s friend, Eliphaz.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Eliphaz’s advice
Eliphaz tells Job to curse Yahweh. The advice Eliphaz gives to Job is bad advice. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]])

### Sickness and sin

In the ancient Near East, it was common to believe that a person’s illness was caused by sin. It was seen as the punishment of a god. While Yahweh may punish people because of their sin, not all sicknesses are caused by sin. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/believe]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Eliphaz uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Job that he is wrong. These questions help to build Eliphaz’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: To which of the holy ones will you turn?
Note: Eliphaz poses this question to make the point that there is no one Job can turn to for help. Alternate translation: “Is there a holy one to whom you may turn?” or “There is no holy one to whom you can turn for help.”

Quote: holy ones
Note: This refers to supernatural beings of some kind, whether angels or other spirits.

Quote: jealousy kills the silly one
Note: Alternate translation: “jealousy kills anyone who acts ignorantly and impulsively”

Quote: the silly one
Note: any silly person

Quote: a foolish person
Note: any foolish person

Quote: a foolish person taking root
Note: Here a person is spoken of as if he were a plant, perhaps becoming more foolish over time. Alternate translation: “a foolish person becoming grounded in foolishness”

Quote: his home
Note: This refers to the person’s family and all his property.
# General Information:\n\nThese verses continue the earlier use of parallelism, here emphasizing in different ways the idea that the children of foolish people are never safe.

Quote: His children are far from safety
Note: Here, **His** refers to the foolish person or the foolish people in [Job 5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: “Their children are never safe”

Quote: are crushed
Note: Here being crushed represents being oppressed, taken advantage of, at court. This idea may be put into active form. Alternate translation: “someone crushes them” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: city gate
Note: The city gate, functioning as a court, was the place where disputes were resolved and where judgments were given.

Quote: There is no one to rescue them
Note: Alternate translation: “There is no one to help the foolish people’s children out of their hardship”

Quote: they even take it from among the thorns
Note: This perhaps refers to parts of a field where the worst crops grow, because of thorn plants present.

Quote: The thirsty pant for their wealth
Note: Here greedy people are spoken of as if they were thirsty, and the wealth of the foolish person is spoken of as if it were something that they could drink.

Quote: For difficulties do not come out from the soil; neither does trouble sprout from the ground
Note: Here difficulties and trouble are spoken of as if they were plants.

Quote: mankind is born for trouble, just as sparks fly upward
Note: It is as natural for people, once they are born, to have trouble as it is for sparks to fly up from a fire.

Quote: great and unsearchable things, marvelous things without number
Note: Alternate translation: “great things that cannot be understood, wonders that cannot be counted”

Quote: unsearchable things
Note: This refers to things that mankind cannot understand.

Quote: great and unsearchable things
Note: Here the writer uses two independent words connected by “and” to emphasize the greatness of God’s actions. Alternate translation: “greatly profound things”

Quote: marvelous things
Note: Alternate translation: “wonderful things” or “wonders”

Quote: He does this in order to set up on high those who are low
Note: Humble people in distress are spoken of as if they were in a low position. When God rescues them, they receive honor. When this happens, they are spoken of as being raised up and put into a high position. Alternate translation: “God does this in order to rescue and honor the humble who have been suffering”

Quote: He breaks the plans
Note: Here stopping the plans of crafty people is spoken of as if they were things that could be physically broken.

Quote: He traps wise people in their own crafty actions
Note: Here making wise people suffer for their own evil actions is spoken of as if it were catching them in traps. Their own actions are spoken of as if they were those traps.

Quote: twisted people
Note: Here being evil in a clever way is spoken of as if it were being twisted. Alternate translation: “those who are cunning” or “those who are devious” or “those who are shrewd”

Quote: They encounter darkness in the daytime
Note: Here the cunning, wicked people whom God confuses are spoken of as if they unexpectedly are in the dark at noon, when the sun is at its highest position in the sky. They cannot do anything they wish to do, because they cannot see. Alternate translation: “Those who are cunning are in the dark, even at noontime”

Quote: grope
Note: feel around like a blind person

Quote: noonday
Note: the middle of the day, when the sun is highest and brightest

Quote: But he saves the poor person from the sword in their mouths
Note: Here the insulting and threatening things that people say are spoken of as if they were a sword in their mouths. Alternate translation: “But he saves the poor person from the threats of the mighty” or “But he saves the poor person when the mighty threaten or insult them”

Quote: injustice shuts her own mouth
Note: People who say unjust things are spoken of as if they were the injustice itself, who must stop speaking. Alternate translation: “It is as though injustice shut her own mouth”

Quote: God corrects … chastening of the Almighty
Note: God is pictured as a parent correcting or instructing a child.

Quote: blessed is the man whom God corrects
Note: Alternate translation: “God really favors the man whom he corrects”

Quote: do not despise
Note: Alternate translation: “do not reject” or “do not consider worthless”

Quote: chastening
Note: Alternate translation: “instruction” or “correction” or “discipline”

Quote: For he wounds and then binds up; he wounds and then his hands heal
Note: Alternate translation: “For he wounds but binds up; he crushes but his hands heal”

Quote: his hands heal
Note: Here “his hands” represents God.

Quote: He will rescue you out of six troubles; indeed, in seven troubles, no evil will touch you
Note: The use of increasing numbers such as “six” and “seven” represents the idea of many, many times. Alternate translation: “He will rescue you out of trouble over and over again; indeed, time after time, no evil will touch you”

Quote: In famine he will ransom you
Note: Here rescuing is spoken of as if it were ransoming, buying back. Alternate translation: “In famine God will rescue you from danger”

Quote: the hands of the sword
Note: Here “hands” probably represents the people who attack with weapons, including swords. Alternate translation: “violent people” or “people who attack you”

Quote: of destruction
Note: Here “destruction” refers to the danger of being destroyed by enemies. Alternate translation: “that any enemy will destroy you”

Quote: You will laugh at destruction and famine
Note: Here “laugh” represents that the person is not afraid. Alternate translation: “You will not be afraid of any danger of destruction or famine”

Quote: beasts of the earth
Note: This refers to wild animals. Alternate translation: “wild animals”

Quote: you will have a covenant with the stones in your field
Note: Here the stones in farmers’ fields are spoken of as if they were people that someone could have a covenant with. Alternate translation: “the stones in your fields will be like people who promise that they will not make any trouble for you”

Quote: the beasts of the field
Note: This refers to dangerous wild animals.

Quote: You will know that your tent is in safety
Note: Here “tent” represents a person’s family, household, and all his possessions. Alternate translation: “You will know that your family, servants, and everything you own are safe”

Quote: you will visit your sheepfold and you will not miss anything
Note: Alternate translation: “when you visit where your flock stays at night, you will find all your sheep there”

Quote: your seed will be great
Note: Here “seed” represents a person’s descendants. Alternate translation: “your descendants will be many”

Quote: your offspring will be like the grass on the ground
Note: Here “offspring” are spoken of as if they were as many as blades of grass, and probably as thriving, too. Alternate translation: “your descendants will be as many and as alive as the grass that grows”

Quote: You will come to your grave at a full age
Note: Alternate translation: “You will die at a very old age”

Quote: like a stack of grain bundles that goes up at its time
Note: You may need to make explicit that the grain in this simile is fully ripe but not overly ripe. He would neither die young nor become weak in his old age. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: See, we have examined this matter; it is like this; listen to it, and know it for yourself
Note: The words “we” refers to Job’s friends but not to Job. Alternate translation: “Look, we have thought about this matter. Listen to what I am saying and know that it is true”

# Job 6 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Eliphaz.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s righteousness
Despite being upset about his circumstances, and desiring his own death, Job does not curse God. He would rather have God end his life than to curse him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphors

Job uses many different metaphors in this chapter to express his pain or despair. He also is upset with the advice of his friends, who are supposed to help him during difficult times. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Eliphaz that he is wrong. These questions help to build Job’s response. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: if only my anguish were weighed; if only all my calamity were laid in the balance
Note: Here the writer uses two different statements to convey a single idea, the burden of Job’s suffering. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “if only I could weigh my anguish and all my calamities in the balance” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: in the balance
Note: Alternate translation: “on a scale”

Quote: For now it would be heavier than the sand of the seas
Note: Job compares the burden of his suffering to the weight of wet sand; both can crush a person. Alternate translation: “For my anguish and calamities would be heavier than the sand on the seashore”

Quote: my words were reckless
Note: Alternate translation: “I spoke recklessly” or “I spoke rashly”

Quote: For the arrows of the Almighty are in me
Note: This is a metaphor for Job’s suffering. He compares his many troubles to arrows that God has shot his body with. Alternate translation: “It is as though the Almighty has shot arrows into my body”

Quote: my spirit drinks up the poison
Note: “my spirit drinks up the arrows’ poison.” This continues the metaphor of the arrows, by implying that they had tips of poison and that Job feels the pain in his spirit. He speaks of feeling this pain as if his spirit drank the poison. Alternate translation: “I feel the pain of their poison in my inner being”

Quote: the terrors of God have arranged themselves in array against me
Note: Job speaks of the terrible things that have happened to him as if they were soldiers that God had lined up to attack him all at once. Alternate translation: “God has caused all the terrible things that could happen to happen to me all at once”

Quote: the terrors of God have arranged themselves in array against me
Note: God causing many things to terrify Job is spoken of as if God’s terrors were soldiers lined up to attack Job. Alternate translation: “the terrors of God have arranged themselves like soldiers in an army”

Quote: Does the wild donkey bray in despair when he has grass? Or does the ox low in hunger when it has fodder?
Note: Job poses these rhetorical questions to emphasize that he has a reason to complain. These question can be written as statements. Alternate translation: “Just as the wild donkey does not bray in despair when he has grass and as the ox does not low in hunger when he has fodder, I would not complain if I did not have a reason”

Quote: bray
Note: the sound a donkey makes

Quote: low
Note: the sound an ox makes

Quote: fodder
Note: animal food

Quote: Can that which has no taste be eaten without salt? Or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
Note: This could mean: (1) Job is comparing his displeasure for his circumstances to people’s dislike for bland food or (2) Job is comparing his displeasure for his friend’s advice to people’s dislike for bland food.

Quote: Can that which has no taste be eaten without salt? Or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
Note: Job uses these rhetorical questions to emphasize his own displeasure. These questions can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: “Tasteless food cannot be eaten without salt, just as there is no taste in the white of an egg.”

Quote: Can that which has no taste be eaten
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Can you eat that which has no taste”

Quote: I refuse to touch them
Note: “Them” refers to bad tasting foods.

Quote: to crush me once
Note: This means for God to cause him to die. Alternate translation: “to crush me and let me die”

Quote: that he would let loose his hand and cut me off from this life
Note: The phrases “let loose his hand” is an idiom that means to act quickly. Also, the phrase “cut me off from this life” is a euphemism for killing him. Alternate translation: “that he would act quickly and cut short my life” or “that he would act quickly and end my life” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Quote: even if I exult in pain that does not lessen
Note: Alternate translation: “I would leap for joy in unending pain” or “I would endure pain that does not diminish”

Quote: exult
Note: Alternate translation: “rejoice”

Quote: does not lessen
Note: Alternate translation: “does not diminish”

Quote: that I have not denied the words of the Holy One
Note: This can be written in positive form. Alternate translation: “that I have always obeyed the Holy One”

Quote: What is my strength, that I should try to wait? What is my end, that I should prolong my life?
Note: Job poses these questions to emphasize that he has no reason to continue living. These questions have the same meaning. They may be written as statements. Alternate translation: “I do not have enough strength to go on living; I have no reason to prolong my life” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
# General Information:\n\nThe writer uses parallel rhetorical questions in each of these verses to emphasize Job’s lack of strength to endure suffering.

Quote: Is my strength the strength of stones? Or is my flesh made of bronze?
Note: Job describes the weakness of his body by saying that he is not as strong as rocks and bronze to emphasize his lack of strength. These rhetorical questions may be written as statements. Alternate translation: “I am not as strong as the rocks. My flesh is not as strong as metal.”

Quote: Is it not true that I have no help in myself … me?
Note: Job uses this rhetorical question to emphasize his lack of wisdom and his weakness. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Also, the phrase “no help in myself” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “It is true that I have no strength left … me.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: wisdom has been driven out of me
Note: “my success has been taken from me.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “my wisdom is gone”

Quote: To the person who is about to faint, faithfulness should be shown by his friend
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “A friend should be faithful to the person who feels he is about to faint”

Quote: who is about to faint
Note: This speaks of a person who feels hopeless and is overwhelmed by his troubles as if he were about to physically faint. Alternate translation: “who feels hopeless”

Quote: even to him who forsakes the fear of the Almighty
Note: “even if he stops fearing Almighty God.” This could mean: (1) the faint person does not fear God or (2) his friend does not fear God.

Quote: But my brothers have been as faithful to me as a desert streambed
Note: Job speaks of his friends being unfaithful to him as being like a “wadi” which is a stream that can suddenly dry up. Also, Job refers to his friends ironically here as his “brothers.” Alternate translation: “But my friends are unfaithful to me. They are like a desert streambed” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: as channels of water that pass away to nothing
Note: “like streams of water that dry up.” Job continues speaking of his friends being unfaithful as if they were streams that dry up.

Quote: which are darkened because of ice over them … and because of the snow that hides itself in them
Note: These two phrases have the same meaning. They describe how the streambed is full of ice and snow in the winter. Alternate translation: “which look dark in the winter because they are covered with ice and are full of melted snow” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: because of the snow that hides itself in them
Note: This speaks of the snow melting and the water going into the streambed as if the snow were hiding in the streambed. Alternate translation: “because the snow melts and goes into them”

Quote: When they thaw out, they vanish … when it is hot, they melt out of their place
Note: These two phrases have the same meaning. They describe how the streambed dries up in the hot season. Alternate translation: “When it is hot, the ice melts and the streambeds dry up” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Job is continuing his description of his friends being as unreliable as streams that dry up.

Quote: The caravans that travel by their way turn aside for water
Note: Alternate translation: “The caravans turn aside from the routes to find water” or “The caravans change course looking for water”

Quote: The caravans
Note: A caravan is a large group of travelers riding camels across the desert.

Quote: barren land
Note: Alternate translation: “wasteland” or “empty land”

Quote: Tema … Sheba
Note: These are the names of places. The people of these places used caravans to trade things with people from other lands.

Quote: while companies of Sheba
Note: Alternate translation: “while caravans from Sheba”

Quote: hoped in them
Note: Alternate translation: “hoped for them” or “put their hope in them”

Quote: but they were deceived
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “but they were disappointed” or “but they were not satisfied”
# General Information:\n\nIn these verses, Job poses four questions to rebuke his friends and to emphasize that he did not ask for help from any of them.

Quote: For now
Note: Job uses this phrase to introduce the main part of what he is saying.

Quote: you friends are nothing to me
Note: Alternate translation: “you friends have not helped me at all”

Quote: are afraid
Note: This means that they see the trouble Job has and are afraid of being in the same situation. Alternate translation: “you are afraid that God might do similar things to you”

Quote: or, ‘Save me from my adversary’s hand’ or, ‘Ransom me from the hand of my oppressors’?
Note: These words are the last of a series of rhetorical questions that begins in verse 22. Job uses these questions to emphasize that he has not asked his friends to give him anything or to help him. “I never said to you, ‘Give … me’ or, ‘Offer … wealth’ or, ‘Save … hand’ or, ‘Ransom … oppressors’.”

Quote: my adversary’s hand … the hand of my oppressors
Note: The word “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “having my adversary control me … having my oppressors control me” or “my adversary’s power … my oppressors’ power”

Quote: Ransom me
Note: Alternate translation: “Rescue me”

Quote: Teach me … make me
Note: These verbs “teach” and “make” are second person plural and are spoken to his friends.

Quote: I will hold my peace
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I will be silent”

Quote: How painful are truthful words! But your arguments, how do they actually rebuke me?
Note: The exact meaning of the original language is uncertain. Some Bibles translate “How painful” as “How pleasant.” Alternate translation: “When a person speaks the truth, it harms no one. But your arguments are not true, so how do they actually rebuke me?”

Quote: But your arguments, how do they actually rebuke me?
Note: Job is using this question to rebuke his friends and to emphasize that what they are saying does not apply to him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Your reasons for rebuking me do not apply to me even though you sternly correct me.” or “But your arguments against me are not true, so they do not actually rebuke me!”

Quote: your arguments
Note: Alternate translation: “your reasons” or “your claims”

Quote: Do you plan to ignore my words, treating the words of a desperate man like the wind?
Note: Job uses this rhetorical question to scold his friends. He compares his words to the wind to explain that his friends act like his words are empty and useless. Alternate translation: “You ignore my words! I am a desperate man, and you treat my words as if they are as useless as the wind.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: Do you
Note: “You” is in second person plural form.

Quote: you cast lots for a fatherless child
Note: Alternate translation: “you would even gamble to win an orphan”

Quote: you cast lots … haggle over your friend
Note: Here “you” and “your” are in second person plural form.

Quote: haggle over your friend like merchandise
Note: This compares how the man would sell his friend to how a person sells merchandise or wares. Alternate translation: “bargain to sell your friend for money”

Quote: Now
Note: This word is used by Job to introduce new information.

Quote: please look
Note: The verb “to look” is in second person plural form.

Quote: I would not lie to your face
Note: The word “your” refers to Job’s friends. Here his friends are represented by their faces to emphasize that they are looking at him. Alternate translation: “I would not lie to you while I am looking at you”

Quote: Relent, I beg you
Note: Alternate translation: “Please be merciful to me” or “Stop speaking like this, I beg you”

Quote: let there be no injustice with you
Note: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “treat me fairly”

Quote: Indeed, relent
Note: Alternate translation: “Please relent.”

Quote: Is there evil on my tongue?
Note: “Do I say wicked things?” Job uses this question to rebuke his friends and to emphasize that he is not wicked. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I do not say wicked things.”

Quote: on my tongue
Note: Here Job’s speech is represented by his “tongue.” Alternate translation: “in my speech”

Quote: Cannot my mouth detect malicious things?
Note: Job uses this question to rebuke his friends and to emphasize that he can tell the difference between right and wrong. Here Job refers to himself by his “mouth” to emphasize his speech. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I know what is right to say and what is wrong to say.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

# Job 7 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s response to Eliphaz.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s righteousness
Despite being upset about his circumstances, and desiring his own death, Job does not curse God. He would rather have God end his life than to curse him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphors

Job uses many different metaphors in this chapter to express his pain or despair. He also is upset with the advice of his friends, who are supposed to help him during difficult times. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Eliphaz that he is wrong. These questions help to build Job’s response. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Does not man have hard labor on earth?
Note: Job poses this negative question to emphasize his awareness that all people experience hard work. It can be translated as a positive statement. Alternate translation: “There is hard labor for every person on earth.”

Quote: on earth
Note: This is a generalization that means for the time people are living on the earth. Alternate translation: “while he lives on the earth”

Quote: Are not his days like the days of a hired man?
Note: Job poses this negative question to emphasize his awareness that all people struggle in life. Alternate translation: “And their days are like the days of a hired man.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: a hired man
Note: “a day laborer.” This is a man who worked jobs one day at a time and was paid at the end of every day.

Quote: Like a slave … like a hired man
Note: Job compares his misery and trouble to that of the slave and hired man.

Quote: the shadows of evening
Note: “cool shade.” The implied information is that the shadows of evening provide coolness and shade from the sun

Quote: looks for his wages
Note: Alternate translation: “waits for his pay”

Quote: I have been made to endure months of misery; I have been given trouble-filled nights
Note: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “so I endure months of misery; I get trouble-filled nights”

Quote: months of misery
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **misery**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “miserable.” Alternate translation: “months when I am miserable”

Quote: When I lie down
Note: The implied information is that this is when Job would lie down to sleep at night. Alternate translation: “When I lie down to sleep”

Quote: I say to myself
Note: Job poses a question to no one else in particular. Alternate translation: “I ask” or “I wonder”

Quote: When will I get up and when will the night be gone?
Note: Job poses this question to emphasize his intense suffering during the hours he should be sleeping. Alternate translation: “I wish I could get up, but night continues.”

Quote: tossing to and fro
Note: “turning back and forth.” This indicates that Job has moved on his bed all night without any rest.

Quote: My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust
Note: The worms and clods of dust are pictured as covering Job as if they were clothing. Alternate translation: “My flesh is covered with worms and clods of dust”

Quote: My flesh
Note: This represents his whole body. Alternate translation: “My body”

Quote: clods of dust
Note: This could mean: (1) lumps or crusts of dirt or (2) scabs on the skin.

Quote: dissolve and run afresh
Note: Alternate translation: “break out again”

Quote: My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle
Note: Job compares his lifetime to the quickness of a weaver’s shuttle. Alternate translation: “My life goes by very quickly”

Quote: weaver
Note: a person who makes cloth by crossing threads or yarn

Quote: a weaver’s shuttle
Note: a moving part that carries thread or yarn back and forth quickly in a loom when making cloth

Quote: call to mind
Note: “remember.” The phrase “call to mind” does not mean God forgot. Job is asking God to consider or think about the shortness of Job’s life.

Quote: my life is only a breath
Note: Job compares the shortness of his life to the shortness of a breath. Alternate translation: “my life is very short, like taking one breath”

Quote: my eye will no more see good
Note: Here “my eye” represents Job’s whole person and his ability to see or experience things. Alternate translation: “I will never again experience good things”

Quote: The eye of God, who sees me, will see me no more
Note: Many versions of the Bible translate this as “The eye which sees me will see me no more.” The words “of God” were added to this phrase because they are implied by the context.

Quote: The eye of God, who sees me … God’s eyes will be on me
Note: Here God is represented by his “eye” to emphasize what he looks at. Alternate translation: “God who watches me … God will look for me”

Quote: As a cloud is consumed and vanishes away, so he who goes down to Sheol will come up no more
Note: Job is describing death as being like the clouds that disappear.

Quote: As a cloud is consumed
Note: This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “As a cloud fades”

Quote: he who goes down to Sheol will come up no more
Note: Alternate translation: “he who dies will not return”

Quote: his place
Note: The words “his place” represent those who live in his place. Alternate translation: “the people who live in his place” or “his family”

Quote: I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitterness of my soul
Note: Job conveys a single idea using two different statements to emphasize the reason he will not remain silent.

Quote: I will not restrain my mouth
Note: Here the mouth represents speech. Alternate translation: “I will not restrain my speech”

Quote: in the anguish of my spirit
Note: “in the distress of my spirit” or “in the torment of my suffering.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **anguish**, you can express the same idea with the adverb “distress.” Alternate translation: “while my spirit is distressed”

Quote: in the bitterness of my soul
Note: Here sorrow is spoken of as if it tasted bitter, and “soul” refers to the whole man. Alternate translation: “with anger and resentment” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: Am I the sea or a sea monster that you place a guard over me?
Note: Job poses this question to express his anger at God. In comparing himself to the sea or a sea monster, Job suggests that God regards him as a hideous creature. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I am not the sea or a sea monster that needs a guard to watch it.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My bed will comfort me, and my couch will ease my complaint
Note: Here “bed” and “couch” are metonyms for “sleep.” In lying down to sleep, Job would hope to be comforted. The metonyms also have human attributes; they have the ability to comfort and ease a person. Alternate translation: “My bed, my couch, will be like someone who can comfort me” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: My bed … my couch
Note: These phrases refer to the same thing. Alternate translation: “My bed … my bed”

Quote: you scare me
Note: “you” here refers to God

Quote: strangling
Note: killing a person by squeezing the throat and stopping the breathing

Quote: these bones of mine
Note: Here Job uses the word “bones” to refer to his body. Alternate translation: “This body of mine”
The writer continues to use parallelism in these verses, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize the impact of Job’s misery on his sense of self worth.

Quote: I loathe my life
Note: Alternate translation: “I despise my life”

Quote: to always be alive
Note: Alternate translation: “to live forever”

Quote: my days are useless
Note: Alternate translation: “my days are pointless” or “the days of my life are empty”
Job asks a rhetorical question to say that he does not understand why God should pay attention to people.

Quote: set your mind on him
Note: Here the mind represents thoughts and attention. To “set your mind on” means to give attention to. Alternate translation: “direct your attention to him” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: that you should observe … every moment?
Note: This is the end of the rhetorical question that Job begins asking with the words “What is man that” in verse 17. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. “Tell me what man is that … mind on him, that you should observe … every moment.” or “I do not understand what man is that … mind on him, that you should observe … every moment.”

Quote: observe him
Note: Alternate translation: “carefully examine him”

Quote: How long will it be … swallow down my own saliva?
Note: Here Job conveys a single idea using two different rhetorical questions to emphasize his wish that God would stop watching him. Alternate translation: “Look away from me! Leave me alone long enough for me to swallow my own saliva!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: saliva
Note: liquid produced in people’s mouths that keeps the mouth moist and helps to swallow food

Quote: Even if I have sinned … burden for you?
Note: Job poses these questions to argue against God treating him unfairly. Alternate translation: “Even if I have sinned, that would do nothing to you, as you watch over people. Tell me why you have made me your target, so that I am a burden for you.”

Quote: Why do you not pardon my transgression and take away my iniquity?
Note: Here Job uses two similar clauses within a rhetorical question to emphasize his point. Possible meanings are: (1) Job is asking why God does not forgive him. Alternate translation: “Tell me why you do not pardon my transgression and take away my iniquity.” or (2) Job is asking God why he cannot just overlook his supposed wrongdoings. Alternate translation: “Tell me why you do not just bear with my transgression and iniquity.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: take away
Note: Alternate translation: “remove”

Quote: now will I lie down in the dust
Note: The phrase “lie down in the dust” is a metonym that represents dying. Alternate translation: “now I will die”

Quote: I will not exist
Note: Alternate translation: “I will not be here” or “I will be gone”

# Job 8 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is the advice of Job’s friend, Bildad.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Bildad’s advice
Bildad tells Job to curse Yahweh. The advice Bildad gives to Job is bad advice. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Bildad uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Job that he is wrong. These questions help to build Bildad’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

# General Information:\n\nVerses 2 and 3 each consist of two different questions that have the same meaning. Bildad uses these questions to rebuke Job. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nIn this chapter, Bildad begins to speak about Job’s complaints.

Quote: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered
Note: “Bildad” is the name of a man who is a member of the tribe of Shuah.

Quote: How long will the words of your mouth be a mighty wind?
Note: Bildad speaks of Job’s words as if they are as empty and insubstantial as the wind. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The words of your mouth are as insignificant as a mighty wind.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Does God pervert justice? Does the Almighty pervert righteousness?
Note: Here “God” and “the Almighty” both refer to Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express the idea behind these questions as statements. Alternate translation: “God does not pervert justice; the Almighty does not pervert righteousness.”

Quote: pervert justice? & pervert righteousness?
Note: Alternate translation: “approve of and do what is not just? … approve of and do what is not righteous?”

Quote: for he gave them into the hand of their sins
Note: Here “hand” represents the power or results of sin. Bildad implies that God killed Job’s children because of their sin. Alternate translation: “for God caused the consequences of your children’s sins to kill them” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: But suppose you diligently sought God and presented your request to the Almighty
Note: Bildad is saying what would have happened if Job had correctly spoken to God, but Bildad does not believe that Job really did this.

Quote: diligently sought God … presented your request to the Almighty
Note: These two phrases both refer to Job asking God for help or pleading with God for mercy.

Quote: diligently sought God
Note: Alternate translation: “earnestly asked God for help”
# General Information:\n\nBildad says that God would treat Job well if he was pure, but Bildad does not believe that Job is pure.

Quote: If you are pure and upright
Note: Alternate translation: “If only you were pure and righteous” or “If only you would obey God and do what is right”

Quote: stir himself on your behalf
Note: Here Yahweh is spoken of as if he woke from sleep to help Job. Alternate translation: “help you” or “do good things for you”

Quote: restore you to your rightful place
Note: This refers to giving back to Job the things he lost, including his family, wealth, and honor.

Quote: Even though your beginning was small, still your final condition would be much greater
Note: Here lack of wealth is spoken of as being a “small beginning.” Alternate translation: “Even if you were poor early in your life, God would make you very wealthy later in your life”

Quote: give your attention to what our ancestors learned
Note: Alternate translation: “study carefully what our ancestors discovered” or “consider the things our forefathers learned”

Quote: our days on earth are a shadow
Note: The shortness of life is spoken of as if it were a shadow which quickly disappears.

Quote: Will they not teach you and tell you? Will they not speak words from their hearts?
Note: Bildad uses these rhetorical questions to rebuke Job for not agreeing with Bildad and the ancestors. They can be translated as statements. Alternate translation: “They will teach you and tell you and speak what they sincerely believe.”

Quote: from their hearts
Note: Here the word “hearts” represents their inner beliefs. Alternate translation: “that they sincerely believe”
# General Information:\n\nIt is unclear if this verse is the teaching of Bildad, or if Bildad is quoting the sayings of the ancestors of [Job 8:8–10](./08.md).

Quote: Can papyrus grow without a marsh? Can reeds grow without water?
Note: Bildad uses these two parallel questions to emphasize the single point that people cannot live without God. Here the plants represent people and the water represents God. The questions can be translated as statements. Alternate translation: “Papyrus plants cannot grow away from the marshes. Reeds cannot grow without water.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: papyrus
Note: a tall reed-like plant that grows in shallow water
# General Information:\n\nIt is unclear if this verse is the teaching of Bildad, or if Bildad is quoting the sayings of the ancestors of [Job 8:8–10](./08.md).

Quote: While they are still green and not cut down, they wither before any other plant
Note: It is implied that they wither when there is no water. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “Without water, they stop growing and wither faster than any other plant, even if no one cuts them down”

Quote: wither
Note: Alternate translation: “dry up”
# General Information:\n\nIt is unclear if this verse is the teaching of Bildad, or if Bildad is quoting the sayings of the ancestors of [Job 8:8–10](./08.md).

Quote: So also are the paths of all who forget God
Note: Here “the paths” represents a person’s future and the events that will happen to them. Alternate translation: “The same thing will happen to everyone who forgets God”

Quote: the hope of the godless will perish
Note: Alternate translation: “the things the godless person desires will not happen”

# General Information:\n\nIt is unclear if this verse is the teaching of Bildad, or if Bildad is quoting the sayings of the ancestors of [Job 8:8–10](./08.md). In this verse the pronoun “his” refers to the godless person, who represents godless people in general. It may be helpful to readers to use the plural pronouns “they” and “their.”

Quote: His confidence will break apart … his trust is as weak as a spider’s web
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the godless person is trusting in something that cannot save him.

Quote: his trust is as weak as a spider’s web
Note: Here Bildad compares the trust of the godless person to a spider’s web; the slightest force will break both.

# General Information:\n\nIn this verse the pronouns “he” and “him” refer to the godless person, who represents godless people in general. It may be helpful to readers to use the plural pronouns “they” and “their.”

Quote: He leans on his house, but it will not support him; he takes hold of it, but it does not stand
Note: This statement probably refers to a man relying on his property and wealth for security. If so, then “house” here represents the owner’s property and wealth. Alternate translation: “He thinks he will be safe because he is wealthy, but he will not be safe”

Quote: it will not support him
Note: This negative statement emphasizes the opposite. It can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “he will fall down”

Quote: it does not stand
Note: This negative statement emphasizes the opposite. It can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “it will fall down”

# General Information:\n\nHere pronouns “he” and “his” refer to the godless person, who represents godless people in general. It may be helpful to readers to use the plural pronouns “they” and “their.”

Quote: Under the sun he is green, and his shoots go out over his entire garden
Note: Here Bildad compares the godless person to a plant that is healthy.

Quote: Under the sun he is green
Note: The meaning of the Hebrew text is unclear. This could mean: (1) he is healthy during the day or (2) he is watered before the sun rises.

# General Information:\n\nIn this verse the pronoun “his” refers to the godless person, who represents godless people in general. It may be helpful to readers to use the plural pronouns “they” and “their.”

Quote: His roots are wrapped about the heaps of stone … they look for good places among the rocks
Note: These two phrases have similar meaning, but the meaning is unclear. This could mean: (1) he appears to be well-rooted in the rocks, taking advantage of every opening or (2) his roots cannot find fertile ground and must try to find nutrients among the rocks. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# General Information:\n\nIn this verse the pronouns “his” and “him” refer to the godless person, who represents godless people in general. It may be helpful to readers to use the plural pronouns “they” and “their.”

Quote: if this person is destroyed out of his place
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “if someone pulls him out of his place” or “if a gardener tears him out of the garden”

Quote: his place
Note: Alternate translation: “the rocky ground” or “the garden”

Quote: that place will deny him and say, ‘I never saw you.’
Note: The garden is spoken of as if it had human ability to speak. The garden immediately forgets that he existed. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: this is the “joy” of such a person’s behavior
Note: Bildad is speaking with irony to express that there is not any real joy for the godless person. Alternate translation: “this is all the joy they will receive from their godless actions”

Quote: other plants will sprout out of the same soil in his place
Note: Bildad continues the metaphor from [Job 8:16–18](./16.md). Other godless people are spoken of as plants who take the place of the first godless man when he dies. Alternate translation: “when one wicked man dies, another will take his place”

Quote: sprout
Note: Alternate translation: “grow”

Quote: the same soil
Note: Alternate translation: “the rocky ground” or “the garden”

Quote: in his place
Note: Alternate translation: “in the place of the godless man”

Quote: God will not cast away an innocent man
Note: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “God will accept an innocent man”

Quote: neither will he take the hand of evildoers
Note: Here “take the hand” refers to help or support. Alternate translation: “God will not support people who do evil things”

Quote: He will yet fill your mouth with laughter, your lips with shouting
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how happy Job would be if he were innocent. The word “he” refers to God and “your” refers to Job. Alternate translation: “God will make you very happy again if you are innocent” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: fill your mouth with laughter
Note: God causing Job to laugh is spoken of as if God had poured laughter into Job’s mouth. Alternate translation: “cause you to continually laugh”

Quote: your lips with shouting
Note: The verb “fill” is understood from the previous clause. God causing him to shout for joy is spoken of as if God had poured joy into Job’s mouth. Alternate translation: “God will cause you to shout for joy” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Those who hate you will be clothed with shame
Note: Here “shame” is spoken of as if it were clothing that God will cause Job’s enemies to wear. This means they will be very ashamed. Alternate translation: “God will cause those who hate you to be very ashamed”

Quote: the tent of the wicked will be no more
Note: Here “tent” refers to the homes of the wicked. Alternate translation: “the houses of the wicked will be destroyed”

Quote: will be no more
Note: Alternate translation: “will not last” or “will be destroyed”

# Job 9 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Bildad.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s righteousness and Yahweh’s power
Despite being upset about his circumstances, Job does not curse God. Job does not think that he can make a claim against Yahweh because only God is perfectly wise and just. Yahweh is truly powerful and Job understands this. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/justice]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphors

Job uses many different metaphors in this chapter to express himself or to describe Yahweh’s power. He is also upset with the advice of his friends, who are supposed to help him during difficult times. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Bildad that he is wrong. These questions help to build Job’s response. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: I truly know that this is so
Note: Alternate translation: “I know that what you say is true”

Quote: this is so
Note: Here the word “this” refers to what Bildad said.

Quote: how can a person be in the right with God?
Note: Alternate translation: “how can anyone be innocent before God?”

Quote: argue
Note: dispute

Quote: he cannot answer him once in a thousand times
Note: “Once in a thousand times” here is an idiom that means “at all.” This could mean: (1) “he cannot give any answer to God” or (2) “God will not answer him at all”

Quote: a thousand times
Note: Alternate translation: “1,000 times”

Quote: wise in heart
Note: Here the heart represents the inner being or thoughts. Alternate translation: “wise in what he decides”

Quote: mighty in strength
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **strength**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “strong.” Alternate translation: “mighty in how strong he is”

Quote: hardened himself against him
Note: To harden oneself means to be stubborn. Alternate translation: “resisted him” or “defied him”

Quote: he who removes the mountains
Note: Alternate translation: “God removes the mountains”

Quote: he who shakes the earth
Note: Alternate translation: “God shakes the earth”

Quote: sets its supports trembling
Note: Alternate translation: “makes its foundations tremble”

Quote: who covers up the stars
Note: Alternate translation: “who blocks the stars from view”

Quote: who by himself stretches out the heavens
Note: God is spoken of as creating the heavens without any help, as if the heavens were fabric that he stretches out. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: tramples down the waves of the sea
Note: God is spoken of as calming the sea as if with his feet. Alternate translation: “puts his feet down on the waves of the sea” or “calms the waves of the sea”

Quote: the Bear, Orion, the Pleiades
Note: These are the names of constellations, which are groups of stars that seem like they form a particular shape in the sky.

Quote: Orion
Note: a famous hunter in Greek mythology

Quote: Pleiades
Note: several bright stars that look like they are close together in the sky

Quote: constellations
Note: groups of stars that seem like they form a particular shape in the sky

Note: This verse expresses the same idea twice for emphasis.

Note: This is a nominalized adjective. Alternate translation: “innocent people”.

Quote: I would forget about my complaints

Note: Job uses this question to emphasize that he does not think it is of any use trying to get God’s attention. The implied information about what Job is trying can be made explicit. Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nThese verses continue the previous argument that no one is greater than God who could act as a judge between God and Job.

Quote: keep his terror from frightening me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **terror**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “terrify.” Alternate translation: “keep him from terrifying and frightening me”

Note: Alternate translation: “because this is how things are now”

# Job 10 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s response to Bildad.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s righteousness
Despite being upset about his circumstances, Job does not curse Yahweh. Instead, he defends himself to Yahweh, while trusting in his decision. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to defend himself. He does not believe that he committed a sin deserving severe punishment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: I am weary of my life
Note: Alternate translation: “I am tired of living”

Quote: I will give free expression to my complaint
Note: The abstract nouns “expression” and “complaint” can be translated as the verbs “express” and “complain.” Alternate translation: “I will freely express what I have to complain about” or “I will argue freely”

Quote: I will speak in the bitterness of my soul
Note: How Job feels is compared to a bitter taste. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **bitterness**, you can express the same idea with the adverb “bitterly.” Alternate translation: “My inner being will speak bitterly” or “I will bitterly speak out” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Is it good to you that you should oppress me, to despise the work of your hands while you smile on the plans of the wicked?
Note: This question expects a “no” answer and can be changed into a statement. Alternate translation: “It is not good that you should oppress me, that you should despise the work of your hands, while you smile on the plans of the wicked.”

Quote: the work of your hands
Note: Here God is represented by his “hands.” Alternate translation: “what you have created”

Quote: smile on the plans of the wicked
Note: Here the idiom “smiling on” represents God’s approval. Alternate translation: “approve the plans of the wicked”

Quote: Do you have eyes of flesh? Do you see like a man sees?
Note: These two questions have nearly the same meaning. These questions expect a negative answer to emphasize that God does not see or understand things the same way a man does. They can be expressed as statements. Alternate translation: “You do not have eyes of flesh, and you do not see like a man sees.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Job begins to ask a rhetorical question. He is saying that God lives forever but people live only for a short time, so God should not worry about Job’s sins.

Quote: your days like the days of mankind … your years like the years of people
Note: These two phrases have nearly the same meaning.

Quote: your days
Note: Alternate translation: “the number of your days”

Quote: your years
Note: Alternate translation: “the number of your years”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues the rhetorical question he began in verse 5. (See: rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion)

Quote: inquire after my iniquity
Note: Alternate translation: “look to see if I have committed iniquity”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nThis is the end of the rhetorical question that begins with the words “Are your days” in verse 5.

Quote: although you know … from your hand?
Note: This is the end of the rhetorical question that begins with the words “Are your days” in verse 5. The whole question can be translated as a statement. “Your days are not like the days of mankind, and your years are not like the years of people, so you should not inquire after my iniquity and search after my sin, because you know I am not guilty and there is no one who can rescue me from your hand.”

Quote: from your hand
Note: Here “your hand” represents God’s power. Alternate translation: “from your power”

Quote: Your hands
Note: Here “hands” represent God and his creative action. Alternate translation: “You”

Quote: Your hands have framed and fashioned me together round about
Note: Job is using a metaphor of a potter forming clay to describe how God carefully created him.

Quote: framed and fashioned me
Note: “shaped and formed me.” The words “framed” and “fashioned” are similar in meaning.

Quote: Call to mind
Note: Alternate translation: “Remember”

Quote: bring me into dust again
Note: Alternate translation: “turn me back into dust again”
# General Information:\n\nIn these verses, Job uses the language of poetry to describe how God formed him in the womb.

Quote: Have you not poured me out like milk and curdled me like cheese?
