Note: This is a question that expects a positive answer. Alternate translation: “You poured me out like milk and curdled me like cheese.” or “You formed me in the womb like poured milk becomes cheese.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: you
Note: Here “you” refers to God.

Quote: me
Note: Here “me” refers to Job.

Quote: You have clothed me with skin and flesh
Note: God putting skin and flesh on Job’s body is spoken of as if God was putting clothing on him. Alternate translation: “You have put skin and flesh on my body”

Quote: knit me together
Note: “wove me together.” God putting Job’s body together in the womb is spoken of as if God was knitting or weaving a piece of cloth. Alternate translation: “put me together”

Quote: sinews
Note: the parts of the body that connect muscles to bones or other body parts and are like tough, white bands or cords

Quote: You have granted me life and covenant faithfulness
Note: The abstract nouns “life” and “faithfulness” can be stated as “live” and “faithful.” Alternate translation: “You have been faithful to your covenant and allowed me to live”

Quote: your help
Note: Alternate translation: “your care”

Quote: guarded my spirit
Note: Here Job is represented by his “spirit.” Alternate translation: “guarded me” or “watched carefully over me” or “kept me safe”

Quote: you would notice it
Note: Alternate translation: “you would watch me”

Quote: If I have acted wickedly
Note: Alternate translation: “If I do evil things”

Quote: woe to me
Note: Alternate translation: “how terrible will it be for me”

Quote: lift up my head
Note: This idiom means to be sure or confident. Alternate translation: “hold my head up” or “be confident” or “be sure about myself”

Quote: I am filled with disgrace—see my affliction
Note: Another possible meaning, followed by some versions, is, “I am full of disgrace and am completely full of my own suffering,” where the disgrace is bad but the suffering is even worse.

Quote: I am filled with disgrace
Note: Alternate translation: “I am totally ashamed” or “No one respects me anymore”

Quote: disgrace
Note: shame

Quote: see my affliction
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **affliction**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “afflict.” Alternate translation: “see how God is afflicting me”

Quote: If my head were lifted up, you would stalk me like a lion
Note: This could mean: (1) this is a hypothetical situation that has not happened or (2) this is a description of a situation that happens repeatedly. Alternate translation: “When my head is lifted up, you stalk me like a lion”

Quote: If my head were lifted up
Note: This idiom means to become self-confident or proud. Alternate translation: “If I become proud” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])

Quote: you would stalk me like a lion
Note: Possible meanings of this simile are: (1) God hunts Job like a lion hunts its prey or (2) Job is like a lion being hunted by God.

Quote: again you would show yourself with marvellous acts of power against me
Note: This phrase expresses irony in how God displays his marvelous power by acting to harm Job. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])

Quote: You bring new witnesses against me
Note: Job’s troubles from God are spoken of as if they were people who were witnesses against him.

Quote: increase your anger against me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **anger**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “angry.” Alternate translation: “are more and more angry with me”

Quote: you attack me with fresh armies
Note: God sending troubles against Job is spoken of as if God was constantly sending new armies against him.

Quote: brought me out of the womb
Note: Here being brought out of the womb represents being born into this world. Alternate translation: “brought me out of my mother’s womb” or “brought me into this world”

Quote: given up my spirit
Note: Giving up one’s spirit represents dying. Alternate translation: “died”

Quote: and that no eye had ever seen me
Note: Job uses “eye” here to refer to the whole person. He wishes he could have died at birth, before anyone saw him. Alternate translation: “before any person had ever seen me” or “before I was born”

Quote: I had never existed
Note: Alternate translation: “I had never lived”

Quote: I would have been carried
Note: Alternate translation: “My body would have been carried”

Quote: Are not my days only a few?
Note: Here “my days” represent the length of Job’s life. This question expects a positive answer, to emphasize that Job only expects to live a few more days. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I only have a few days left to live.” or “My life will soon end.”

Quote: the land
Note: Here the place where the spirits of dead people go is spoken of as if it was a land. Alternate translation: “the place”

Quote: of darkness and of the shadow of death
Note: The phrase “shadow of death” intensifies the idea of “darkness.” Both phrases describe where the spirits of dead people go.

Quote: the shadow of death
Note: See how you translated this in [Job 3:5](../03/05.md).

Quote: as dark as midnight
Note: The darkness of the place where the spirits of dead people go is compared to the darkness of midnight.

Quote: without any order
Note: This negative phrase can be expressed in positive form. Alternate translation: “full of confusion” or “where all is confused”

Quote: where the light is like midnight
Note: The light of the place where the spirits of dead people go is compared to midnight. Alternate translation: “where there is no light”

# Job 11 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is the advice of Job’s friend, Zophar.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Zophar’s advice

Zophar tells Job to curse Yahweh. The advice Zophar gives to Job is bad advice. He even questions the character of God. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Zophar uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Job that he is wrong. These questions help to build Zophar’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Zophar the Naamathite
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Job 2:11](../02/11.md). Alternate translation: “Zophar from the region of Naamah”

Quote: Should not such a multitude of words be answered?
Note: Zophar is asking a question in the negative to emphasize that Job’s words must be challenged. Alternate translation: “We must answer all of these words!” or “Someone should respond to all these words!”

Quote: Should this man, so full of talk, be believed?
Note: Zophar uses this question to emphasize that they should not believe what Job was saying. Alternate translation: “This man is so full of talk, but the people should not believe him!” or “Your many words alone do not mean you are innocent!”

Quote: Should your boasting make others remain silent?
Note: Zophar uses this question to rebuke Job. Alternate translation: “Just because you have spoken many words, this does not mean that others must keep silent.”

Quote: When you mock, will no one make you feel ashamed?
Note: Zophar uses this question to rebuke Job. You may need to make explicit what it is that Job is mocking. Alternate translation: “You have mocked us for what we have said. Now we will make you feel ashamed!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: My beliefs are pure
Note: Alternate translation: “My understanding is correct”

Quote: I am blameless in your eyes
Note: The eyes represent sight, which is a metaphor for God’s evaluation of Job. This could mean: (1) that Job is saying that God judges him as blameless. Alternate translation: “You say that I am blameless” or (2) that Job believes he has been blameless and that God should judge him as blameless. Alternate translation: “You should recognize that I am blameless”

Quote: that God would speak … open his lips against you
Note: The words “open his lips” are a metonym that means speak. These two phrases mean the same thing and are used together to emphasize Zophar’s desire that God would speak harshly against Job. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: that he would show … secrets of wisdom
Note: What the “secrets of wisdom” are can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “that he would show you that you are suffering because of your sin”

Quote: God demands from you less than your iniquity deserves
Note: Demanding from Job represents punishing Job. Alternate translation: “God is punishing you less than you deserve”

Quote: Can you understand God by searching for him? Can you comprehend the Almighty perfectly?
Note: These two parallel questions are asking the same thing. The writer uses the form of a question to add emphasis. Alternate translation: “You cannot understand God by searching for him, and you will never completely understand the Almighty!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: The matter
Note: This refers to understanding God. Alternate translation: “To understand God”

Quote: is as high as heaven … deeper than Sheol
Note: The impossibility of understanding God is spoken of as if it were impossible to go to these extremely far away places. Alternate translation: “is as inaccessible as the highest places in heaven … is more inaccessible than the deepest places in Sheol” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: what can you do?
Note: Zophar uses this question to show that a person cannot do anything to understand God fully. Alternate translation: “you cannot do anything.” or “you cannot understand him fully.”

Quote: what can you know?
Note: Zophar uses this question to show that a person cannot do anything to know God fully. Alternate translation: “you cannot know God fully.” or “you cannot know all there is to know.”

Quote: Its measure
Note: This could mean: (1) God’s greatness or (2) the greatness of God’s wisdom.

Quote: is longer than the earth … wider than the sea
Note: God’s greatness or wisdom is spoken of as if it could be measured in distance.

Quote: If he … shuts anyone up
Note: Alternate translation: “If God … shuts anyone up in prison”

Quote: if he calls anyone to judgment
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **judgment**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “judge.” Alternate translation: “if God calls anyone to go to him so that God might judge him”

Quote: who can stop him?
Note: This question emphasizes that no one can stop God. Alternate translation: “no one can stop him!”

Quote: does he not notice it?
Note: This emphasizes that God does notice sin. Alternate translation: “he surely notices it!”

Quote: But foolish people have no understanding
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **understanding**, you can express the same idea with the verb “understand.” Alternate translation: “But foolish people do not understand”

Quote: they will get it when a wild donkey gives birth to a man
Note: Since a wild donkey can never give birth to a man, this means that foolish people will never get understanding. Alternate translation: “only if a wild donkey could give birth to a man could foolish people get understanding” or “it is as impossible for a foolish person to get understanding as it is for a donkey to give birth to a man”

Quote: suppose that you had set your heart right
Note: The heart represents thoughts and attitudes. Setting it right represents correcting it. Alternate translation: “even if you had corrected your attitude”

Quote: had reached out with your hands toward God
Note: This is a symbolic action representing asking God for help. Alternate translation: “had made an appeal and prayed to God”

Quote: suppose that iniquity were in your hand
Note: The hand represents what a person does. Alternate translation: “even if you had done some evil things in the past”

Quote: but that then you put it far away from you
Note: Putting sin behind represents stopping sinning. Alternate translation: “but that then you stopped doing evil things”

Quote: did not let unrighteousness live in your tents
Note: Unrighteousness living represents people doing unrighteous things. Alternate translation: “and you did not allow the members of your household to do unrighteous things”

Quote: lift up your face without a sign of shame
Note: “Lifting up your face” represents the attitude of a person who is confident and brave. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: you would remember it only like waters that have flowed away
Note: Zophar is comparing misery with water that flows downstream and it is gone. Alternate translation: “You would remember it, but the misery will be gone, like waters that have flowed away”

Quote: Your life would … like the morning.
Note: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis.

Quote: Your life would be brighter than the noonday
Note: Brightness represents being prosperous and happy. Alternate translation: “Your life would be prosperous and happy like the noonday”

Quote: though there were darkness
Note: Darkness represents troubles and sadness. Alternate translation: “Though there were dark troubles and sadness”

Quote: it would become like the morning
Note: The morning represents light, which represents prosperity and happiness. Alternate translation: “it would be prosperous and happy like the morning”

Quote: You would be secure … take your rest in safety
Note: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis and describes the possibility. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: would take your rest in safety
Note: “Take your rest” here is an idiom for “rest.” The phrase “in safety” can be expressed with the word “safely.” Alternate translation: “would rest safely” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Also you would lie down in rest … your favor.
Note: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis and describes the possibility. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: you would lie down in rest
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **rest**, you can express the same idea with the verb “rest.” Alternate translation: “you would lie down and rest”

Quote: the eyes of wicked people will fail
Note: Their eyes represent their understanding. Alternate translation: “the understanding of the wicked people will fail” or “the wicked people will not be able to understand”

# Job 12 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Zophar.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s righteousness
Despite being upset about his circumstances, Job does not curse God. His friends, on the other hand, judge Job’s case, which Job recognizes to be Yahweh’s authority. These three friends therefore try to take God’s place. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/judge]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphors

Job uses many different metaphors in this chapter to express his pain or despair. He is also upset with the advice of his friends, who are supposed to help him during difficult times. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Zophar that he is wrong. These questions help to build Job’s response. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: No doubt you are the people; wisdom will die with you
Note: Job mocks how they are acting and shows how ridiculous they sound. Alternate translation: “Surely you are such important people that wisdom cannot exist without you” or “You all act like you are the only wise people and that when you die, wisdom will disappear”

Quote: No doubt
Note: Alternate translation: “Surely”

Quote: you
Note: This is plural in verses 2 and 3.

Quote: you are the people
Note: Alternate translation: “you are the important people who know everything”

Quote: Indeed, who does not know such things as these?
Note: Job used this question to express a truth that should be obvious to his listeners. It can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: “Certainly there is no one who does not know such things as these.” or “Certainly everyone knows these things.”

Quote: I am something for my neighbor to laugh at—I, one who called on God and who was answered by him!
Note: The relationship between these phrases can be made clear with the words “even though.” Alternate translation: “I am something for my neighbor to laugh at—even though I am one who called on God and he answered me!”

Quote: I, a just and blameless man—I am now something to laugh at
Note: The relationship between these phrases can be made clear with the words “even though.” Alternate translation: “Even though I am a just and blameless man, people now laugh at me”

Quote: In the thought of someone who is at ease, there is contempt for misfortune
Note: The abstract nouns “thought,” “ease,” “contempt,” and “misfortune” can be expressed with other phrases. Alternate translation: “A person who lives an easy life despises a person who suffers”

Quote: brings more misfortune
Note: Bringing misfortune represents causing it to happen. Alternate translation: “causes more bad things to happen”

Quote: to those whose foot is slipping
Note: The foot slipping represents being in danger or trouble. Alternate translation: “to those who are already in trouble”

Quote: The tents of robbers prosper
Note: Their tents prospering represents the robbers prospering in their tents. Alternate translation: “Robbers live in prosperity in their own tents”

Quote: their own hands are their gods
Note: Here “their own hands” is a metonym for strength, and “their gods” is a metaphor for their pride. Alternate translation: “they are extremely proud of their own abilities” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: But now ask the beasts … the birds … they will tell you
Note: Job is saying that the beasts and the birds understand God better than Job’s friends do.

Quote: you
Note: All occurrences of “you” are plural.

Quote: But now ask the beasts, and they will teach you
Note: The command in the first part of the sentence functions as a hypothetical condition. Alternate translation: “But if you were to ask the beasts, they would teach you” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: ask the birds of the heavens, and they will tell you
Note: The command in the first part of the sentence functions as a hypothetical condition. Alternate translation: if you were to ask the birds of the heavens, they would tell you” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: speak to the earth … will declare to you
Note: Job is saying that the beasts, the birds, the earth, and the fish understand God better than Job’s friends do.

Quote: Or speak to the earth, and it will teach you
Note: The command in the first part of the sentence functions as a hypothetical condition. Alternate translation: “Or if you were to speak to the earth, it would teach you” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: the fish of the sea will declare to you
Note: The command “Ask the fish of the sea” is understood from the previous sentences. It functions as a hypothetical condition. Alternate translation: “and if you were to ask the fish of the sea, they would declare to you” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-imperative]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: Which animal among all these does not know … this?
Note: This question emphasizes the point that all the animals know that Yahweh has done this. This question can be worded as a statement. Alternate translation: “Every animal among all these knows … this.”

Quote: the hand of Yahweh has done this
Note: Yahweh’s hand represents his power. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has done this by his power”

Quote: In his hand is the life … and the breath of all mankind
Note: Yahweh’s hand represents his control or power. Alternate translation: “God controls the life of every living thing and gives breath to all mankind”

Quote: the breath of all mankind
Note: Here “breath” represents life or the ability to live.

Quote: Does not the ear test words just as the palate tastes its food?
Note: Job uses this question to emphasize that people listen to what others say and judge whether it is good or not. The ear and palate are metonyms for hearing and tasting. Alternate translation: “We hear what people say and test it just as we taste food and test it.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: With aged men is wisdom
Note: “Aged men have wisdom.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **wisdom**, you can express the same idea with “wise.” The word “men” refers to people in general. Alternate translation: “Old people are wise” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])

Quote: in length of days is understanding
Note: This represents people gaining understanding when they live a long time. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **understanding**, you can express the same idea with the phrase “understand much.” Alternate translation: “people gain understanding when they live a long time” or “people who live a long time understand much”
# General Information:\n\nVerse 13 says that God is wise and mighty. The rest of this chapter shows that this is true by telling about the wise and mighty things that God does.

Quote: With God are wisdom and might
Note: The abstract nouns “wisdom” and “might” can be expressed with the adjectives “wise” and “mighty.” Alternate translation: “God is wise and mighty”

Quote: See
Note: Alternate translation: “Look” or “Listen” or “Pay attention to what I am about to tell you”

Quote: it cannot be built again
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one can rebuild it”

Quote: if he imprisons someone, there can be no release
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **release**, you can express the same idea with the verb “free.” Alternate translation: “if God shuts someone in, no one can free him”

Quote: if he withholds the waters, they dry up
Note: Possible meanings are that withholding waters represents: (1) preventing the rain from falling. Alternate translation: “if he stops the rain from falling the land dries up” or (2) preventing running water from flowing. Alternate translation: “if he stops the water from flowing, the land dries up”

Quote: if he sends them out, they overwhelm the land
Note: Possible meanings are that sending them out is a metaphor meaning: (1) causing the rain to fall. Alternate translation: “if he causes a lot of rain to fall, it floods the land” or (2) causing the waters to flow. Alternate translation: “if he makes a lot of water flow, it floods the land”

Quote: With him are strength and wisdom
Note: The abstract nouns “strength” and “wisdom” can be expressed with the words “strong” and “wise.” Alternate translation: “God is strong and wise”

Quote: people who are deceived and the deceiver are both in his power
Note: Being in God’s power represents God ruling over them. Alternate translation: “people who believe a lie and people who lie to others are both in his power” or “God rules over both people who believe lies and people who lie to others”

Quote: He leads counselors away barefoot
Note: Leading counselors away barefoot represents taking away their wisdom and authority.

Quote: in sorrow
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **sorrow**, you can express the same idea with the words “sad” or “grieve” Alternate translation: “and they feel very sad” or “and they grieve”

Quote: he turns judges into fools
Note: Alternate translation: “he makes judges become foolish”

Quote: He takes off the chain of authority from kings
Note: Possible meanings are that: (1) this is a metonym for causing kings to no longer have authority. Alternate translation: “He takes away the authority of kings” or (2) this is a metonym for setting people free from the chains that kings have put on them. Alternate translation: “He takes off the bonds that kings have put on people”

Quote: he wraps a cloth about their waists
Note: This cloth is probably what a slave wears. To put these cloths on kings represents making the kings slaves. Alternate translation: “he makes kings wear the clothing of slaves” or “he makes them slaves”

Quote: He leads priests away barefoot
Note: Leading priests away barefoot represents taking away their authority.

Quote: in sorrow
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **sorrow**, you can express the same idea with the words “sad” or “grieve” Alternate translation: “and they feel sad” or “and they grieve”

Quote: overthrows mighty people
Note: Alternate translation: “defeats powerful people”

Quote: He removes the speech of those who had been trusted
Note: Removing their speech represents making them unable to speak. Alternate translation: “He makes those who were trusted unable to speak” or “He silences people whom others trusted”

Quote: takes away the understanding of the elders
Note: Taking away their understanding represents making them unable to understand or make good decisions. Alternate translation: “makes the elders unable to understand” or “makes the elders unable to make good decisions”

Quote: the elders
Note: This could mean: (1) the older people or (2) the leaders.

Quote: He pours contempt upon princes
Note: Pouring contempt on princes is a metaphor for causing people to feel contempt for them. Alternate translation: “He causes people to greatly disrespect those who rule”

Quote: unfastens the belt of strong people
Note: The belt is a symbol of strength. Unfastening a strong person’s belt represents taking away his strength and making him weak. Alternate translation: “makes the strong people weak”

Quote: He reveals the deep things of darkness
Note: Revealing things represents making them known. “Deep things from darkness” represent secrets that people do not know. Alternate translation: “He makes known secrets that people do not know”

Quote: brings deep shadows into the light
Note: Bringing things out into the light represents making them known, and here “shadows” is a metonym for the things that are hidden in the shadows, which in turn are a metaphor for truths that God has hidden from people. Alternate translation: “makes known things that no one can see” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: He enlarges nations
Note: Alternate translation: “He makes nations larger” or “He makes nations have more land”

Quote: he also leads them along as prisoners
Note: God leading nations represents God causing enemy nations to lead them. The word “them” represents nations, which here represents the people of those nations. Alternate translation: “he also causes their enemies to lead them along as prisoners”

Quote: He takes away understanding from the leaders of the people of the earth
Note: Taking away their understanding represents causing them to be unable to understand. Alternate translation: “He causes the leaders of the people of the earth to be unable to understand”

Quote: to wander in a wilderness where there is no path
Note: Wandering in a wilderness where there is no path represents being in a difficult situation and not knowing what to do. Alternate translation: “to be unsure of what to do like a person wandering in a wasteland with no path”

Quote: They grope in the dark without light
Note: Being in the dark without light represents lacking knowledge. Alternate translation: “They struggle to make decisions without knowledge as people struggle to walk in the dark without light”

Quote: he makes them stagger like a drunk man
Note: Staggering or wandering like a drunk man represents living without purpose. Alternate translation: “he makes them live without purpose like a drunk person who staggers as he walks” or “they wander aimlessly like a drunk person who staggers back and forth”

# Job 13 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s response to Zophar. It also contains Job’s claim of righteousness to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s righteousness
Despite being upset about his circumstances, Job does not curse God. His friends, on the other hand, judge Job’s case, which Job recognizes to be Yahweh’s authority. These three friends therefore try to take God’s place. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/judge]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Zophar that he is wrong. These questions help to build Job’s response. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to speak to his friends.

Quote: See
Note: Alternate translation: “Look” or “Listen” or “Pay attention to what I am about to tell you”

Quote: my eye has seen all this
Note: Job referred to himself as his eye since it is with his eyes that he saw these things. Alternate translation: “I have seen all this”

Quote: my ear has heard and understood it
Note: Job referred to himself as his ear since it is with his ears that he heard these things. Alternate translation: “I have heard and understood it”

Quote: What you know, the same I also know
Note: Alternate translation: “What you know, I also know” or “I know as much as you”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to speak to his friends.

Quote: I wish to reason with God
Note: Job’s friends are judging him, but they not speaking the truth. Job would rather argue with God alone about his complaint.

Quote: you whitewash the truth with lies
Note: Putting whitewash or plaster on the truth represents ignoring the truth. Alternate translation: “you hide the truth with lies” or “you lie and ignore the truth”

Quote: you are all physicians of no value
Note: Being a physician represents being a person who comforts others. Being of no value means that they do not know how to do what they should. Alternate translation: “you are all like physicians who do not know how to heal people” or “you all come to comfort me, but you do not know how, like unskilled physicians”

Quote: hold your peace
Note: This expression means “be quiet” or “stop talking.”

Quote: That would be your wisdom
Note: They thought that they were saying wise things, but Job was saying that they would be wiser if they would stop talking. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **wisdom**, you can express the same idea with another word such as “wise.” Alternate translation: “If you were to do that, you would be wise” or “If you were to stop talking, you would appear wise”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to speak to his friends.

Quote: listen to the pleading of my own lips
Note: Here “lips” represent the person who is speaking. Alternate translation: “listen to what I myself plead for”

Quote: Will you speak unrighteously … deceitfully for him?
Note: Job uses these two questions to rebuke his friends for speaking unrighteously. Alternate translation: “You think that you are speaking for God, but you are speaking unrighteously. You are speaking deceitfully.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: talk deceitfully
Note: Alternate translation: “lie” or “tell lies”

Quote: Will you show him partiality? Will you argue the case for God?
Note: Showing kindness to God represents helping God or defending God against Job’s complaints. Job uses these questions to rebuke his friends for thinking that they can defend God. Alternate translation: “You think that God need you to defend him? You think that you can argue for God like attorneys in court.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to speak to his friends.

Quote: Will it be good for you when he searches you out?
Note: Here “searches you out” is a metaphor meaning “examines you.” Job uses this question to warn his friends that if God were to examine them, he would say that what they are doing is wrong. Alternate translation: “When God examines you, it will not be good for you.”

Quote: Could you deceive him as you might deceive men?
Note: Job uses this question to warn his friends that God knows the truth about them. Alternate translation: “You might be able to deceive men, but you cannot deceive God.”

Quote: reprove you
Note: Alternate translation: “rebuke you”

Quote: if in secret you showed partiality
Note: “if you secretly show favor to another.” Showing partiality refers to saying only good things about someone so that the judge will say that the person is good. Doing this in secret means pretending to speak fairly, but really favoring one person over another.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to speak to his friends.

Quote: Will not his majesty terrify you, and the dread of him fall upon you?
Note: Job uses these questions to rebuke his friends. This could mean: (1) Job is saying that they should fear God. Alternate translation: “His majesty should make you afraid, and his dread should fall on you.” or (2) Job is saying that they will fear God. Alternate translation: “His majesty will make you afraid, and his dread will fall on you!”

Quote: and the dread of him fall upon you
Note: Dread falling on people represents them becoming terribly afraid. Alternate translation: “and you not be terribly afraid” or “and you not be terrified”

Quote: Your memorable sayings are proverbs made of ashes
Note: Ashes represent things that are worthless and do not last. Alternate translation: “Your memorable sayings are worthless like ashes” or “Your memorable sayings will be forgotten like ashes that are blown away”

Quote: your defenses are defenses made of clay
Note: Job speaks of what they say as if it were a wall made of clay around a city; it cannot defend the people because clay breaks easily. Alternate translation: “What you say in defense is as useless as a wall of clay”

Quote: your defenses
Note: Possible meanings are that this refers to: (1) what they say to defend themselves or (2) what they say to defend God.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to speak to his friends.

Quote: Hold your peace
Note: This is an idiom meaning “Be quiet” or “Stop talking”

Quote: let me alone
Note: This is an idiom that means “stop bothering me” or “stop hindering me”

Quote: let come what may on me
Note: Things coming on a person represents things happening to a person. This expression starting with “let” means that he does not care what might happen to him. Alternate translation: “let whatever may happen to me happen” or “I do not care what may happen to me”

Quote: I will take my own flesh … in my hands
Note: “Flesh” here is a metonym for life. “Teeth” and “hands” are metonyms for his own control. These two phrases together emphasize that Job is willing to risk his life by arguing his case with God. Alternate translation: “I am ready to risk my life” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob finishes speaking to his friends and begins to address God directly.

Quote: This will be the reason for my deliverance
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **deliverance**, you can express the same idea with the verb “deliver.” Alternate translation: “This is the reason that God will deliver me” or “This is why God will save me from my troubles”

Quote: God, listen carefully
Note: Job begins directing his speech directly to God.

Quote: listen carefully to my speech; let my declaration come to your ears
Note: These two lines mean basically the same thing and intensify Job’s request for God to listen to him.

Quote: let my declaration come to your ears
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **declaration**, you can express the same idea with the verb “declare.” The ears represent listening. Alternate translation: “listen to my declaration” or “listen to what I declare” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to God.

Quote: See now
Note: This emphasizes what follows. “Listen now” or “Please pay special attention”

Quote: I have set my defense in order
Note: Setting his defense in order represents deciding what he will say to defend himself. Alternate translation: “I have thought through how I will defend myself” or “I have decided how I will explain myself”

Quote: Who is the one who would argue against me in court?
Note: Job uses this question to express his belief that since he is right, no one would argue against him. Alternate translation: “I do not believe that anyone would argue against me in court.”

Quote: If you came to do so
Note: Alternate translation: “If you came to argue against me”

Quote: If you
Note: “You” here means God himself.

Quote: if I were proved wrong
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “if you were to prove me wrong”

Quote: give up my life
Note: Giving up one’s life is a metaphor for dying. Alternate translation: “die”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to God.

Quote: from your face
Note: “Face” represents the person. Alternate translation: “from you”

Quote: withdraw your oppressive hand
Note: An oppressive hand is a metonym for doing things that oppress someone. Withdrawing the hand is a metaphor for stopping doing those things. Alternate translation: “stop oppressing me” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: do not let your terrors make me afraid
Note: The phrase “your terrors” refers to what causes people to be terrified of God. Alternate translation: “do not terrify me”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to God.

Quote: Why do you hide … like your enemy?
Note: Job asks this question to complain about how God is treating him. He probably hopes for an answer.

Quote: you hide your face from me
Note: Hiding one’s face from someone represents refusing to look at him or ignoring him. Alternate translation: “you refuse to look at me” or “you ignore me”

Quote: Will you persecute … pursue dry stubble?
Note: Job uses these questions to tell God that since Job is so insignificant and weak, it is useless to persecute him. “Leaf” and “stubble” are metaphors describing Job’s weakness, insignificance and frailty. Alternate translation: “You persecute me, but I am weak like a leaf blown by the wind and insignificant like dry stubble.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob finishes presenting his case to God.

Quote: For you write down bitter things against me
Note: “Bitter things” represents accusations. Alternate translation: “For you write down accusations against me”

Quote: you make me inherit the iniquities of my youth
Note: Inheriting the iniquities of his youth is a metaphor. This could mean: (1) being guilty for the sins of his youth. Alternate translation: “you say that I am still guilty for the sins of my youth” or (2) being punished for the sins of his youth. Alternate translation: “you punish me for the sins of my youth”

Quote: the iniquities of my youth
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **youth**, you can express the same idea with the word “young.” Alternate translation: “the sins I committed when I was young”

Quote: You also put my feet in the stocks
Note: Doing this represents punishing Job and keeping him from living freely as if Job had committed a crime and was a prisoner. Alternate translation: “It is as though you put my feet in the stocks”

Quote: the stocks
Note: This could mean: (1) a frame that holds a prisoner’s feet in place so that he cannot move at all or (2) chains around a prisoner’s feet that make it hard for him to walk. These are used as a form of punishment.

Quote: all my paths
Note: “Paths” represent the things Job does. Alternate translation: “everything I do”

Quote: you examine the ground where the soles of my feet have walked
Note: The soles of his feet represent the person who walks. Alternate translation: “you examine the ground where I have walked”

Quote: you examine the ground where the soles of my feet have walked
Note: Examining this ground represents examining all that Job has done. Alternate translation: “it is as though you examine the ground where I have walked” or “you examine everything I do like a person examining someone’s footprints on the ground”

Quote: like a rotten thing that wastes away
Note: Job compares his life to something that is decaying. He is slowly dying.

Quote: like a garment that moths have eaten
Note: Job compares himself to clothes that are full of holes because the moths have eaten parts of it.

# Job 14 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s claim of righteousness being presented to Yahweh. It also has an abrupt shift in tone. Rather than being hopeful, Job laments. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/lament]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Resurrection

The events of Job occurred long before the Old Testament was written. Therefore, he likely had very little direct revelation about Yahweh. The resurrection of the dead was apparently not well-known during Job’s day. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/reveal]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in his appeal to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Man, who is born of woman
Note: This refers to all people, both men and women; all are born into this world.

Quote: lives only a few days
Note: This is an exaggeration to emphasize that people live only a short time. Alternate translation: “lives only a very short time”

Quote: is full of trouble
Note: Being “full of trouble” represents experiencing much trouble. Alternate translation: “has many troubles” or “suffers much”

Quote: He sprouts from the ground like a flower and is cut down
Note: Like the life of a flower, a person’s life is short and is easily killed.

Quote: he flees like a shadow and does not last
Note: A person’s short life is compared to a shadow that disappears quickly.

Quote: Do you look at any of these?
Note: Job implies that he does not want God to pay so much attention to him. Alternate translation: “You do not look at any of these.” or “You do not pay so much attention to these. Please do not pay so much attention to me.”

Quote: look at
Note: Here looking at some one represents paying attention to him in order to judge him. Alternate translation: “pay attention to” or “look for faults in”

Quote: Do you bring me into judgment with you?
Note: Job uses this question to show his surprise that God judges him even though Job is so insignificant like the flowers. Alternate translation: “But you judge me.”

Quote: Who can bring something clean out of something unclean? No one
Note: Job uses this question to persuade God to apply what he knows about unclean things to Job. Alternate translation: “No one can bring something clean out of something unclean”

Quote: Man’s days are determined
Note: This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “You determine a man’s days” or “You decide how long a man lives”

Quote: The number of his months is with you
Note: The number of man’s months being with God represents God deciding the number of months that the man will live. “You decide how many months he will live”

Quote: you have appointed his limits that he cannot pass
Note: Passing a limit represents living past a time that God has set for a person to die. Alternate translation: “you have appointed the time that he will die, and he cannot live longer than that”

Quote: hired man
Note: a man who is hired to do a job and goes home afterwards

Quote: There can be hope for a tree
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **hope**, you can express the same idea with the verb “hope.” The hope is explained in verses 7–9. Alternate translation: “We can hope that a tree will live again” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: it might sprout again
Note: Alternate translation: “it might start growing again”

Quote: so that its tender stalk does not disappear
Note: Disappearing represents dying. Alternate translation: “so that its young shoot will not die”

Quote: Though
Note: Alternate translation: “Even if”

Quote: stump
Note: the part of the tree that remains sticking out of the ground after someone has cut down most of the tree

Quote: even if it only smells water
Note: This describes the dead stump as if it could smell water to represent water being near it. Alternate translation: “even if only a little water is near it”

Quote: it will bud
Note: Alternate translation: “it will start growing”

Quote: send out branches like a plant
Note: The tree sending out branches represents branches growing on the tree. Alternate translation: “branches will start growing on it like a plant”

Quote: then where is he?
Note: Job uses this question to emphasize that when a person dies, he is not present. Alternate translation: “no one knows where he is.” or “he is gone.”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob begins to use word pictures to describe how it is that “man dies; he becomes weak” (verse 10).

Quote: As water disappears from a lake … dries up
Note: Water that has dried up from a lake or a river cannot return, and once a person dies or grows old, he cannot become young again.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob finishes comparing growing old and dying with water drying up (verse 11).

Quote: so people lie down
Note: Lying down represents dying. Alternate translation: “so people die”

Quote: do not rise again
Note: Rising again represents living again. Alternate translation: “do not live again”

Quote: Oh, that you would hide me
Note: This is an exclamation showing what Job wants very much but does not really expect to happen. Alternate translation: “I wish that you would hide me”

Quote: keep me in private
Note: Alternate translation: “keep me locked up” or “keep me hidden”

Quote: call me to mind
Note: Call someone to mind is an idiom meaning to think about him. Alternate translation: “think about me” or “remember me”

Quote: If a man dies, will he live again?
Note: The implicit answer is “no.” Alternate translation: “If a man dies, he will not live again.”

Quote: If so
Note: What “so” refers to is understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “If he would live again”

Quote: to wait all my weary time there
Note: Alternate translation: “to wait all my time there even though I would be weary”

Quote: until my release should come
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **release**, you can express the same idea with the verb “release.” Alternate translation: “until I should be released” or “until you release me”

Quote: I would answer
Note: Alternate translation: “I would do what you wanted me to do”

Quote: You would have a desire for
Note: The noun “desire” can be expressed with the verbs “desire” or “want.” Alternate translation: “You would desire” or “You would want”

Quote: for the work of your hands
Note: Here God’s hands represent him making things. Job refers to himself as the work of God’s hands. Alternate translation: “for me, whom you have made” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: number and care for
Note: These two verbs together express a single action. Alternate translation: “attentively care for”

Quote: my footsteps
Note: Footsteps represent his life or what he does. Alternate translation: “my life” or “the things I do”

Quote: you would not keep track of my sin
Note: Keeping track of Job’s sin represents thinking about his sin. Alternate translation: “you would not look at my sin” or “you would not think about my sin”

Quote: My transgression would be … you would cover up
Note: These three lines express the same thought and are used together to emphasize his confidence that God would forgive him.

Quote: My transgression would be sealed up in a bag
Note: Sealing transgression in a bag represents hiding it and refusing to think about it. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You would refuse to think about my transgression like someone who hides something in a bag”

Quote: you would cover up my iniquity
Note: Covering up someone’s iniquity so that it cannot be seen represents refusing to think about it. Alternate translation: “you would hide my iniquity” or “you would ignore my iniquity”

Quote: mountains fall and come to nothing
Note: “Come to nothing” here is an idiom meaning be completely destroyed. This phrase expands on the word “fall” and emphasizes complete destruction. Alternate translation: “mountains completely fall apart”

Quote: rocks are moved out of their place
Note: This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “rocks tumble down from their place”

Quote: Like this, you destroy the hope of man
Note: If it is easier in your language, you can put this phrase at the beginning of verse 18 and adjust the text accordingly. Alternate translation: “You destroy the hope of man, just like … dust of the earth”

Quote: you destroy the hope of man
Note: Destroying hope represents causing the things people hope for not to happen. Alternate translation: “You prevent the hope of man from happening”

Quote: the hope of man
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **hopes**, you can express the same idea with the verb “hope.” Alternate translation: “the things that man hopes for”

Quote: You always defeat him
Note: The word “him” refers to any person. Alternate translation: “You always defeat man” or “You always defeat people”

Quote: he passes away
Note: Passing away represents dying. Alternate translation: “he dies”

Quote: you change his face
Note: This could mean: (1) the pain just before dying makes his face contract or (2) when a person dies, God makes the person’s face look different.

Quote: send him away to die
Note: This represents causing him to die.

Quote: if they are brought low
Note: Being brought low represents being shamed. Alternate translation: “if they are disgraced” or “if people shame them”

# Job 15 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of the advice of Job’s friend, Eliphaz. His words in this chapter are much stronger than when he previously spoke.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Eliphaz’s advice
Eliphaz tells Job to curse Yahweh. The advice Eliphaz gives to Job is bad advice. He tries to convince Job that he is sinning and has been punished by Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Eliphaz uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Job that he is wrong. These questions help to build Eliphaz’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Eliphaz the Temanite
Note: This is the name of a man. People from Teman are known as Temanites. See how you translated this in [Job 2:11](../02/11.md).

Quote: Should a wise man answer with useless knowledge and fill himself with the east wind?
Note: Eliphaz uses this rhetorical question to rebuke Job. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “A wise man should not answer with useless knowledge nor fill himself with the east wind.”

Quote: fill himself with the east wind
Note: The wind represents emptiness. This phrase speaks of a person speaking empty and meaningless words as if that person were full of the wind. Alternate translation: “fill himself with empty words” or “only have meaningless words”

Quote: the east wind
Note: Alternate translation: “hot air” or “the desert wind”

Quote: Should he reason with unprofitable talk or with speeches with which he can do no good?
Note: Eliphaz uses this rhetorical question to rebuke Job. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “He should not reason with unprofitable talk nor with speeches with which he can do no good.” or “He should not argue using unprofitable talk or make speeches that accomplish nothing good.”

Quote: you diminish respect for God
Note: This could mean: (1) “because of what you say and do, other people no longer respect God” or (2) “you are no longer respecting God.”

Quote: diminish
Note: make smaller

Quote: you obstruct devotion to him
Note: This could mean: (1) “you make it difficult for others to devote themselves to God” or (2) “you are no longer devoting yourself to God.”

Quote: obstruct
Note: block someone’s path

Quote: devotion to
Note: Alternate translation: “meditation on” or “concern for”

Quote: your iniquity teaches your mouth
Note: This describes “iniquity” as if it were a teacher and Job’s mouth is described as if it is learning. This means that his speech is greatly influenced by his iniquity. Alternate translation: “your iniquity is like a teacher and your mouth is like its student” or “it is because of your sin that you speak the way you do” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: your mouth
Note: This speaks of Job, but refers to his “mouth” to place emphasis on what he says. Alternate translation: “you to speak” or “you to say what you say”

Quote: to have the tongue of a crafty man
Note: This refers to the way a crafty man speaks as his “tongue.” Alternate translation: “to speak in the way of a crafty man”

Quote: crafty man
Note: man who harms others by lying to them

Quote: Your own mouth condemns you, not mine
Note: This refers to Job and Eliphaz by their “mouths” to place emphasis on what they say. Alternate translation: “You are condemned by what you say, not by what I say” or “You condemn yourself by what you say, it is not I who condemns you”

Quote: your own lips testify
Note: This speaks of Job, but refers to his “lips” to place emphasis on what he says. Alternate translation: “your own words” or “you testify”
# General Information:\n\nEach verse is a parallelism that contains two rhetorical questions. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Are you the first man that was born?
Note: The implicit answer here is “no.” This rhetorical question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: “You are not the first man that was born.”

Quote: Were you brought into existence before the hills?
Note: The implicit answer here is “no.” This rhetorical question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: “You were not brought into existence before the hills.” or “God did not bring you into existence before he brought the hills into existence.”

Quote: Were you brought
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Did God bring you”

Quote: Have you heard the secret knowledge of God?
Note: The implicit answer here is “no.” This rhetorical question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have not heard the secret knowledge of God.”

Quote: Do you limit wisdom to yourself?
Note: This rhetorical question emphasizes that he cannot limit wisdom to himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You cannot limit wisdom to yourself.” or “You are not the only wise person.”

Quote: What do you know that we do not know?
Note: The implicit answer here is “nothing.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is nothing that you know that we do not know.” or “Everything you know, we also know.”

Quote: What do you understand that is not also in us?
Note: This speaks of the men having understanding as if it were something “inside” them. Alternate translation: “Everything you understand, we also understand.” or “We understand everything that you understand.”

Quote: With us are both the gray-headed and the very aged men
Note: Eliphaz speaks of him and the other men having learned wisdom from older men and wisdom that had been passed down from men of previous generations as if these older men were physically present with them. Alternate translation: “We acquired wisdom from old gray-haired people, from people who were born before your father was”

Quote: Are the consolations of God … gentle toward you?
Note: This rhetorical question is an accusation, with the implicit answer to the question being “yes.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You must think that the consolations of God are too small for you, the words that are gentle toward you”

Quote: consolations
Note: Alternate translation: “comforts” or “sympathies”

Quote: Why does your heart carry you away?
Note: Here the “heart” represents a person’s emotions. Alternate translation: “Why do your emotions take you away?” or “Why do you allow your emotions to guide your decisions?” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Why do your eyes flash
Note: This probably refers to Job appearing angry, specifically the appearance of his eyes. Alternate translation: “Why do your eyes look angry” or “Why are you angry”

Quote: turn your spirit
Note: Here the “spirit” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “turn yourself”

Quote: bring out such words from your mouth
Note: This describes him speaking. Alternate translation: “so you say harsh things against him”

Quote: What is man … What is he who is born
Note: These two questions are basically the same and are used together to emphasize that a man cannot be perfect.

Quote: What is man that he should be clean?
Note: This rhetorical question is asked to emphasize that a man cannot be completely “clean.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “A man, he cannot be completely clean.”

Quote: clean
Note: A person who God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if the person were physically clean.

Quote: What is he who is born of a woman that he should be righteous?
Note: This rhetorical question is asked to emphasize that a man cannot be completely “righteous.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “A man who is born from a woman cannot be completely righteous.”

Quote: See
Note: This word is used here to draw Job’s attention to what is said next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: his holy ones
Note: Alternate translation: “his angels”

Quote: clean
Note: Something that God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if it were physically clean.

Quote: in his sight
Note: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “in his judgment”

Quote: abominable and corrupt
Note: These two words basically mean the same thing and emphasize how wicked humans are.

Quote: who drinks iniquity like water
Note: This describes iniquity as if it were water you can drink. It compares how the evil man desires to commit sin to how readily he desires to drink cool water. Alternate translation: “who love iniquity as much as they love a cup of fresh water” or “who commit evil deeds as often as they drink water”

Quote: I will show you
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I will explain to you” or “I will make it clear to you”

Quote: I will announce
Note: Alternate translation: “I will declare”

Quote: their ancestors did not hide
Note: Eliphaz emphasizes that their ancestors purposefully taught them these things. Alternate translation: “their ancestors taught openly”

Quote: to whom alone the land was given
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “to whom alone God gave the land”

Quote: among whom no stranger ever passed
Note: This means that no foreigner lived among them, specifically so that they would not be influenced by pagan religions. Alternate translation: “no one from another country came and caused them to think wrongly about God”

Quote: twists in pain
Note: “suffers a lot of pain.” This is either physical or emotional pain.

Quote: the number of years that are laid up
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “all the years that God has laid up”

Quote: that are laid up
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “that are prepared” or “that are set aside”

Quote: A sound of terrors is in his ears
Note: Alternate translation: “He constantly hears sounds that terrify him”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues describing the wicked man he began to describe in [Job 15:20](../15/20.md).

Quote: return out of darkness
Note: Here “darkness” is a metaphor for trouble or misfortune. Alternate translation: “escape misfortune”

Quote: the sword waits for him
Note: Here “the sword” is a metonym that represents an enemy who is waiting to kill the evil man. This could mean: (1) he is worried that someone will murder him. Alternate translation: “he worries that someone is about to murder him” or (2) it is certain that he is going to be murdered. Alternate translation: “someone is waiting to murder him” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: for bread
Note: Here “bread” refers to food in general. Alternate translation: “for food”

Quote: the day of darkness
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “the day of disaster” or “the moment of his death”

Quote: is at hand
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “is coming soon”

Quote: Distress and anguish make him afraid; they prevail against him
Note: The words “distress” and “anguish” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of the emotion. Here these feelings are spoken of as if they were an enemy who is attacking the wicked man. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: prevail against
Note: Alternate translation: “overpower” or “defeat”

Quote: as a king ready for battle
Note: This compares how his distress and anguish overpower him to how a king, who is ready for battle, would prevail against him. Alternate translation: “just like a king, who is ready for a battle, would prevail against him”

Quote: he has reached out with his hand against God
Note: “he has shook his fist against God.” This is a sign of aggression.

Quote: runs at God
Note: This speaks of the wicked man acting aggressively against God as if he were running towards him to attack him. Alternate translation: “attacks God” or “acts violently against God”

Quote: with a thick shield
Note: Alternate translation: “with his strong shield”

Quote: This is true
Note: “This” refers to the wicked man running at God from the previous verse.

Quote: he has covered his face with his fat and gathered fat on his loins
Note: This wicked man is described as fat and weak, while believing himself to be strong enough to defeat God. Alternate translation: “he is weak with a fat face and fat loins”

Quote: which no man inhabits
Note: Alternate translation: “which are abandoned”

Quote: heaps
Note: piles of useless things

Quote: He will not be rich; his wealth will not last
Note: These two litotes express that he will be the opposite of rich, that he will be poor. Alternate translation: “he will be poor; all his money will disappear”

Quote: out of darkness
Note: Darkness here represents death. Alternate translation: “out of the darkness of death”

Quote: a flame will dry up his stalks
Note: Here the flame represents God’s judgment and the drying up of his stalks represents either the fact that his possessions disappear, or that he will die. Alternate translation: “God will take everything he owns away, like a fire dries out the moist branches of a tree”

Quote: the breath of God’s mouth
Note: Here God’s “breath” represents his judgement. Alternate translation: “God’s breath” or “God’s judgment”

Quote: he will go away
Note: This refers to him dying. Alternate translation: “he will die”

Quote: for uselessness will be his reward
Note: This is implied that this is what will happen if he trusts in useless things. Alternate translation: “for if he trusts in them, uselessness will be his reward”

Quote: his branch will not be green
Note: This speaks of the man looking pale and dead as if he were a dried out stalk or tree branch. Alternate translation: “he will look dead, just like the branch of a dead tree does not look green”

Quote: He will drop his … he will cast off his
Note: These two lines give a similar image, which is repeated to emphasize that this will surely happen.

Quote: He will drop his unripe grapes like a grapevine
Note: This speaks of the wicked man growing weak and dying as if he were a grapevine dropping unripe grapes. Alternate translation: “Just like a grapevine drops its unripe grapes, so the wicked man will drop his strength”

Quote: he will cast off his flowers like the olive tree
Note: This speaks of the wicked man growing weak and dying as if he were an olive tree dropping its flowers. Alternate translation: “just like an olive tree loses its flowers, so the wicked man will lose his strength”

Quote: the company of godless people
Note: Alternate translation: “the group of godless people”

Quote: fire will consume their tents of bribery
Note: The phrase “tents of bribery” means that the wicked people bought these tents with the money they made by bribery. Alternate translation: “the tents they bought with their bribes will be burned by fire”

Quote: They conceive mischief and give birth to iniquity; their womb conceives deceit
Note: The same thought is repeated three times to emphasize how much evil these people produce. This speaks of a person planning to do evil things and doing them as if the person were conceiving and giving birth to these things as a woman conceives and gives birth to a child. Alternate translation: “They plan to cause mischief and do evil things; they are always planning to deceive others” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: their womb conceives
Note: Here the “womb” is used to refer to the person to emphasize conception, as it is in the womb that conception takes place. Alternate translation: “they conceive”

# Job 16 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Eliphaz.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s response
Job expresses shock and disgust at the advice Eliphaz gives to him. He even mocks Eliphaz. He describes the difficulties of his circumstances but never curses Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]])

### Advocate

Job describes the need for someone to intercede for him in heaven. This person would be his advocate and provide a witness for him. Although this is probably not intended as a prophecy, it closely parallels the way Jesus intercedes for people in heaven. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/intercede]], [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/heaven]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/testimony]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

Quote: you are all miserable comforters
Note: Alternate translation: “instead of comforting me, you all make me more miserable”

Quote: Will useless words ever have an end?
Note: Job uses this rhetorical question to express that he wishes that they would stop speaking useless words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “How I wish your useless words would end!”

Quote: What is wrong with you that you answer like this?
Note: Job uses this rhetorical question to rebuke Eliphaz. Here the word “you” is singular and refers to Eliphaz, who just finished speaking to Job. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Eliphaz, you should stop answering me like this!”

Quote: I could collect and join words together
Note: Job speaks of thinking of useless things to say as if his words were random items that he collected and joined together. Alternate translation: “I could think of things to say”

Quote: shake my head
Note: This is an action that shows disapproval.

Quote: in mockery
Note: The word “mockery” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “to mock you”

Quote: I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the quivering of my lips will bring you relief!
Note: The words “mouth” and “lips” are metonyms for the words or messages that a person speaks using his mouth and lips. Here Job is speaking sarcastically and means the opposite of what he says. Alternate translation: “My words would surely not be encouraging to you! They would surely not lighten your grief” or “By speaking to you as you spoke to me earlier, I would not encourage you or lighten your grief!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: with my mouth
Note: Here Job’s “mouth” represents what he says. Alternate translation: “with what I say”

Quote: the quivering of my lips
Note: This is a metonym for the words or message that he speaks. Alternate translation: “my comforting words”

Quote: will bring you relief
Note: This speaks of grief as if it were a heavy physical burden. Alternate translation: “will lessen your grief” or “will help you feel less grief”

Quote: grief
Note: Job has experienced great loss of family and health that is unexplained and therefore causes him “great sorrow and emotional pain.”

Quote: how am I helped?
Note: Job uses this rhetorical question to express that keeping quiet does not lessen his grief. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “it does not help me at all.”

Quote: But now, God, you
Note: Job now turns his complaining to God.

Quote: made all my family desolate
Note: Alternate translation: “destroyed all my family”

Quote: You have made me dry up
Note: This means that Job’s body has shriveled and become wrinkled. Alternate translation: “You have made my body shrivel up”

Quote: which itself is a witness against me
Note: Job describes the shriveling of his body as if it were an accuser against him. Alternate translation: “and people think that shows me to be a sinner”

Quote: the leanness of my body rises up against me, and it testifies against
Note: Job describes the thinness of his body as if it were accuser against him. Alternate translation: “They see how thin my body is, and they think that proves that I am guilty”

Quote: against my face
Note: Here Job is referred to by his “face.” Alternate translation: “against me”

Quote: God has torn me in his wrath and persecuted me … as he tears me apart
Note: This speaks of God causing Job pain as if God were a wild animal and Job were his prey that he was killing. Alternate translation: “Because God is very angry with me, it is as though he were a wild animal that tore my body apart with his teeth because he was my enemy”

Quote: my enemy
Note: Job refers to God as his “enemy” as he describes how he has caused him great pain.

Quote: fastens his eyes on me
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “glares at me”

Quote: People have gaped with open mouth
Note: To “gape” means to stare in amazement with open mouth.

Quote: hands me over to ungodly people, and throws me into the hands of wicked people
Note: These two lines mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize Job’s feeling of having been betrayed by God.

Quote: hands me over to
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “puts me under the control of”

Quote: throws me into the hands
Note: Here a person’s “hands” refer to his “control.” Alternate translation: “delivers me to the control”

Quote: and he broke me apart
Note: Job speaks of his pain and despair as if he himself were something that was broken into pieces. Alternate translation: “but then it felt as though he broke me apart”

Quote: dashed me to pieces
Note: Job speaks of God causing him pain and despair as if he were something that God had taken and smashed into pieces. Alternate translation: “it is as though he has taken me by the neck and smashed me to pieces”

Quote: he has also set me up as his target
Note: Job speaks of himself being the focus of God’s attacks as if God has set him up as a target to shoot arrows at. Alternate translation: “it is as though he set me up like a target”

Quote: His archers surround me all around
Note: Job speaks of himself being the focus of God’s attacks as if God has set him up as a target and God had archers surrounding him to attack him. Alternate translation: “It is as though his archers have me surrounded”

Quote: God pierces my kidneys and does not spare me; he pours out my bile on the ground
Note: Job speaks of the pain he is feeling by comparing it to God piercing his body with arrows. Here “God” represents the arrows that he shoots. Alternate translation: “It feels like God’s arrows have pierced my kidneys and my liver, spilling my bile on the ground. He does not spare me”

Quote: He smashes through my wall
Note: Job speaks of the pain that he feels by comparing himself to a wall that God smashes through. Alternate translation: “I feel like a wall that God smashes through” or “I feel like a wall that God breaks through”

Quote: he runs upon me like a warrior
Note: Job describes God as a soldier that attacks him. Alternate translation: “it is like he is a warrior who runs at me to attack me”

Quote: I have sewn sackcloth on my skin
Note: Job speaks of wearing clothing made of sackcloth as if the cloth were attached to his body. People often wore sackcloth to express mourning or great grief. Alternate translation: “Because I am mourning, I have sewn together sackcloth to wear as my clothing” or “I wear clothing that I made from sackcloth, because I am mourning”

Quote: I have thrust my horn into the ground
Note: Job’s “horn” represents the power and authority he had before but now is no more. Alternate translation: “I sit here in the dirt, very depressed”

Quote: on my eyelids is the shadow of death
Note: Here Job’s eyes are represented by his “eyelids.” Job speaks of his eyes’ dark appearance as if his eyes looked like the eyes of a dead person. Alternate translation: “there are dark circles around my eyes” or “my eyes are dark, like the eyes of a dead person” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: there is no violence in my hands
Note: “Hands” refers to a person’s ability and activity. Alternate translation: “I have not acted violently”

Quote: Earth, do not cover up my blood
Note: Jobs speaks to the “earth” directly even though it cannot hear him, to add strength to his statement. The earth is personified as purposefully covering up his blood after he dies. Alternate translation: “I wish my blood would not soak into the ground but that it would remain on top of the ground as proof of how I died” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Earth, do not cover up my blood
Note: Job speaks of himself dying as if he would be murdered. Here his “blood” is a metonym referring to his death. Alternate translation: “Earth, when I die, do not hide how I died unfairly” or “Let it not be hidden how I died unfairly”

Quote: let my cry have no resting place
Note: Job speaks of wanting everyone to know what happened to him as if his “cry” were a person that never stopped testifying to what happened to him and never rested. Alternate translation: “let everyone hear about what has happened to me”

Quote: see
Note: Job uses this word to draw attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “listen”

Quote: vouches for me
Note: Alternate translation: “testifies that I am righteous”

Quote: on high
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “in heaven” or “in heaven on high”

Quote: scoff at
Note: Alternate translation: “scorn” or “ridicule”

Quote: my eye pours out tears
Note: Job describes how strongly he feels his sorrow. Here he exaggerates how he often cries by saying that tears pour from his eyes. Alternate translation: “my eyes are full of tears while I cry out”

Quote: for this man
Note: “for me.” Here Job refers to himself in the third person.

Quote: as a man does with his neighbor!
Note: “as a man does for his neighbor.” Job describes how he wants that one in heaven to plead for him.

Quote: I will go to a place
Note: Here Job is referring to himself dying. Alternate translation: “I will die and go to a place”

# Job 17 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s response to Eliphaz, but it is more directly addressed to Yahweh.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s grief
