Job expresses grief or great sadness in this chapter. He awaits the justice and intercession of Yahweh as he awaits his own death. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/intercede]])

### Advocate

Job describes the need for someone to intercede for him in heaven. This person would be his advocate and provide a witness for him. Although this is probably not intended as a prophecy, it closely parallels the way Jesus intercedes for people in heaven. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/heaven]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/testimony]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

Quote: My spirit is consumed
Note: Job refers to himself by his “spirit” to emphasize his inner emotions. He speaks of not having any strength left as if he were something that has been used up. Alternate translation: “I am consumed” or “I have lost all of my strength” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: my days are over
Note: Alternate translation: “my time is over” or “I am going to die soon”

Quote: the grave is ready for me
Note: This phrase describes “the grave” as if it is a person who will receive Job as a guest. Alternate translation: “soon I will be dead and buried”

Quote: Surely there are mockers with me
Note: Alternate translation: “Those who are around me are mocking me”

Quote: Surely
Note: Alternate translation: “Certainly” or “There is no doubt that”

Quote: my eye must always see
Note: Job refers to himself by his “eyes” to emphasize what he sees. Alternate translation: “I must always see” or “I must always hear”

Quote: their provocation
Note: “their insults.” The word “provocation” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “them provoking me” or “them, trying to make me angry”

Quote: Give now a pledge, be a guarantee for me with yourself
Note: Job begins to speak to God. Here he speaks of his situation as if he were in prison. He is asking God to provide a pledge so that he may be released. Alternate translation: “God, give now a pledge so that I may be released from this prison” or “pay for my release from prison”

Quote: who else is there who will help me?
Note: Job uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is no one else to help him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “there is no one else who will help me.”

Quote: have kept their hearts
Note: The word “their” refers to his friends. They are referred to by their “hearts” to emphasize their emotions. Alternate translation: “have kept them” or “have kept my friends”

Quote: you will not exalt them over me
Note: Alternate translation: “you will not allow them to triumph over me”

Quote: He who
Note: Alternate translation: “Anyone who”

Quote: denounces his friends for a reward
Note: Alternate translation: “falsely accuses his friends in order to get a profit” or “betrays his friends to receive a reward”

Quote: the eyes of his children will fail
Note: The person’s children are referred to here by their “eyes.” This phrase describes the children suffering because of what their father or mother did. Alternate translation: “his children will suffer for it” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: he has made me a byword of the people
Note: This means that people speak of him in a mocking way and use his name as an insult. Alternate translation: “because of him, people use my name as an insult” or “because of them, people use my name as a byword”

Quote: they spit in my face
Note: “people spit in my face.” In this culture spitting on someone was a great insult. If spitting has a different meaning in your culture you can write this differently. Alternate translation: “people insult me greatly, by spitting in my face”

Quote: My eye is also dim because of sorrow
Note: Job speaks of his vision as his “eyes.” Alternate translation: “My vision has become weak because I am so sad” or “I am almost blind because of my sorrow”

Quote: all my body parts are as thin as shadows
Note: Shadows have no thickness and are infinitely thin. That is an exaggeration of how thin Job’s body parts are. Alternate translation: “all my body parts are very thin” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: all my body parts
Note: This is a generalization used to emphasize that his whole body is thin, but refers specifically to his arms and legs. Alternate translation: “my arms and legs”

Quote: will be stunned
Note: Alternate translation: “will be shocked” or “will be horrified”

Quote: by this
Note: Alternate translation: “by what has happened to me”

Quote: will stir himself up against
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “will be distressed because of” or “will be very angry with”

Quote: will keep to his way
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “will continue to live in a righteous way”

Quote: he who has clean hands
Note: This speaks of a person being innocent as having clean hands. Alternate translation: “he who does what is right” or “he who is innocent”

Quote: will grow stronger and stronger
Note: This does not refer only to physical strength but also to the strength of a person’s will and emotions.

Quote: you all
Note: Job is speaking to Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar.

Quote: come on now
Note: Job invites his friends to debate what he has said. Alternate translation: “come on now, argue with me again”

Quote: My days are past
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “My time is past” or “My life is over”

Quote: my plans are shattered, and so are the desires of my heart
Note: Here Job’s “heart” represents his inner being. Alternate translation: “my plans will never happen, nor will the things that I have desired most”

Quote: These people, these mockers
Note: These two phrases refer to the same people, namely Job’s friends, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. The second phrase emphasizes their unfriendly attitude.

Quote: change the night into day
Note: This speaks of the people claiming that night is day as if they actually changed night into day. Alternate translation: “claim it is daytime when it is night” or “say the opposite of what is true, just as night is the opposite of day”

Quote: light is near to darkness
Note: It is implied that the mockers claim that it is light when it is close to dark. Alternate translation: “they claim that light is near to darkness” or “they claim that when it is becoming dark, that it is getting light”

Quote: If the only home … and if I have spread
Note: The instances of “if” here have the meaning of “since”; Job is speaking as if all these things were true. “Since the only home … and since I have spread”

Quote: have spread my couch in the darkness
Note: Here Job speaks of being prepared to die as having laid his bed in the darkness. Alternate translation: “have prepared myself to go and sleep among the dead”

Quote: have spread my couch
Note: Alternate translation: “have made my bed”

Quote: if I have said
Note: The word “if” here has the meaning of “since”; Job is speaking as if this were true. “since I have said”

Quote: I have said to the pit … and to the worm
Note: These two lines are a variation to each other and are used together to emphasize how desperate Job is.

Quote: the pit
Note: Alternate translation: “the grave”

Quote: You are my father
Note: Job speaks of the closeness he will soon have with his grave by comparing it to the closeness a man has with his father. Alternate translation: “You are as close to me as my father” or “When I am buried, you will be as close to me as a father”

Quote: the worm
Note: “the maggot.” Worms are the small creatures that eat dead bodies.

Quote: You are my mother or my sister
Note: Job speaks of the closeness he will soon have with the worms in his grave by comparing it to the closeness a man has with his mother and sisters. Alternate translation: “You are as close to me as my mother or my sister” or “You will be as close to me as a mother or sister”

Quote: where then is my hope?
Note: The implicit answer is “nowhere,” because he has no hope. This rhetorical question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: “I have no hope.”

Quote: As for my hope, who can see any?
Note: This rhetorical question is used to emphasize that no one expects him to have any hope. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can see any hope for me.” or “No one expects me to have any more hope.”

Quote: Will hope go down with me … dust?
Note: The implicit answer is “no.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Hope will not go down with me … dust.” or “I will no longer hope when I go down … dust.”

Quote: gates of Sheol
Note: Sheol does not really have gates, but it is a metaphor for Job entering Sheol. Alternate translation: “when I go into Sheol”

Quote: when we
Note: “when I and the things that I hope for” or “when I and my hopes.” The word “we” refers to Job and his hope.

Quote: descend to the dust
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “die and are buried” or “go to the grave”

# Job 18 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is the advice of Job’s friend, Bildad. His words in this chapter are much stronger than when he previously spoke, and he is even angry at Job.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Bildad’s advice
Bildad tells Job to curse Yahweh. The advice Bildad gives to Job is bad advice. He tries to convince Job that he is sinning and has been punished by Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])
# General Information:\n\nBildad the Shuhite is speaking to Job. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said
Note: “Bildad” is the name of a man who is a member of the tribe of Shuah. See how you translated this in [Job 8:1](../08/01.md).

Quote: When will you stop your talk?
Note: This rhetorical question means that Job has been talking for too long. Alternate translation: “Stop talking!”

Quote: Consider, and
Note: Alternate translation: “Be reasonable, and” or “Think about these things, and”

Quote: Why are we regarded as beasts, stupid in your sight?
Note: Bildad uses this rhetorical questions to emphasize to Job that he should not consider his friends as animals who cannot think or speak. It can be written as a statement in active form. Alternate translation: “We should not be regarded as beasts, as stupid in your sight.” or “You should not regard us as beasts or think of us as stupid.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Why are we
Note: The word “we” probably refers to Bildad and Job’s other friends and so is exclusive.

Quote: regarded
Note: Regarding, looking, is a metonym here for thinking well or badly of someone.

Quote: in your sight
Note: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “in your judgment” or “in your thinking”

Quote: your sight
Note: The word “your” here is plural. Bildad is using sarcasm to tell Job that Job should not think of himself as a great man. Alternate translation: “your sight, you who wrongly think you are great” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: You who tear at yourself in your anger
Note: Here Bildad is stating that it is because of Job’s anger and disobedience that he has been injured, not because of God’s anger as Job has previously claimed. The word “tear” here means to “injure.” Alternate translation: “You who have caused your own injuries because of your anger”

Quote: should the earth be forsaken for you or should the rocks be removed out of their places?
Note: This rhetorical question suggests that letting Job, whom they consider a guilty man, go free would be like changing the whole world. Bildad uses these huge exaggerations here to emphasize how outrageous he thinks this is. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “asking God to let you, a guilty man, go free is as silly as asking for God to forsake the earth for your sake or for God to move the rocks out of their places to please you!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: should the earth be forsaken
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “should everyone leave the earth”

Quote: should the rocks be removed out of their places
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. The word “rocks” here refers to large rocks, such as those in the mountains. Alternate translation: “should God remove the rocks from their places” or “should God move mountains around”

Quote: Indeed, the light of the wicked person will be put out; the spark of his fire will not shine
Note: Bildad speaks of a wicked person dying as if his lamp were being blown out. Alternate translation: “What will happen is that the lives of wicked people like you end as quickly as we can put out a light or extinguish the flame of a fire”

Quote: will be put out
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “will go out”

Quote: The light will be dark in his tent; his lamp above him will be put out
Note: Bildad continues to speak of the wicked person dying. He speaks of the wicked man’s life as if it were the light in his tent. Alternate translation: It will be like the light in his tent has turned to darkness, like the lamp above him has gone out”

Quote: The steps of his strength will be made short
Note: This speaks of the wicked person suddenly experiencing disaster as if he no longer had strength to walk. Alternate translation: “It will be like he no longer has the strength to walk”

Quote: his own plans will cast him down
Note: “his own advice makes him fall down.” This speaks of the wicked person undergoing disaster as if he fell down. Alternate translation: “his own plans will lead him into disaster”

Quote: For he will be thrown into a net by his own feet; he will walk into a pitfall
Note: “His own feet will lead him into a net.” Bildad uses this image to say that the way that a wicked person lives his life leads him to sudden disaster. Alternate translation: “It will be as though he led himself into a net, as if he walked right into a pitfall”

Quote: a net
Note: cords or ropes that people weave together to create a mesh. People used nets to catch animals.

Quote: a pitfall
Note: a pit that has branches and leaves over it so that an animal will walk onto the branches and leaves and fall into the pit

Quote: A trap will take him … a snare will
Note: These four phrases speak of the wicked man experiencing disaster as if he were caught in a trap. Alternate translation: “It will be as though a trap will take him … a snare will”

Quote: A trap
Note: People used this kind of trap to catch birds. The trap snapped shut and held on to the foot of the bird.

Quote: will take him by the heel
Note: Here the “heel” refers to the whole foot. Alternate translation: “will take hold of his foot”

Quote: A noose is … and a trap for him in the way
Note: These four phrases speak of the wicked man experiencing disaster as if he were caught in a trap. Alternate translation: “It will be as though a noose is … and a trap for him in the way”

Quote: A noose is hidden for him on the ground
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Someone has hidden a noose on the ground in order to catch him”

Quote: A noose
Note: a rope with a loop that grabs hold of an animal’s leg when the animal steps in the middle of the loop

Quote: a trap for him
Note: The understood verbal phrase “is hidden” may be supplied. Alternate translation: “a trap is hidden on the path to catch him” or “someone will hide a trap to catch him in the way”

Quote: Terrors will make him afraid on every side
Note: Alternate translation: “Terrors all around will make him afraid”

Quote: they will chase him at his heels
Note: This speaks of the things that terrify the wicked person as if they were enemies who chased him. Alternate translation: “it will be as if the terrors will chase him all around”

Quote: His wealth will turn into hunger
Note: This speaks of the wicked man becoming poor and hungry as if his wealth were something that turned into something else. Alternate translation: “Instead of being wealthy, he will become poor and hungry”

Quote: calamity will be ready at his side
Note: The phrase “ready at his side” is an idiom that means that something is continually present. Alternate translation: “he will continually experience disaster” or “he will not be able to avoid calamity”

Quote: The parts of his body will be devoured
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Also, this speaks of a disease destroying his body as if it were an animal that had attacked him and was eating him. Alternate translation: “Disease will eat away at his skin” or “Disease will destroy his skin” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the firstborn of death will devour his parts
Note: Here a disease that kills many people is referred to as “the firstborn of death.” This speaks of that disease destroying his body as if it were an animal that had attacked him and was eating him. Alternate translation: “a deadly disease will destroy the different parts of his body”

Quote: He is torn from the safety of his tent
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Disaster rips him out of his tent, where he is safe”

Quote: marched off
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “it marches him off” or “it forces him to go”

Quote: the king of terrors
Note: This is a reference to “King Death,” a pagan god who was believed to rule over death. Alternate translation: “the one who rules over the dead” or “the king of death”

Quote: People not his own
Note: Alternate translation: “People who are not his family”

Quote: after they see that sulfur is scattered within his home
Note: People used sulfur to get rid of any diseases from a dying person. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “after they spread sulfur all over his home”

Quote: His roots will be dried up … branch be cut off
Note: This speaks of the wicked man dying and having no descendants as if he were a tree whose roots dried up and branches withered, producing no fruit. Alternate translation: “He will die and leave no descendants, he will be like a tree whose roots have dried up and whose branches have all withered”

Quote: will his branch be cut off
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “his branches will wither”

Quote: His memory will perish from the earth; he will have no name in the street
Note: These phrases have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize the fact that nobody will remember him after he dies.

Quote: His memory will perish from the earth
Note: This speaks of the “memory” of the wicked man as if it were a person who died. Alternate translation: “No one on the earth will remember him”

Quote: he will have no name in the street
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “no one walking along the street will even remember his name”

Quote: He will be driven from light into darkness … and be chased out of this world
Note: These phrases together emphasize the fact that the wicked person will be sent to Sheol, the place of the dead.

Quote: He will be driven from light into darkness
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will drive the wicked person from light into darkness”

Quote: from light into darkness
Note: The word “light” refers to life, and the word “darkness” refers to death. Alternate translation: “from the light of life to the darkness of death”

Quote: be chased out of this world
Note: This speaks of God making him leave earth and go where dead people go as if he were chasing him. Alternate translation: “God will make him leave this world” or “God will send him to the place where dead people go”

Quote: be chased out
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will chase him”

Quote: He will have no son … nor any remaining kinfolk where he had stayed
Note: Together these two phrases emphasize that he will have no family or descendants left.

Quote: son’s son
Note: Alternate translation: “grandson” or “grandchild”

Quote: kinfolk
Note: Alternate translation: “relatives”

Quote: Those who live in the west … those who live in the east will be frightened by it
Note: The phrases “in the west” and “in the east” are together a merism that refers to all people living everywhere. This is an exaggeration as not everyone on the earth will hear about what happened to a specific wicked person. Alternate translation: “Everyone in the whole world will be horrified and frightened when they see what happens to the wicked person” or “Many people who live in the east and in the west will be horrified and frightened when they see what happens to the wicked person” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: one day
Note: Alternate translation: “someday”

Quote: the homes of unrighteous people, the places of those who do not know God
Note: These two phrases have the same meaning and refer to the same people. Here these people are referred to by the places where they live. Alternate translation: “unrighteous people, those who do not know God” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Job 19 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Bildad.

Verses 25–27 are very important to this book. They show the great depth of Job’s faith in Yahweh after his most difficult time. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])
# General Information:\n\n(See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob speaks to his three friends.

Quote: How long will you make me suffer and break me into pieces with words?
Note: Job uses this question to complain about how his friends are treating him. Alternate translation: “Stop making me suffer and breaking me into pieces with words.”

Quote: break me into pieces with words
Note: Job uses this image to say that their words make him feel very sad and hopeless. Alternate translation: “torment me with your words”

Quote: These ten times you have reproached me
Note: The phrase “These ten times” refers to the way that the friends have completely rebuked Job. Alternate translation: “You have completely reproached me” or “You have reproached me many times”

Quote: you are not ashamed that you have treated me harshly
Note: Job is rebuking them for this. This can be written in positive form. Alternate translation: “You should be ashamed that you have treated me so harshly”

Quote: have treated me harshly
Note: Alternate translation: “have despised me” or “have publicly ridiculed me”

Quote: have erred
Note: Alternate translation: “have sinned by accident” or “mistakenly sinned”

Quote: my error remains my own concern
Note: Job implies that his friends are not responsible for continuing to rebuke him since he is the one who made the error. Alternate translation: “my error is my own responsibility, so you should not continue to rebuke me” or “my error did not hurt you, so you should not continue to rebuke me”

Quote: my error
Note: Alternate translation: “my sin” or “my mistake”

Quote: If indeed you will exalt yourselves above me
Note: Alternate translation: “If you think you are better than I am” or “Since you act as though you are better than I am”

Quote: use my humiliation against me
Note: How his friends would do this can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “claim that my humiliation is proof against me” or “use my humiliation as evidence that I am guilty”

Quote: use my humiliation against me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **humiliation**, you can express the same idea with the verb “humiliate.” Alternate translation: “claim that what has happened to humiliate me proves that I am guilty”

Quote: has caught me in his net
Note: Job speaks as if God were a hunter that has trapped Job in his net. This metaphor represents God taking control of Job and Job’s feeling of helplessness. Alternate translation: “has trapped me” or “has taken control of me” or “has control of what happens to me, so that I am helpless”

Quote: See, I cry out
Note: Alternate translation: “Pay attention, because what I am about to say is both true and important: I cry out”

Quote: Violence!
Note: This is a cry for help. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Violence! Help!” or “Help! I am being attacked!”

Quote: I call out for help
Note: Alternate translation: “I shout for help” or “I cry for help”

Quote: but there is no justice
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **justice**, you can express the same idea with a phrase that makes the meaning clear. Alternate translation: “but no one protects me from those who do me wrong” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: He has walled up … darkness in my path
Note: Job uses these images to describe how God has made him feel helpless and hopeless.

Quote: He has walled up my way so that I cannot pass
Note: Alternate translation: “God has put a wall on the road that I am walking on” or “He has blocked the way so I cannot keep going”

Quote: He has stripped … the crown from my head
Note: Job uses these images to say that God has taken his good reputation, wealth, and dignity away from him.

Quote: He has stripped me of my glory
Note: Job speaks of his glory as if it were a robe that God has taken away. Alternate translation: “He has taken away my glory”

Quote: he has taken the crown from my head
Note: The crown refers to Job’s dignity or honor. Alternate translation: “he has taken away my dignity and honor” or “it is as though he has taken my crown off my head”

Quote: He has broken me down on every side
Note: Job speaks of God ruining him as if Job were building that God is smashing down. Alternate translation: “He has ruined me in every way” or “He has attacked me in every way”

Quote: I am gone
Note: The metaphor “being gone” represents being completely destroyed. Alternate translation: “I am completely destroyed”

Quote: he has pulled up my hope like a tree
Note: Job speaks of God causing Job not to have hope as if Job’s hope were a tree that God has pulled with its roots out of the ground. Alternate translation: “he has completely taken away all my hope” or “because of what he has done, I can no longer hope for anything good”

Quote: like a tree
Note: This simile is also an ellipsis. You may need to supply the omitted words. Alternate translation: “the way a man pulls a tree up by its roots” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: He has also kindled his wrath against me
Note: Job speaks of God’s wrath as if it were a fire. Alternate translation: “God has also lit a fire of anger against me” or “God has also become very angry with me”

Quote: he regards me as one of his adversaries
Note: Alternate translation: “he thinks of me as an enemy”

Quote: His troops come on together
Note: Job speaks of God attacking him as if Job was a city and God was sending an army to attack it. Alternate translation: “God sends his army to attack me”

Quote: they cast up siege mounds against me
Note: Job speaks of God attacking him as if Job was a city and God’s army was piling up dirt against the city wall in order to climb over the wall and attack the city. Alternate translation: “the soldiers pile up dirt in order to climb over my wall”

Quote: encamp around my tent
Note: Job speaks of God attacking him as if Job was in his tent and God’s army was camping around him and preparing to attack him. Alternate translation: “they camp around my tent and prepare to attack me”

Quote: He has put my brothers far from me
Note: Being “far from” someone represents being unwilling to relate to him or help him. Alternate translation: “God has caused my brothers to stay away from me” or “God caused my brothers to refuse to help me”

Quote: my acquaintances are wholly alienated from me
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “my acquaintances have alienated themselves from me” or “my friends treat me like a stranger”

Quote: My kinsfolk have failed me
Note: Alternate translation: “My relatives have left me without help”

Quote: my close friends
Note: Alternate translation: “my intimate friends”

Quote: have forgotten me
Note: “have abandoned me” or “have neglected me.” This means that they refuse to treat him according to how he and they had related to each other in the past. It implies that they abandoned him.

Quote: regard me
Note: Alternate translation: “consider me”

Quote: I am an alien in their sight
Note: Job describes how people now think of him as an outsider. Here sight represents judgement or evaluation. Alternate translation: “they think of me as a foreigner”

Quote: but he gives me no answer
Note: “but he does not respond to me” or “but he does not come to me.” The answer is a response to Job’s call.

Quote: although I entreat him with my mouth
Note: The phrase “my mouth” is a metonym which refers to Job speaking. Alternate translation: “even though I speak to him and plead with him”

Quote: entreat him
Note: Alternate translation: “plead with him”

Quote: My breath is offensive to my wife
Note: Here “breath” represents the smell of his breath. If something is offensive to someone, it means that he hates it. Alternate translation: “My wife hates the smell of my breath”

Quote: those who were born from my mother’s womb
Note: Job refers to his brothers and sisters this way to imply that they are people who should love him. The full meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “my own brothers who should love me” or “my brothers and sisters who should love me”

Quote: despise me
Note: Alternate translation: “hate me” or “detest me”

Quote: they speak against me
Note: Alternate translation: “they ridicule me” or “they make fun of me”

Quote: All my familiar friends
Note: “All my closest friends” or “All of my friends with whom I shared my secrets.” This refers to his closest friends.

Quote: abhor me
Note: Alternate translation: “think I am disgusting”

Quote: have turned against me
Note: Alternate translation: “have betrayed me”

Quote: My bones cling to my skin and to my flesh
Note: “I am just skin and bones” or “My skin sticks to my bones.” Job speaks of his bones, skin, and flesh to describe his appearance. He was extremely thin, and people could easily see the shape of his bones. Some languages have idioms for this.

Quote: I survive only by the skin of my teeth
Note: This idiom means that he is barely surviving, that he almost does not survive. Alternate translation: “I am barely alive” or “I hardly survive”

Quote: Have pity upon me
Note: Alternate translation: “Have compassion on me”

Quote: for the hand of God has touched me
Note: Here “touched me” is a metonym for “hit me.” And, “hand” represents God’s power. Causing Job to suffer is spoken of as if Yahweh were physically hitting him with his hand. Alternate translation: “because God has afflicted me” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Why do you pursue me … God does?
Note: Job uses this question to complain about how his friends are treating him. Alternate translation: “Do not persecute me … God does!”

Quote: Will you ever be satisfied with my flesh?
Note: Job uses this question to complain about how his friends are treating him. Alternate translation: “You have consumed my flesh enough!” or “Stop consuming my flesh!”

Quote: Will you ever be satisfied with my flesh?
Note: Job speaks of his friends speaking so cruelly to him as if they were wild beasts eating up another animal. Alternate translation: “Stop violently slandering me.” or “Stop attacking me with your words.”

Quote: Oh, that my words were now written down
Note: This exclamation tells what Job wishes for. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “I wish that someone would write down my words” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: my words
Note: Alternate translation: “what I am saying”

Quote: Oh, that they were inscribed in a book
Note: This exclamation tells what Job wishes for. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “I wish that someone would write them in a book” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Oh, that with an iron pen and lead they were engraved in the rock forever
Note: This exclamation tells what Job wishes for. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “I wish that someone would use an iron pen and lead to carve them in the rock forever” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: an iron pen
Note: “an iron chisel.” This was a tool used for writing. It was made of iron so that people could carve words in rock.

Quote: lead
Note: Lead is a soft metal. We do not know how people used lead when carving rock. They may have filled the letters of the inscription with lead in order to make the inscription last longer.

Quote: my Redeemer
Note: “My Defender.” Here “Redeemer” refers to a person who will rescue Job by proving Job’s innocence, restoring his honor, and giving him justice.

Quote: at last he will stand on the earth
Note: This refers to standing to speak in court. This could mean: (1) the Redeemer will be the last one to speak in the court. Alternate translation: “he will judge whether or not I am guilty” or (2) the Redeemer will stand in this final court to defend Job. Alternate translation: “at last he will defend me in court”

Quote: after my skin … is destroyed
Note: Possible meanings are that this refers to: (1) his body being destroyed by disease or (2) his body decaying after he has died.

Quote: in my flesh I will see God
Note: His flesh represents his body, and “in my flesh” represents being alive. Alternate translation: “while I live in my body, I will see God”

Quote: my own eyes—I, and not someone else
Note: The synecdoche “my own eyes” represents Job. The phrases “my eyes” and “and not someone else” emphasize that Job himself will actually see God. It is not that someone else will see God and tell Job about him.

Quote: My heart fails within me
Note: People thought of the heart as being where the emotions are. So the heart failing represents him having very many emotions. Alternate translation: “I am very emotional about it” or “My emotions overwhelm me as I think about that”

Quote: My heart fails within me
Note: This could mean: (1) Job feels very hopeful, thankful, and happy or (2) Job feels exhausted waiting to see his Redeemer.

Quote: How we will persecute him!
Note: This is an exclamation. This could mean: (1) that they will certainly persecute Job or (2) that they will persecute him severely.

Quote: The root of his troubles lies in him
Note: The “root” represents the source. Alternate translation: “He is the source of all his troubles” or “He has all these troubles because of what he has done”

Quote: then be afraid of the sword
Note: Possible meanings are that the sword represents: (1) God judging them. Alternate translation: “then be afraid that God will judge you” or (2) God killing them. Alternate translation: “then be afraid that God will kill you”

Quote: because wrath brings the punishment of the sword
Note: The abstract nouns “wrath” and “punishment” can be expressed with the adjective “angry” and the verb “punish.” This could mean: (1) God’s anger results in punishment. Alternate translation: “because God will be angry with you and punish you” or (2) the anger of Job’s friends results in punishment. Alternate translation: “because if you are so angry with me, God will punish you”

Quote: brings
Note: Alternate translation: “causes” or “results in”

Quote: there is a judgment
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **judgment**, you can express the same idea with the verb “judge.” Alternate translation: “God judges people”

# Job 20 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is the advice of Job’s friend, Zophar. His words in this chapter are much stronger than when he previously spoke, and he is even angry at Job. He claims that Job took advantage of the poor and is being punished for it.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Zophar’s advice
Zophar tells Job to curse Yahweh. The advice Zophar gives to Job is bad advice. He tries to convince Job that he is sinning and has been punished by Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphors

There are many metaphors used in this chapter. Zophar uses them to explain the temporary nature of life and riches. He also uses them to describe God’s punishment of Job. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nZophar replies to Job.

Quote: Zophar the Naamathite
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Job 2:11](../02/11.md). Since this is the second time that Zophar speaks, some translations omit “the Naamathite” here.

Quote: My thoughts make me answer quickly
Note: The idea of Zophar’s thoughts making him do something represents his strong desire to do something. Alternate translation: “I want very much to answer you quickly”

Quote: because of the worry that is in me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **worry**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “worried.” The reason for the worry can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “because I am very worried about you” or “because I am very worried because of what you said” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: I hear a rebuke that dishonors me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **rebuke**, you can express the same idea with the verb “rebuke.” Alternate translation: “I hear you rebuke me, and what you say dishonors me” or “You insult me by how you rebuke me”

Quote: a spirit from my understanding answers me
Note: Here “spirit” probably refers to a thought or idea. Alternate translation: “a thought from my understanding answers me”

Quote: a spirit from my understanding answers me
Note: This “spirit” or thought is spoken of as if it were a person that could answer Zophar. Alternate translation: “I have a thought from my understanding, and now I know what I wanted to know”

Quote: a spirit from my understanding answers me
Note: The content of the answer can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “a thought from my understanding answers me about how I can reply to you” or “I have a thought from my understanding, and now I know how I can reply to you”

Quote: a spirit from my understanding answers me
Note: The abstract nouns “spirit” and “understanding” can be expressed with the verbs “think” and “understand.” Alternate translation: “because I understand things, I have thought, and now I know how I can reply to you”

Quote: Do you not know this fact from ancient times … man on earth
Note: Zophar begins a rhetorical question to cause Job to think deeply about what he will now say.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nZophar finishes the rhetorical question he began in verse 4.

Quote: the triumph … for a moment?
Note: Zophar uses a rhetorical question to cause Job to think deeply about what he will now say. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. “Surely you know … man on earth; the triumph … for a moment.”

Quote: the triumph of a wicked man is short
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **triumph**, you can express the same idea with the verbs “triumph” or “celebrate.” Alternate translation: “the wicked man triumphs only a short time” or “the wicked person celebrates for only a little while”

Quote: the joy of a godless man lasts only for a moment
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **joy**, you can express the same idea with the verb “rejoice” or the adjective “happy.” The word “moment” is an exaggeration to emphasize that the time is very short. Alternate translation: “a godless man rejoices for only a moment” or “the godless man is happy for only a very short time” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: Though his height reaches up to the heavens
Note: “Though the wicked person’s height reaches up to the heavens.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **height**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “tall.” Alternate translation: “Though he is as tall as the heavens”

Quote: Though his height reaches up to the heavens
Note: The wicked man’s height represents either his reputation or his pride. Also, here “reaches up to the heavens” represents being very great. Alternate translation: “Though his reputation is great” or “Though his pride is great”

Quote: his head reaches to the clouds
Note: “and though his head is as high as the clouds.” This also represents his reputation or pride being great. This means the same as the previous phrase. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: will perish permanently like his own feces
Note: Feces mixes in with the ground and disappears. The reference to feces may also imply that the wicked person is worthless. Alternate translation: “will perish permanently like his feces, which completely disappears in the ground”

Quote: will perish permanently like his own feces
Note: If people are embarrassed about the word feces, translators may refer to something else that disappears completely. Alternate translation: “will disappear permanently like dust that the wind blows away”

Quote: He will
Note: Alternate translation: “The wicked person will”

Quote: He will fly away like a dream … he will be chased away like a vision of the night
Note: Here “fly away” and “be chased away” represent disappearing. They may also imply being forgotten, since dreams and visions disappear when people forget them. Alternate translation: “He will disappear like a dream … he will be forgotten like a vision of the night” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: will not be found
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one will find him”

Quote: The eye that saw him
Note: The eye represents a person. Alternate translation: “Anyone who saw him” or “The people who saw him”

Quote: his place
Note: The phrase “his place” represents those who live in his place. Alternate translation: “the people who live in his place” or “his family”

Quote: His children
Note: Alternate translation: “The wicked person’s children”

Quote: his hands will have to give back his wealth
Note: Here the word “hands” refers to the wicked man’s children. When he dies, his children will have to return everything that he took from others.

Quote: His bones are full of youthful strength
Note: The word “bones” represents his body. Being “full of youthful strength” represents being strong like a young person. Alternate translation: “His body is strong like a young person’s body” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: but it will lie down with him in the dust
Note: The word “it” refers to his youthful strength. The metonym “lie down … in the dust” represents dying. The strength dying is a metaphor for disappearing. Alternate translation: “but his youthful strength will die with him” or “but his youthful strength will disappear when he dies” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Although wickedness is sweet in his mouth
Note: Here “wickedness is sweet” represents a person enjoying doing wicked things. Alternate translation: “Although doing wicked things is pleasurable like tasting sweet food in the mouth”

Quote: although he hides it under his tongue
Note: Zophar speaks of wickedness as if it were sweet food that a person puts under his tongue so it will stay in his mouth and he can taste it for a long time.

Quote: he holds it there and does not let it go but keeps it still in his mouth
Note: Zophar speaks of wickedness as if it were sweet food that a person puts under his tongue so it will stay in his mouth and he can taste it for a long time. (See: rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor)

Quote: the food in his intestines turns bitter
Note: When food turns bitter in the stomach, it causes pain and a bitter taste. This is a metaphor for a person experiencing the painful consequences of doing wicked things. Alternate translation: “those wicked things become like food that has turned bitter in the stomach” or “the consequences of those wicked things are painful like food that becomes sour in the stomach”

Quote: it becomes the poison of asps inside him
Note: This image is even worse than sour food in the stomach. This is a metaphor for a person experiencing the terrible consequences of doing wicked things. Alternate translation: “the consequences of doing those wicked things are painful like the poison of asps inside him”

Quote: asps
Note: poisonous snakes

Quote: He swallows down riches … cast them out of his stomach
Note: Zophar speaks of gaining and losing wealth as if it were food that a person eats and vomits. Alternate translation: “The wicked person becomes very wealthy, but he loses his wealth like a person who vomits up his food. God causes him to lose it all”

Quote: He swallows down riches
Note: Here, **swallows down riche** could mean: (1) accumulating riches and storing them selfishly. Alternate translation: “The wicked man gains much wealth and keeps it all for himself” or (2) accumulating riches in wicked ways. Alternate translation: “The wicked man steals many riches”

Quote: God will cast them out of his stomach
Note: Here “cast them out of his stomach” is a metonym for causing the man to vomit them. This is a metaphor for causing the man to lose his riches. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: cast
Note: throw

Quote: He will suck the poison of asps
Note: Here “suck the poison of asps” represents doing evil things. Both are very dangerous. Alternate translation: “Doing evil things is like sucking the poison of asps” or “He will do evil things and endanger his life like a person who sucks the poison of asps”

Quote: asps
Note: poisonous snakes

Quote: the viper’s tongue will kill him
Note: The viper is a poisonous snake. Its tongue represents its poisonous bite. Alternate translation: “the viper’s poisonous bite will kill him” or “the viper will bite him and he will die”

Quote: the viper’s tongue will kill him
Note: The viper represents the man’s wickedness. Alternate translation: “his wickedness will kill him like a viper’s bite”

Quote: the streams, the torrents of honey and butter
Note: “Streams” and “torrents” are metaphors that represent abundance. “Honey” and “butter” are metonyms that represent the good things that God gives people. Alternate translation: “the abundance of good things that God gives his people” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the fruit of his labor
Note: Normally “the fruit of his labor” simply refers to the results of his labor. In this case it refers to the things the wicked man had stolen. Alternate translation: “the things he had worked to get” or “the things he had stolen” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: will not be able to eat it
Note: Here “to eat” the fruit of his labor represents enjoying the things he had stolen. Alternate translation: “will not be able to enjoy them”

Quote: There is nothing left that he did not devour
Note: This can be reworded with only one of the negatives. Alternate translation: “He devoured everything, and there is nothing left” or “There is nothing left because he devoured everything”

Quote: There is nothing left that he did not devour
Note: Here “devour” represents taking things for himself. Alternate translation: “There is nothing left that he did not take for himself” or “He took everything for himself, and there is nothing left”

Quote: he will fall into trouble
Note: Alternate translation: “he will suddenly experience trouble”

Quote: the hand of everyone who is in poverty will come against him
Note: Here “hand” represents power, and “hand … will come against him” represents people attacking him. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **poverty**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “poor.” Alternate translation: “everyone who is in poverty will attack him” or “everyone who is poor will attack him” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: to fill his stomach
Note: Here “fill his stomach” is a metonym meaning eat a lot.

Quote: God will throw the fierceness of his wrath on him
Note: The “fierceness of his wrath” represents God’s anger and punishment. Throwing the punishment on him represents punishing him severely. Alternate translation: “God will be angry and throw down his punishment on him” or “God will be angry and punish him severely”

Quote: God will rain it down on him
Note: “God will cause it to rain down on him.” Here “rain it down on him” represents causing much punishment to happen to the man. Alternate translation: “God will punish him severely”

Quote: will flee from the iron weapon
Note: The iron weapon represents the person carrying it. Alternate translation: “will flee from the person carrying an iron weapon”

Quote: a bow of bronze will shoot him
Note: The bow represents the person who shoots an arrow with it. Alternate translation: “someone with a bronze bow will shoot him”

Quote: liver
Note: This is a large and important part of the body. If someone shoots through it with an arrow, the person who is shot will die.

Quote: Terrors come over him
Note: He will suddenly become very afraid. Alternate translation: “he is terrified”

Quote: Complete darkness is reserved for his treasures
Note: “Complete darkness” here is a metaphor for destruction. Alternate translation: “Destruction is reserved for his treasures” or “His treasures will be destroyed”

Quote: a fire not fanned will devour him
Note: Here “devour” is a metaphor meaning destroy. Alternate translation: “a fire that is not fanned will destroy him”

Quote: a fire not fanned will devour him
Note: The phrase “not fanned” implies that no human will start the fire. Rather, God will cause the fire. Alternate translation: “a fire that is not started by humans will destroy him” or “God will cause a fire to destroy him”

Quote: it will consume
Note: Here “consume” is a metaphor meaning destroy. Alternate translation: “the fire will destroy”

Quote: The heavens … the earth
Note: Possible meanings are: (1) those who live in the heavens and the earth or (2) Zophar is describing the heavens and the earth as if they are humans who will testify in court against the wicked person. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
# General Information:\n\nThis concludes Zophar’s speech to Job.

Quote: vanish
Note: disappear

Quote: his goods will flow away on
Note: Here “flow away” represents being taken away from him. Alternate translation: “his goods will be taken away from him, like goods that float away in a flood, on”

Quote: his goods
Note: Alternate translation: “his possessions”

Quote: the day of God’s wrath
Note: Here “wrath” represents punishment. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **wrath**, you can express the same idea with the verb punish. Alternate translation: “the day when God punishes people”

Quote: This is the wicked man’s portion from God
Note: Here “portion from God” represents what God has decided should happen to someone. It is spoken of as if it were something that God would give him. Alternate translation: “This is what God has decided should happen to the wicked man”

Quote: the heritage reserved for him by God
Note: This represents what God has decided should happen to someone. It is spoken of as if it were something that God would give him as an inheritance. Alternate translation: “what God has planned to give to him” or “what God has planned should happen to him”

# Job 21 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Zophar. It is also a response to all three of his friends in general.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Ancestor’s sin
In the ancient Near East, it was common to believe that a person could be punished because of the sins of their fathers and ancestors. It was seen as the punishment of a god. While a father’s sin may have consequences for their children, Yahweh does not punish people because of their father’s sin. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/believe]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Zophar that he is wrong. These questions help to build Job’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob begins to answer Zophar’s accusations.

Quote: Put up with me
Note: Alternate translation: “Allow me” or “Be patient with me”

Quote: mock on
Note: “you can continue mocking me.” Job is using sarcasm to imply that his friends would ignore what he would say and continue to mock him.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: As for me, is my complaint to a person? Why should I not be impatient?
Note: Job uses questions to emphasize that he thinks it is fair for him to complain to God. Alternate translation: “I am not complaining to a person. I have the right to be impatient”

Quote: lay your hand upon your mouth
Note: “cover your mouth with your hand.” Possible meanings are that: (1) this is a response to being astonished. Alternate translation: “cover your mouth with your hand” or (2) this is a symbol that the person will not speak. Alternate translation: “do not say anything”

Quote: trembling seizes my body
Note: Alternate translation: “fear causes my body to tremble” or “I shake with fear”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: Why do wicked people continue to live, become old, and grow mighty in power?
Note: Job uses this question to show that his friends are wrong to think evil men always suffer. Alternate translation: “Wicked people indeed continue to live, become old, and become wealthier.”

Quote: Their descendants are established with them in their sight … their offspring are established before their eyes
Note: This two clauses mean the same thing and emphasize that this is true.

Quote: in their sight … before their eyes
Note: These phrases mean the same thing because “eyes” refers to sight. Wicked people get to watch their descendants grow strong and wealthy. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Their houses
Note: Here “houses” refers to the family members that lives in them. Alternate translation: “Their families”

Quote: rod of God
Note: This refers to God’s punishment.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: does not lose her calf prematurely
Note: Alternate translation: “she does not miscarry” or “her calf is born healthy and strong”

Quote: little ones like a flock
Note: Job compares these children to lambs to emphasize that they run, play, and are happy.

Quote: tambourine
Note: a musical instrument with a head like a drum that can be hit and with pieces of metal around the side that sound when the instrument is shaken

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking with his friends.

Quote: their days
Note: Alternate translation: “their lifetime”

Quote: they go down quietly to Sheol
Note: This is a polite way of saying that they die. Alternate translation: “they die peacefully”

Quote: your ways
Note: This refers to how God wants people to behave.

Quote: What is the Almighty, that we should worship him? What advantage would we get if we prayed to him?
Note: The wicked people use these questions to mock God. Alternate translation: “We do not believe that this Almighty God is worthy of our worship. He can do nothing for us.”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: See, is not their prosperity in their own hands?
Note: Here “hands” refers to their power or control. Job uses this question to challenge his friends. Alternate translation: “Look, these wicked people claim that they make themselves prosper!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: How often is it … their calamity comes upon them?
Note: Job uses this question to emphasize that it seems to him that God does not punish the wicked very often. Alternate translation: “It is not often … their calamity comes upon them.”

Quote: the lamp of wicked people is put out
Note: Job compares extinguishing the lamp to a person dying. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that God causes them to die suddenly” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the lamp of wicked people
Note: Job compares the life of the wicked to a lamp that is burning.

Quote: How often does it happen … in his anger?
Note: Job uses this second question to emphasize that it seems to him that God does not punish the wicked very often. Alternate translation: “It is not often … in his anger.”

Quote: How often is it … the storm carries away?
Note: Job uses this third question to emphasize that it seems to him that God does not punish the wicked very often. Alternate translation: “It is not often … the storm carries away.”

Quote: they become like stubble before the wind or like chaff that the storm carries away
Note: The death of the wicked is spoken of as if they were worthless less chaff and stubble that blows away. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God takes them away like the wind blows away the chaff” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: You say
Note: These words are added by most versions in order to make it clear that the Job is quoting his friends in the next statement.

Quote: God lays up one’s guilt for his children to pay
Note: Guilt is spoken of as something that can be stored for later use. Here “to pay” refers to punishment for sin. Alternate translation: “God keeps a record of a person’s sins, then he punishes the person’s children for his wicked deeds”

Quote: Let him pay it himself, & know his guilt
Note: Job now begins to state his own opinion. It may be helpful to state this explicitly using an indirect quotation. “But I say that he should pay it himself, … know his guilt’”

Quote: Let his eyes see
Note: Here “eyes” refers to the person. Alternate translation: “Let him see”

Quote: let him drink of the wrath of the Almighty
Note: Here the wrath of God is spoken of as if it were a drink that a person can taste, and tasting is a metonym for experiencing the drink. Job wants the wicked person to experience God’s punishment. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: For what does he care about his family after him when the number of his months is cut off?
Note: Job uses this question to show that punishing the evil man’s children is not effective. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “For the wicked man does not care what happens to his family after he has died!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the number of his months is cut off
Note: This is a polite way of saying that he dies.

Quote: the number of his months
Note: This refers to the length of his life.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: Can anyone teach God knowledge since he judges even those who are high?
Note: Job asks this question to emphasize that God knows everything. Alternate translation: “Obviously, no one can teach anything to God since he even judges those in heaven.”

Quote: those who are high
Note: This could mean: (1) “those who are in heaven” or (2) “powerful people.”

Quote: One man dies in his full strength
Note: Job contrasts this man who dies in health and peace to the man who dies in sorrow and pain in [Job 21:25](../21/25.md). You can make this explicit. Alternate translation: “If there are two men, one may die in his full strength”

Quote: His body is full of milk … the marrow of his bones is moist
Note: Both of these phrases mean that the person is very healthy.

Quote: His body is full of milk
Note: The word for “milk” may mean “fat.” Either rendering means he is well-fed. Alternate translation: “His body if full of fat”

Quote: the marrow of his bones is moist
Note: This idiom means his body is youthful and healthy.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: Another man dies
Note: Job contrasts this man to the man who dies in peace in [Job 21:23](../21/23.md).

Quote: in bitterness of soul
Note: Here sorrow is spoken of as if it tasted bitter, and “soul” refers to the whole man. Alternate translation: “with anger and resentment” or “after living a sad life” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: has never experienced anything good
Note: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “has experienced only bad things”

Quote: They lie down alike in the dust
Note: This is a polite way to say that they died. Alternate translation: “They both die and people bury them”

Quote: the worms cover them both
Note: Worms are associated with decay of dead bodies. Alternate translation: “the worms in the dirt eat their dead bodies”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: See
Note: Job uses this phrase to call attention to the statement that follows. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: Where now is the house of the prince? Where is the tent in which the wicked man once lived?
Note: Job believes his friends will ask these question to scold him. Both questions mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “See, the house of the evil ruler is gone. The tent of the wicked man has disappeared.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: Have you never asked traveling people?
Note: Job uses these questions to rebuke his friends for not learning from people who travel. Alternate translation: “You should listen to those who have traveled to distant places.”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob finishes asking a rhetorical question that begins with the words “Do you not know” in verse 29.

Quote: the wicked man is kept … from the day of wrath?
Note: Job uses these questions to rebuke his friends for not learning from people who travel. “Those who have traveled to distant places will tell you … from the day of wrath.”

Quote: the wicked man is kept from the day of calamity … he is led away from the day of wrath
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God keeps the wicked man from the day of calamity … God leads him away from the day of wrath”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to his friends.

Quote: Who will condemn the wicked man’s way to his face?
Note: Job uses this question to contradict his friends’ belief that the wicked are always judged. Alternate translation: “No one condemns the wicked man to his face.”

Quote: to his face
Note: This means no one will go directly to the wicked person and condemn him personally.

Quote: Who will repay him for what he has done?
Note: Job uses this question to contradict his friends’ belief that the wicked are always judged. Alternate translation: “No one repays him for the bad things that he has done.”

Quote: he will be borne
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people will carry him”

Quote: The clods of the valley will be sweet to him
Note: Job imagines that the dead person will even enjoy the dirt that is put on him. This means the wicked person will even have a good death and a nice burial after a fulfilling life. “Clods” refer to the earth that covers the grave. Alternate translation: “He will enjoy being covered with the dirt of the valley” or “He will enjoy being buried in the dirt of the valley”

Quote: all people will follow after him, as there were innumerable people before him
Note: Job emphasizes that a large crowd of people will be in the funeral procession of this imaginary wicked man to honor him. Alternate translation: “a huge number of people go to the grave site; some go in front of the procession and some come behind”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nThis concludes Job’s speech to his friends.

Quote: How then do you comfort me with nonsense, since in your answers there is nothing but falsehood?
Note: Job uses a question to scold his friends. Alternate translation: “You cannot comfort me with nonsense. All of your answers are false.”

# Job 22 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of the advice of Job’s friend, Eliphaz. His words in this chapter are much stronger than when he previously spoke.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Repentance

Eliphaz tries to get Job to repent in this chapter. Eliphaz assumes that he is righteous, while assuming Job is not. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/repent]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Eliphaz uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Job that he is wrong. These questions help to build Eliphaz’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Eliphaz the Temanite
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Job 2:11](../02/11.md).

Quote: Can a man be useful to God? Can a wise man be useful to him?
Note: Both questions mean basically the same thing. Eliphaz uses questions to emphasize that a person’s actions and wisdom do not benefit God. Alternate translation: “A man cannot be useful to God. A wise man cannot be useful to him.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Is it any pleasure to the Almighty if you are righteous? Is it gain to him if you make your ways blameless?
Note: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Eliphaz uses questions to emphasize that Job’s actions do not help God. Alternate translation: “The Almighty does not receive any pleasure if you are righteous. He does not gain anything if you make your ways blameless.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: Is it because of your reverence for him that he rebukes you and takes you to judgment?
Note: Eliphaz uses questions to scold Job and accuse him of committing terrible sins. Alternate translation: “It is certainly not because you have been devoted to him that God rebukes you and takes you to judgment!”

Quote: Is not your wickedness great? Is there no end to your iniquities?
Note: Eliphaz uses questions to scold Job and accuse him of committing terrible sins. Alternate translation: “As you know, he judges you because your wickedness is great and you keep on sinning!”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: you have demanded guarantee of a loan
Note: This refers to a lender taking something from the borrower to ensure that the borrower pays him back.

Quote: you have stripped away clothing from the naked
Note: Eliphaz is accusing Job of taking clothes as security from poor people who borrowed from him.

Quote: withheld bread
Note: Here “bread” refers to food in general. Alternate translation: “withheld food”

Quote: possessed the earth … lived in it
Note: Eliphaz is accusing Job of taking land from poor people and not allowing them to live on it. He is emphasizing this point by restating it twice.

Quote: possessed the earth
Note: Eliphaz is exaggerating the amount of land that Job owned in order to portray Job as greedy. Alternate translation: “possessed a great amount of land”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: You have sent widows away empty
Note: Alternate translation: “You made widows go away with nothing”

Quote: widows
Note: women whose husbands have died

Quote: the arms of the fatherless have been broken
Note: Here “arms” refer to power. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “you even oppressed orphans” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: snares are all around you … sudden fear troubles you
Note: These are metaphors for trouble and danger. Alternate translation: “you are always in danger … you become afraid for no reason”

Quote: There is darkness … an abundance of waters covers you
Note: Each of these metaphors means troubles and dangers are all around Job because of his sin.

Quote: an abundance of waters
Note: Alternate translation: “a flood”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: Is not God in the heights of heaven?
Note: Eliphaz uses this question to say that God sees Job’s sin and will judge him. Alternate translation: “God is in the heights of heaven and sees everything that happens on earth.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Look at the height of the stars, how high they are!
Note: Eliphaz implies that God is higher than the stars. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Look at how high the stars are. God is even higher than the stars!”

Quote: What does God know? Can he judge through the thick darkness?
Note: Eliphaz uses these questions to imply that Job has said these things against God. Alternate translation: “God does not know what happens on earth. He sits in dark clouds and cannot see to judge us.”

Quote: he walks on the vault of heaven
Note: Here “vault” refers to the barrier that ancient people believed separated the earth from heaven. Alternate translation: “he lives too far away in heaven to see what happens here”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: those who were snatched away
Note: Dying is compared to God snatching them away. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “those who died” or “those whom God took away” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: those whose foundations have washed away like a river
Note: The death of wicked people is compared to buildings that had their foundations washed away by a flood.

Quote: What can the Almighty do to us?
Note: Eliphaz quotes a question wicked people use to mock God. Alternate translation: “The Almighty cannot do anything to us!”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: Yet he filled
Note: Alternate translation: “Yet God filled”

Quote: the plans of wicked people are far from me
Note: The idiom “far from me” means Eliphaz rejects them. Alternate translation: “but I will not listen to their wicked plans”

Quote: see their fate
Note: Alternate translation: “know what will happen to the wicked”

Quote: laugh them to scorn
Note: Alternate translation: “mock the wicked people”

Quote: They say
Note: Alternate translation: “The righteous say”

Quote: Surely those who rose up against us are cut off
Note: Here “those who rose up” refers to the wicked people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Surely God has destroyed the wicked people who harmed us”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: Now
Note: Eliphaz uses this word to introduce something important he is about to say.

Quote: instruction from his mouth
Note: Here “from his mouth” represents what God has spoken. Alternate translation: “the instruction that God has spoken”

Quote: store up his words
Note: God’s words are compared to treasures that Job could keep in a storeroom. Alternate translation: “treasure his commands”

Quote: your heart
Note: Here “heart” refers to Job’s thoughts. Alternate translation: “your mind”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: you will be built up
Note: Eliphaz compares Job’s restoration to the rebuilding of a house that has fallen. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he will heal you and make you prosper again” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: if you put unrighteousness far away from your tents
Note: Unrighteousness is pictured as a person who is living in Job’s tent who must be removed. Alternate translation: “if you and everyone in your house stops sinning”

Quote: Lay your treasure down in the dust
Note: To lay a treasure in the dust is to treat it as unimportant. Alternate translation: “Consider your riches as unimportant as dust”

Quote: the gold of Ophir among the stones of the brooks
Note: To put gold in the stream is to treat it as no more valuable than stones. Alternate translation: “the gold of Ophir is as worthless as stones in a stream”

Quote: Ophir
Note: This is the name of a region famous for its gold.

Quote: the Almighty will be your treasure, precious silver to you
Note: This means God will be more valuable to Job than any treasure.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nEliphaz continues speaking to Job.

Quote: you will lift up your face to God
Note: This means Job will no longer be ashamed but will trust in God. Alternate translation: “you will be able to approach God confidently”

Quote: it will be confirmed for you
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will cause you to succeed”

Quote: light will shine on your paths
Note: God’s blessing is compared to a light on all of Job’s paths. Alternate translation: “it will be like a light shining on the road in front of you”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nThis concludes Eliphaz’s speech to Job.

Quote: the one with lowered eyes
Note: Here “lowered eyes” refers to humility. Alternate translation: “the humble person”

Quote: He will rescue even the man who is not innocent; who will be rescued through the cleanness of your hands
Note: Job being innocent is spoken of as if his hands were physically clean. The phrase “who will be rescued” can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will rescue even the person who is not innocent because you do what is right” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: He will rescue even the man who is not innocent; who will be rescued through the cleanness of your hands
Note: Some versions of the Bible read, “He rescues the innocent person; so he will rescue you when your hands are clean”

# Job 23 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Eliphaz.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Court

This chapter uses an extended metaphor of a court case to describe Job’s “case,” which he seeks to bring to Yahweh, who is a judge. Cultures without a legal system will have difficulty translating this chapter. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Even today my complaint is bitter
