Note: Here “Even today” emphasizes that his friends arguments have not changed Job’s situation at all. Alternate translation: “In spite of what you have said, my complaint is still bitter”

Quote: my complaint is bitter
Note: Job speaks of his unanswered complaint against God as if it was a bitter taste in his mouth. Alternate translation: “my unanswered complaint is as bad as bitter food in my mouth”

Quote: my hand … heavy because of my groaning
Note: This could mean: (1) “I can barely lift my hand because of my groaning” or (2) “God’s hand continues to make me suffer in spite of my groaning” where “hand” refers to God’s power to punish.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: Oh, that I knew where … Oh, that I might come
Note: These two lines mean the same thing and emphasize Job’s desire to meet with God.

Quote: I might find him
Note: Alternate translation: “I might find God”

Quote: lay my case … fill my mouth
Note: These two lines mean the same thing and emphasize Job’s desire to explain his situation to God.

Quote: fill my mouth with arguments
Note: Here “fill my mouth” refers to speaking. Alternate translation: “I would speak all of my arguments”

Quote: I would learn the words … would understand
Note: These two lines mean basically the same thing and emphasize Job’s desire to hear God’s answer.

Quote: the words with which he would answer me
Note: Alternate translation: “the answer that he would give me”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: Would he
Note: Alternate translation: “Would God”

Quote: There
Note: This refers to the place where God is.

Quote: I would be acquitted forever by my judge
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “my judge would acquit me forever” or “God, who is my judge, would say that I am innocent once and for all”
Job continues speaking. He begins using a merism to say that he has looked everywhere.

Quote: north … south
Note: This is the end of the merism that begins with the words “eastward … westward” in verse 8. By mentioning these four directions, Job emphasizes that he has looked everywhere.

Quote: where he hides himself
Note: Job speaks of God as if he is a person who hides.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: he knows the way that I take
Note: Job’s actions are spoken of as if he is walking on a path. Alternate translation: “God knows what I do”

Quote: I will come out like gold
Note: Job believes that the test will prove that he is as pure as refined gold. Alternate translation: “he will see that I am as pure as gold when anything not pure has been burned away”

Quote: My foot has held fast to his steps
Note: Here “My foot” refers to Job. Alternate translation: “I have followed the path he has shown me”

Quote: I have kept to his way
Note: Job’s obedience is spoken of as if he is walking in a path that God showed him. Alternate translation: “I have done what he told me to do”

Quote: turned not aside
Note: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “followed it exactly”

Quote: I have not gone back from
Note: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “I have always obeyed”

Quote: of his lips
Note: This phrase refers to the message that God spoke. Alternate translation: “that he spoke”

Quote: the words of his mouth
Note: Here God is represented by his “mouth.” Alternate translation: “what he said”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: But he is one of a kind, who can turn him back?
Note: Job uses this question to emphasize that there is no one like God and no one can force him to change. Alternate translation: “But there is no one like him, and nobody can make him change his mind.” or “But he alone is God, and no one can influence him.”

Quote: What he desires, he does
Note: Alternate translation: “He does whatever he wants to do”

Quote: he carries out his decree against me
Note: Alternate translation: “he is doing to me what he said he would do”

Quote: there are many like them
Note: Alternate translation: “he has many similar plans for me”
# General Information:\n\nEach of these verses has the form of a parallelism to emphasize the main point Job makes there.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: For God has made my heart weak; the Almighty has terrified me
Note: These two lines mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Job is very afraid of God.

Quote: made my heart weak
Note: A person whose heart is weak is a person who is timid or fearful. Alternate translation: “made me afraid”

Quote: I have not been brought to an end by darkness
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This could mean: (1) “The thick darkness in front of me has not made me silent” or (2) “Darkness has not stopped me” or “God has stopped me, not the darkness.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the gloom of my face
Note: Here Job refers to himself by his “face.” Alternate translation: “my sadness”

# Job 24 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Eliphaz. It is a continuation of the previous chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Court

This chapter uses an extended metaphor of a court case to describe Job’s “case,” which he seeks to bring to Yahweh, who is a judge. Cultures without a legal system will have difficulty translating this chapter. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Job uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Eliphaz that he is wrong. These questions help to build Job’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: Why are times for judging wicked people not set by the Almighty?
Note: Job uses this question to express his frustration that God has not judged evil. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I do not understand why God does not set a time when he will judge wicked people.” or “The Almighty should set a time when he will judge wicked people.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Why do not those who are faithful to God see his days of judgment come?
Note: Job uses this question to express his frustration that the righteous have not seen God judge evil. Alternate translation: “It seems that those who obey him never get to see him judge the wicked.” or “God should show the day he will judge the wicked to those who know him.”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: boundary markers
Note: These are stones or other objects to mark the boundary between the lands owned by different people.

Quote: pastures
Note: land with grass for animals to eat

Quote: They drive away
Note: Alternate translation: “They steal”

Quote: those without fathers
Note: Alternate translation: “orphans” or “children whose parents have died”

Quote: they take the widow’s ox as security
Note: Alternate translation: “they take widows’ oxen to guarantee that the widows will pay back the money that they loaned to those widows”

Quote: widow
Note: a woman whose husband has died

Quote: as security
Note: A lender would take something from a borrower to ensure that the borrower pays him back.

Quote: out of their path
Note: Alternate translation: “out of their way” or “off the road”

Quote: poor people of the earth all hide themselves
Note: The word “all” is an exaggeration to show that many poor people are afraid of these wicked people.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: these poor people go out to their work like wild donkeys in the wilderness, looking carefully for food
Note: These poor people are spoken of as if they are wild donkeys who do not know where they will find food. Alternate translation: “these poor people go out to search for food as if they were wild donkeys in the wilderness”

Quote: wild donkeys
Note: Alternate translation: “donkeys that no one owns or cares for”

Quote: Poor people reap in the night … they glean grapes
Note: These two lines describe the same thing and are used together to emphasize that these people are so hungry that they are forced to steal food at night.

Quote: They lie naked … they have no covering
Note: These two lines describe the same thing and are used together to emphasize that these people do not have enough clothing to keep warm.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: They are wet with the showers of the mountains
Note: Alternate translation: “They become wet when it rains in the mountains”

Quote: orphans from their mothers’ breast
Note: Here “breast” refers to the mother. This implies that these orphans are still very young. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “young orphans out of their mothers’ arms” or “fatherless infants from their mothers” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: orphans
Note: This generally refers to children without parents. Here, however, it is used for children who have mothers but do not have fathers.

Quote: take children as security from poor people
Note: Alternate translation: “take poor people’s children to guarantee that the poor people will pay back money that they borrowed from the wicked people”

Quote: as security
Note: A lender would take something from a borrower to ensure that the borrower pays him back. See how you translated this in [Job 24:3](../24/03.md).

Quote: go about
Note: Alternate translation: “walk around”

Quote: naked without clothing
Note: The words “without clothing” mean the same thing as “naked.” Alternate translation: “completely naked” or “naked because they have no clothing”

Quote: they carry bundles of grain belonging to other people
Note: This means their work will provide food for others but not for themselves.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: The poor people make oil
Note: they squeezed olives in order to extract olive oil from them

Quote: within the walls of those wicked men
Note: Here “walls” refers to the whole house. Alternate translation: “in the houses of those evil men”

Quote: they tread the wicked men’s winepresses
Note: It may be helpful to state that they do this to produce juice to make wine. Alternate translation: “they tread on grapes to make juice for wine”

Quote: they themselves suffer thirst
Note: Alternate translation: “they suffer from thirst” or “they are thirsty”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: rebel against the light
Note: Here, **light** could mean: (1) visible light or (2) spiritual light, which refers to God or living righteously. Alternate translation: “hate the daylight” or “do not want to do things openly” or “rebel against God”

Quote: they know not its ways, nor do they stay in its paths
Note: These two lines describe the same thing, and are used together to emphasize that they do not want to follow the ways of the light. Alternate translation: “they do not know how to live a moral life; they stay far away from living a righteous life” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: poor and needy people
Note: The words “poor” and “needy” refer to the same group of people and emphasize that these are people who are unable to help themselves.

Quote: he is like a thief
Note: The murderer kills in secret just like a thief steals without anyone seeing what he does. Alternate translation: “he kills people secretly, just like a thief steals secretly”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: the eye of the adulterer
Note: Here “eye” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “the adulterer”

Quote: for the twilight
Note: Alternate translation: “for the sunset”

Quote: No eye will see me
Note: Here “eye” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “No one will see me”

Quote: wicked people dig into houses
Note: They dig into the houses in order to steal from them. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “wicked people dig into houses to steal from them”

Quote: they shut themselves up
Note: Alternate translation: “they hide inside”

Quote: For all of them, thick darkness is like the morning
Note: The thick darkness is as comfortable for the wicked as light of the morning is for normal people.

Quote: the terrors of thick darkness
Note: Alternate translation: “the scary things that happen at night”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: like foam on the surface of the waters
Note: Foam lasts only a short time. This emphasizes how quickly God will cause the wicked to disappear.

Quote: their portion of the land is cursed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God curses the part of the land that they own”

Quote: As drought and heat melt away … those who have sinned
Note: Job says that sinners will disappear in Sheol in the same way as snow melts and disappears when it becomes warm.

Quote: drought and heat
Note: These two words describe essentially the same weather and are used together to describe it fully.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: The womb
Note: This refers to the mother. Alternate translation: “The mother”

Quote: the worm will feed sweetly on him
Note: This means that he will die and worms will eat his body. Alternate translation: “the worm will enjoy eating his dead body” or “he will die and then his body will be eaten by worms”

Quote: he will be remembered no more
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one will remember him anymore”

Quote: wickedness will be broken like a tree
Note: God’s destruction of the wicked man is describes as if he were cutting down a tree. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will destroy the wicked as if he were a tree” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: The wicked one devours
Note: This metaphor emphasizes how ruthless the wicked man is. Alternate translation: “Just like a wild animal kills its prey, so the wicked person harms”

Quote: the barren women who have not borne children
Note: The people of that day considered that a woman who was barren was cursed by God. Therefore, this represents the most unfortunate women.

Quote: widow
Note: a woman whose husband has died

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking.

Quote: by his power
Note: Alternate translation: “by using his power” or “because he is powerful”

Quote: he rises up and does not strengthen them in life
Note: Here “does not strengthen them in life” means God does not keep them alive. Alternate translation: “God rises up and does not give wicked people the strength to live” or “God rises up and causes them to die”

Quote: but his eyes are on their ways
Note: Here “eyes” refers to God. Alternate translation: “but he is always watching what they do”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nThis concludes Job’s speech.

Quote: they will be brought low
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will bring them low” or “God will destroy them”

Quote: they will be gathered up like all the others
Note: Some translations are based on a different early text, which says “they wither and fade like weeds.”

Quote: they will be gathered up like all the others
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. What “the others” refers to can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “God will gather them up as he gathered up the other wicked people” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: they will be cut off like the tops of ears of grain
Note: These wicked people will be cut off in the same way heads of grain are cut off during harvest. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will cut them off like a farmer cuts off the top of a stalk of grain” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: If it is not so, who can prove me to be a liar; who can make my speech worth nothing?
Note: Job uses this question to express the certainty of his argument. The implicit answer is: “no one.” Alternate translation: “This is true, and no one can prove that I am a liar; no one can prove me wrong.”

Quote: make my speech worth nothing
Note: Alternate translation: “prove what I say is wrong”

# Job 25 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of the advice of Job’s friend, Bildad. His words in this chapter are much stronger than when he previously spoke.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### God’s holiness and man’s sin
Bildad describes the holiness of Yahweh and the universal nature of man’s sinfulness. While his points are accurate, they are not convincing for Job because he has been righteous. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/holy]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Bildad uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Job that he is wrong. These questions help to build Bildad’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Bildad the Shuhite
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Job 2:11](../02/11.md).

Quote: Dominion and fear are with him
Note: Here “him” refers to God. The abstract nouns “dominion” and “fear” can be stated as verbs. Alternate translation: “God rules over all and people should fear only him”

Quote: he makes order in his high places of heaven
Note: Alternate translation: “he makes peace in the high heaven”

Quote: Is there any end to the number of his armies?
Note: Bildad uses this question to emphasize how great God is. The implicit answer is “no.” This refers to the armies of God’s angels. Alternate translation: “There is no end to the number of angels in his army.” or “His armies are so big that no one can count them.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Upon whom does his light not shine?
Note: Bildad uses this question to emphasize that God gives light to every person. Alternate translation: “There is no one upon whom his light does not shine.” or “God makes his light shine over everyone.”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nBildad continues speaking.

Quote: How then can man … God? How can he who is born … him?
Note: These two questions are used together to emphasize that it is impossible for a man to be good enough before God. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: How then can man be righteous with God?
Note: The implicit reaction is that he cannot. Alternate translation: “A man can never be righteous before God.”

Quote: How can he who is born … acceptable to him?
Note: The implicit reaction is that he cannot. Alternate translation: “He who is born of a woman cannot be clean or acceptable to him.”

Quote: he who is born of a woman
Note: This idiom includes everyone. Alternate translation: “any person”

Quote: See
Note: The word “See” here adds emphasis to what follows. Alternate translation: “Indeed”

Quote: the moon has no brightness to him
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **brightness**, you can express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “the moon is not bright enough for God”

Quote: the stars are not pure in his sight
Note: Here “pure” means “perfect.” Alternate translation: “he does not think even the stars are perfect”

Quote: How much less man … a son of man, who is a worm
Note: These two lines say the same thing and are used together to emphasize that man is not perfect.

Quote: who is a worm
Note: Bildad states that human beings are as worthless as worms. Alternate translation: “who is as worthless as a worm”

Quote: a son of man
Note: This is another way of referring to a person. Alternate translation: “a person”

# Job 26 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is Job’s response to Bildad.

This chapter begins a section continuing through chapter 31.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s power
While Bildad describes Yahweh’s power as being so much greater than Job’s, Job understands the true extent of Yahweh’s power. It is not just over Job’s life, but over all of creation.

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Sarcasm

Job uses sarcasm in this chapter. This is the use of irony to insult Bildad. (See: [Job 1–4](./01.md) and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: How you have helped one … the arm that has no strength
Note: In these statements, Job is accusing Bildad. The word “one” refers to Job. And, the word “arm” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “I am powerless and have no strength, but you act like you have helped me; but really, you have not helped me at all” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: How you have advised one who has no wisdom and announced to him sound knowledge
Note: Job is saying that Bildad has not provided him with good advice and knowledge. Alternate translation: “You act like I have no wisdom and that you have advised me, that you have given me good advice”

Quote: announced to him sound knowledge
Note: Alternate translation: “given him good advice”

Quote: With whose help have you spoken these words? Whose spirit was it … you?
Note: In these questions Job continues to mock Bildad. They are both rhetorical questions and have basically the same meaning. They are used together to strengthen each other. Alternate translation: “You must have had help speaking these words. Perhaps some spirit helped you speak them!”

Quote: The dead
Note: This refers to dead people. Alternate translation: “Those who are dead” or “The spirits of the dead”

Quote: tremble
Note: They tremble because they are afraid of God. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “tremble in fear” or “tremble in fear of God”

Quote: those who are beneath the waters
Note: This refers to the dead people who tremble.

Quote: all who dwell in them
Note: This refers to the dead people who dwell in the waters.

Quote: Sheol is naked before God; destruction itself has no covering
Note: Sheol is spoken of as if it were a person. These two phrases have the same meaning. To be “naked” or have “no covering” is to be completely exposed and not able to hide anything. Alternate translation: “It is like sheol is naked before God, for nothing in sheol, the place of destruction, is hidden from God” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: destruction
Note: This is another name for sheol. Alternate translation: “the place of destruction”

Quote: He stretches out the northern skies over the empty space
Note: The northern skies represent heaven, the place where God dwells with the beings he created to dwell there.

Quote: He binds up the waters in his thick clouds
Note: The clouds are compared to a large blanket in which God wraps the rainwater. Alternate translation: “He wraps up the water in his thick clouds”

Quote: but the clouds are not torn under them
Note: This can be stated actively. The word “them” refers to the waters. Alternate translation: “but the weight of the waters does not tear the clouds”

Quote: and spreads his clouds on it
Note: This phrase tells how he covers the surface of the moon. Alternate translation: “by spreading his clouds in front of it”

Quote: He has engraved a circular boundary on the surface of the waters
Note: This speaks of the horizon, where the earth appears to meet the sky, as if God has marked a boundary on the ocean.

Quote: The pillars of heaven tremble and are astonished at his rebuke
Note: People thought of heaven or the sky as resting on pillars. Job speaks as though the pillars are humans that shake in fear when God is angry. Alternate translation: “The pillars that hold up heaven shake in fear when God rebukes them” or “The pillars that hold up the sky shake like people who are afraid when God rebukes them”

Quote: he shattered Rahab
Note: Alternate translation: “he destroyed Rahab”

Quote: Rahab
Note: This is the name of a frightening monster that lived in the sea. See how you translated this in [Job 9:13](../09/13.md).

Quote: By his breath he made the skies clear
Note: The noun “breath” can be translated with the verb “breathe” or “blow.” This image represents God causing the wind to blow away the clouds. Alternate translation: “God blew away the clouds so that the skies were clear”

Quote: his hand pierced the fleeing serpent
Note: It is implied that God his holding a sword, and here “his hand” represents that sword. Also, “pierced” represents killing. Alternate translation: “With his sword he pierced the fleeing serpent” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the fleeing serpent
Note: “the serpent as it was trying to escape from him.” This refers to Rahab, the monster in the sea. See [Job 26:12](../26/12.md).

Quote: See, these are but the fringes of his ways
Note: Here “fringes” represents a small part that we can see of something that is much bigger. Alternate translation: “See, these things that God has done show only a small part of his great power”

Quote: how small a whisper do we hear of him!
Note: This is an exclamation that expresses Job’s amazement of all the great things that God does that we do not even know about. Seeing what God does is spoken of as hearing God’s voice. Alternate translation: “it is as if we heard only his quiet whisper!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Who can understand the thunder of his power?
Note: The “thunder of his power” represents God’s greatness. Job uses this question to emphasize that God’s power is so great that no one can understand it. Alternate translation: “The thunder displays the greatness of his power which no one can understand!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Job 27 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s response to Bildad.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Job’s righteousness
Despite being upset about his circumstances, Job does not curse God. Instead, he recognizes Yahweh’s authority. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]])

Quote: As surely as God lives
Note: This phrase shows that Job is taking an oath. Job compares the certainty that God is alive to the certainty of what he is saying. This is a way of making a solemn promise. Alternate translation: “I swear by God”

Quote: has taken away my justice
Note: Justice is spoken of as if it were an object that could be taken away or given. Taking it away represents refusing to treat Job with justice. Alternate translation: “has refused to treat me justly”

Quote: made my life bitter
Note: Job’s “life” being bitter represents Job feeling resentful toward God. Alternate translation: “has caused me to become resentful” or “has made me feel angry because of the unfair way he has treated me”

Quote: while my life is yet in me
Note: This refers to the duration of the rest of his life. Alternate translation: “during the whole time that my life is yet in me” or “as long as my life is yet in me”

Quote: while my life is yet in me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **life**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “alive” or the verb “live.” Alternate translation: “as long as I am still alive” or “while I still live”

Quote: the breath from God is in my nostrils
Note: “Breath … in my nostrils” represents being able to breathe. “Breath from God” represents God making him able to breathe. Alternate translation: “God enables me to breathe”

Quote: nostrils
Note: Alternate translation: “nose”

Quote: My lips will not speak wickedness, neither will my tongue speak deceit
Note: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that he will not speak in such ways. The phrases “My lips” and “my tongue” represent Job himself. Alternate translation: “I will not speak wickedness or deceit” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: speak wickedness … speak deceit
Note: The abstract nouns “wickedness” and “deceit” can be expressed with “wickedly” and “deceitfully.” Alternate translation: “speak wickedly … speak deceitfully”

Quote: I will never admit that you three are right
Note: Alternate translation: “I will never agree with you and say that you three are right”

Quote: that you three are right
Note: The word “you” here is plural. It refers to Job’s friends.

Quote: I will never deny my integrity
Note: Alternate translation: “I will never say that I am not innocent” or “I will always say that I am innocent”

Quote: I hold fast to my righteousness
Note: Here “hold fast” is a metaphor that represents being determined to continue to say something. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **righteousness**, you can express the same idea with “righteous.” Alternate translation: “I am determined to continue saying that I am righteous” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: will not let it go
Note: Here “will not let it go” is a metaphor that represents not stopping saying something. Alternate translation: “will not stop saying that I am righteous” or “will not stop saying so”

Quote: my thoughts will not reproach me
Note: Here the phrase “my thoughts” represents Job. Alternate translation: “even in my thoughts, I will not reproach myself”

Quote: Let my enemy be … let him who rises up against me be
Note: The two clauses that start with these words share the same meaning. They are used together to emphasize Job’s strong desire that this should happen.

Quote: Let my enemy be like a wicked man
Note: How he wants his enemy to be like a wicked person can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Let my enemy be punished like a wicked man” or “Let God punish my enemy as he punishes wicked people”

Quote: let him who rises up against me be like an unrighteous man
Note: How he wants this person to be like an unrighteous man can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “let him who rises up against me be punished like an unrighteous man”

Quote: him who rises up against me
Note: Here “rises up against me” is a metaphor meaning “opposes me.” The whole phrase refers to Job’s adversary. Alternate translation: “him who opposes me” or “my adversary”

Quote: For what is the hope of a godless man when … when God takes away his life?
Note: Job uses this question to say that such a man has no hope. This question can be translated as a simple statement. Alternate translation: “There is no hope for the godless when God … takes away his soul.”

Quote: when God cuts him off, when God takes away his life
Note: These two phrases have the same meaning. Alternate translation: “when God cuts him off and takes away his life” or “when God causes him to die”

Quote: cuts him off
Note: This is a metaphor meaning “kills him” or “causes him to die”

Quote: takes away his life
Note: This is a metaphor meaning “kills him” or “makes him stop living”

Quote: Will God hear his cry when trouble comes upon him?
Note: Job uses this question to say that God will not help that person. This question can be translated as a simple statement. Alternate translation: “God will not hear his cry when trouble comes upon him.” or “When trouble comes upon him and he cries out for help, God will not hear him.”

Quote: Will God hear his cry
Note: Here “hear his cry” represents responding to the godless man’s cry and helping him. Alternate translation: “Will God respond to his cry”

Quote: Will he delight himself in the Almighty and call upon God at all times?
Note: Job uses this question to say that the godless man will not do these things. This question can be translated as a simple statement. Alternate translation: “He will not delight himself in the Almighty and call upon God at all times.” or “He will not be happy about what the Almighty does and he will not pray to God often.”

Quote: I will teach you
Note: Each occurrence of “you” in these verses is plural and refers to Job’s three friends.

Quote: the hand of God
Note: God’s “hand” represents his power. Alternate translation: “the power of God”

Quote: I will not conceal the thoughts of the Almighty
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **thoughts**, you can express the same idea with the verb “think.” Alternate translation: I will not hide from you what the Almighty thinks”

Quote: why then have you spoken all this nonsense?
Note: Job uses this question to rebuke his friends for saying such foolish things. This question can be translated as a simple statement. Alternate translation: “you should not have spoken so foolishly!”

Quote: This is the portion of a wicked man with God
Note: Alternate translation: “This is what God has planned for the wicked man”

Quote: the heritage of the oppressor that he receives from the Almighty
Note: Here “the heritage of the oppressor” is a metaphor representing what will happen to the oppressor. What God will do to him is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that God will give him. Alternate translation: “what the Almighty will do to the oppressor”

Quote: it is for the sword
Note: Here “the sword” represents dying in battle. Alternate translation: “they will die in battle”

Quote: Those who survive him
Note: This refers to the wicked man’s children. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Those who continue to live after their wicked father dies”

Quote: will be buried by plague
Note: Here “be buried” represents dying. Alternate translation: “will die by plague”

Quote: their widows … them
Note: The words “their” and “them” refer to “Those who survive him,” that is, the children of the wicked man.

Quote: heaps up silver like the dust
Note: Here “heaps up” is a metonym meaning “gathers much.” Job speaks as if the silver were as easy to get as dust. Alternate translation: “gathers large piles of silver” or “gathers silver as easily as he could gather dust”

Quote: heaps up clothing like clay
Note: Here “heaps up” is a metonym meaning “gathers much.” Job speaks as if the clothing were as easy to get as clay. Alternate translation: “gathers large piles of clothing” or “gathers clothing as easily as he could gather clay”

Quote: He builds his house like a spider
Note: After “spider,” the phrase “builds its web” is understood information. It can be made clear. Alternate translation: “He builds his house as a spider builds its web”

Quote: He builds his house like a spider
Note: A spider web is fragile and easily destroyed. Alternate translation: “He builds his house as fragile as a spider builds its web” or “He builds his house as fragile as a spider’s web”

Quote: like a hut
Note: A hut is a temporary house that is also not very strong. Alternate translation: “like a temporary hut”

Quote: He lies down in bed rich
Note: “He is wealthy when he lies down in bed.” This refers to his lying down in bed at night and sleeping.

Quote: but he will not keep doing so
Note: Alternate translation: “but he will not keep lying down in bed rich” or “but he will not continue to be wealthy when he lies down in bed”

Quote: he opens his eyes
Note: Opening his eyes represents waking up in the morning. Alternate translation: “he wakes up”

Quote: everything is gone
Note: Alternate translation: “all of his riches are gone” or “everything has vanished”

Quote: Terrors overtake him
Note: Here “overtake him” represents suddenly happening to him. Possible meanings are that **terrors** is a metonym for:: (1) things that cause people to be afraid. Alternate translation: “Terrifying things suddenly happen to him” or (2) fear. Alternate translation: “He suddenly becomes terrified”

Quote: like waters
Note: The word “waters” refers to a flood. Floods can happen very suddenly when people do not expect them, and they are dangerous and frightening. Alternate translation: “like a flood” or “like waters that rise up suddenly”

Quote: a storm takes him away
Note: Alternate translation: “a violent wind blows him away”

Quote: it sweeps him out of his place
Note: Job speaks of the wind blowing the wicked man out of his house as if the wind were a person sweeping dust out of a house with a broom. Alternate translation: “the wind sweeps him out of his place like a woman who sweeps dirt out of a house” or “the wind easily blows him out of his place”

Quote: his place
Note: Alternate translation: “his home”
# General Information:\n\nIn verses 22–23 Job speaks of the wind as if it were a person attacking the wicked person.

Quote: It throws itself at him
Note: Here the phrase “throws itself at him” represents the wind blowing strong against him like an attacker. Alternate translation: “It blows strong against him like someone attacking him”

Quote: he tries to flee out of its hand
Note: Here “hand” represents the power or control that the wind has over the wicked man. Alternate translation: “he tries to flee out of its control” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: It claps its hands at him
Note: Clapping the hands is a way of mocking someone. Here it represents the wind making loud noises. Alternate translation: “It makes loud noises like someone clapping his hands to mock him” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: hisses him from his place
Note: The wind makes a noise as it blows him out of his place, and the noise is like the hissing sound that people make to mock someone. Alternate translation: “it makes a hissing noise as it causes him to leave his home” or “it blows him out of his place and makes a hissing noise like someone who hisses at him to mock him” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

# Job 28 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s response to Bildad.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s wisdom

Despite being upset about his circumstances, Job does not curse God. Instead, he recognizes Yahweh’s wisdom and authority. This chapter especially focuses on Yahweh’s wisdom as he controls the circumstances of Job’s life. Men cannot understand because they do not have Yahweh’s wisdom. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/curse]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]])

Quote: mine
Note: This is a place where people dig rocks out of the earth. These rocks have metal in them.

Quote: refine
Note: This is the process of heating a metal to remove all of the impurities that are in it.

Quote: Iron is taken out of the earth
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “People take iron out of the earth”

Quote: copper is smelted out of the stone
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people smelt copper out of the stone” or “people heat stone to melt copper out of it”

Quote: copper
Note: an important red-brown colored metal

Quote: smelted
Note: This is a process of heating rocks to melt the metal in them in order to get the metal out of the rocks.

Quote: A man sets an end to darkness
Note: Here “sets an end to darkness” represents shining a light in the darkness. People used a lantern or a torch for light. Alternate translation: “A man carries light into dark places”

Quote: to the farthest limit
Note: Alternate translation: “to the farthest parts of the mine”

Quote: obscurity … thick darkness
Note: These two phrases are used together to emphasize that the mine is extremely dark.

Quote: shaft
Note: a deep narrow hole dug into the ground or rock. People go down into the hole to mine it.

Quote: places that are forgotten by anyone’s foot
Note: The foot is spoken of as if it is a person who can remember. Alternate translation: “places where people no longer walk” or “where no one ever walks”

Quote: He hangs far away from people
Note: How and where he hangs can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Far away from people, he hangs from a rope in the shaft”

Quote: the earth, out of which comes bread
Note: Here “bread” represents food in general. Food coming out of the ground is a metaphor for food growing out of the ground. Alternate translation: “the earth, where food grows” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: it is turned up below as if by fire
Note: This could mean: (1) people made fires under the ground to break apart the rock. Alternate translation: “it is broken up below by the fires that the miners make” or (2) “turned” is a metaphor for changed. Alternate translation: “it is broken up below so much that it appears that it was destroyed by fire”

Quote: it is turned
Note: The word “it” refers to the earth.

Quote: Its stones … its dust
Note: The word “its” refers to the earth.

Quote: sapphires
Note: a rare and valuable blue gemstone

Quote: No bird of prey knows the path to it … nor has the falcon’s eye seen it
Note: These clauses express a similar meaning. Alternate translation: “No bird of prey or falcon knows or has ever seen the path that goes to the mine”

Quote: bird of prey
Note: a bird that eats other animals

Quote: falcon
Note: This may also be translated “hawk.” Both are birds that hunt and eat other animals. You may translate this with a similar bird from your culture.

Quote: The proud animals have not walked such a path … nor has the fierce lion passed there
Note: These clauses also express similar meaning.

Quote: The proud animals
Note: This refers to very strong, wild animals.

Quote: lays his hand on the flinty rock
Note: This represents breaking up the rock. Alternate translation: “digs into the flinty rock”

Quote: flinty rock
Note: Alternate translation: “hard rock”

Quote: he overturns mountains by their roots
Note: Digging up the mountains and the ground underneath them is a metaphor from digging out weeds or trees, an exaggeration that represents digging minerals out of the ground. Alternate translation: “he turns the mountains upside down by pulling out their roots” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: his eye sees
Note: Here “his eye” represents him. Alternate translation: “he sees”

Quote: He ties up the streams so they do not run
Note: Here “ties up the streams” means damming or blocking the streams. Alternate translation: “He blocks the streams so they do not flow”

Quote: what is hidden there
Note: This refers to things that people normally do not see because they are in the ground or underwater.

# General Information:\n\nIn 28:12–28, wisdom and understanding are spoken of as if they were precious objects that are in some place and people want to find them. Finding wisdom and understanding represents becoming wise and learning to understand things well.

Quote: Where will wisdom be found? Where is the place of understanding?
Note: These questions mean the same thing and are used to show that it is very difficult to find wisdom and understanding. Alternate translation: “It is very difficult to find wisdom and understanding.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Where will wisdom be found? Where is the place of understanding
Note: Becoming wise and understanding is spoken of as finding wisdom and understanding. Alternate translation: “How do people become wise? How do people learn to understand things well”

Quote: Man does not know its price
Note: This could mean: (1) wisdom is spoken of as if it were something that people can buy. Alternate translation: “People do not know what it is worth” or (2) the word translated as “price” means “place.” Alternate translation: “People do not know where it is”

Quote: neither is it found in the land of the living
Note: “and it is not found in the land of the living.” The “land of the living” refers to this world where people live. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and no one can find wisdom in this world”

Quote: The deep waters … say, ‘It is not in me’; the sea says, ‘It is not with me.’
Note: The deep waters and the sea are presented as if they are people that can speak. Alternate translation: “Wisdom is not in the deep waters under the earth, nor is it in the sea”

Quote: It cannot be gotten for gold
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This implies that wisdom is worth much more than gold. Alternate translation: “People cannot pay for wisdom with gold”

Quote: neither can silver be weighed as its price
Note: This implies that wisdom is worth much more than silver. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “and people cannot weigh out enough silver to pay for wisdom”

Quote: It cannot be valued with … sapphire
Note: This implies that wisdom is much more valuable than the gold of Ophir, precious onyx and sapphire.

Quote: Ophir
Note: This is the name of a land where there was fine gold.

Quote: onyx
Note: a valuable black gemstone

Quote: sapphire
Note: a valuable blue gemstone

Quote: Gold and crystal cannot equal it in worth
Note: This implies that wisdom is much more valuable than gold and crystal.

Quote: crystal
Note: a valuable gemstone that is clear or lightly colored

Quote: neither can it be exchanged for jewels of fine gold
Note: “and it cannot be exchanged for jewels of fine gold.” This implies that wisdom is much more valuable than jewels of fine gold.

Quote: exchanged
Note: Alternate translation: “traded”

Quote: No mention is worth making of coral or jasper
Note: “It is not worth making mention of coral and jasper.” This implies that wisdom is worth so much more than coral and jasper that there is no need for Job to say anything about them. Alternate translation: “I will not bother to mention coral or jasper” or “Coral and jasper are worthless compared to wisdom”

Quote: coral
Note: This is a beautiful, hard substance that grows on ocean reefs.

Quote: jasper … rubies
Note: These are valuable gemstones.

Quote: The topaz of Cush does not equal it
Note: This implies that wisdom is much more valuable than the finest topaz.

Quote: topaz
Note: This is a valuable gemstone.

Quote: neither can it be valued in terms of pure gold
Note: “and wisdom cannot be valued in terms of pure gold.” This implies that wisdom is much more valuable than pure gold.

Quote: From where, then, comes wisdom? Where is the place of understanding?
Note: Job uses these questions to introduce how people get wisdom and understanding. Alternate translation: “I will tell you where wisdom comes from and where understanding is.” or “I will tell you how to become wise and how to learn to understand things.”

Quote: From where, then, comes wisdom
Note: Wisdom is spoken of as if it were in a place and comes to people. Its coming represents people becoming wise.

Quote: Where is the place of understanding
Note: Understanding is spoken of as if it were in a place.

Quote: Wisdom is hidden from the eyes of all living things
Note: This means that living things are unable to see wisdom. It can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “No living thing can see wisdom” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: is kept hidden from the birds of the heavens
Note: This means that the birds are unable to see wisdom. This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “even the birds that fly in the skies cannot see wisdom”

Quote: Destruction and Death say
Note: Here “Destruction” and “Death” are spoken of as if they are living things who can speak.

Quote: God understands the way to it; he knows its place
Note: Wisdom is spoken of as if it were in a certain place. Alternate translation: “God knows how to find wisdom. He knows where it is”

Quote: the very ends of the earth
Note: Alternate translation: “the farthest places on the earth”

Quote: parceled out the waters by measure
Note: This describes God deciding how much water should be in each place. Possible meanings are that this refers to deciding: (1) how much rain should be in each cloud or (2) how much water should be in each sea. Alternate translation: “decided how much water should be in each place”

Quote: a path for the thunder
Note: Alternate translation: “he decided how the thunder can be heard” or “he decided the path of the thunderstorm”

Quote: See, the fear of the Lord—that is wisdom
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **fear**, you can express the same idea with the verbs “fear” or “respect.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **wisdom**, you can express the same idea with another word such as “wise.” Alternate translation: “Listen, if you fear the Lord, you will be wise”

Quote: to depart from evil is understanding
Note: Here “depart from evil” means refusing to do evil things. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **understanding**, you can express the same idea with the verb “understand.” Alternate translation: “if you refuse to do evil, then you will understand many things”

# Job 29 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s statement, but now it is directly addressed to Yahweh.

In this chapter, Job recalls the days before Yahweh’s blessings were taken from him. This is only one part of Job’s argument that continues for the next 3 chapters.

Quote: Oh, that I were as I was in the past months
Note: Job uses this exclamation to express a wish. Alternate translation: “I wish that I were as I was in past months”

Quote: when his lamp shined on my head
Note: God’s lamp shining on Job represents God blessing Job. Alternate translation: “when God’s blessing was like a lamp shining its light on my head”

Quote: when I walked through darkness by his light
Note: Walking through darkness represents experiencing difficult situations.

Quote: in the ripeness of my days
Note: Job speaks of when he was young and strong as if his days were the time when the harvest is ripe. Alternate translation: “when I was young and strong”

Quote: when the friendship of God was on my tent
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **friendship**, you can express the same idea with the noun “friend.” The word “tent” represents Job’s home. Alternate translation: “when God was my friend and protected my home” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: when my way was covered with cream
Note: “when my path was flowing with cream.” Job uses this exaggeration to express that he had many cows and they produced much more cream than he and his family needed. Alternate translation: “when my cows provided an abundance of cream”

Quote: and the rock poured out for me streams of oil
Note: “and the rock poured out streams of oil for me.” Job uses this exaggeration to express that he had many olive vines and great amounts of olive oil. The rock is where his servants pressed the oil out of the olives. Alternate translation: “when my servants pressed out a great amount of olive oil” or “when oil flowed like streams from the pressing rock” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: city square
Note: This is an open area in a village or city where two or more streets meet.

Quote: rose and stood for me
Note: This is a symbol of respect. It can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “rose and stood respectfully for me”

Quote: The princes used to refrain from talking when I came
Note: This was a sign of respect.

Quote: they would lay their hand on their mouths
Note: They did this to show that they would not speak. This was a sign of their respect for Job.

Quote: The voices of the noblemen were hushed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The noblemen hushed their voices” or “The noblemen stopped speaking”

Quote: their tongue clung to the roof of their mouths
Note: This represents them having so much respect for Job that they had nothing to say. Alternate translation: “they felt that they were unable to speak” or “they had nothing to say”

Quote: after their ears heard me … after their eyes saw me
Note: The ears represent those who heard him, and the eyes represent those who saw him. Alternate translation: “after they heard what I told them … after they saw me”

Quote: they would then give witness to me and approve of me
Note: Alternate translation: “they would witness approvingly of me”

Quote: I rescued the one who was poor when he cried out
Note: Here “the one who was poor” refers to any poor person. Alternate translation: “I used to rescue poor people who cried out”

Quote: The blessing of him who was about to perish came on me
Note: Someone’s blessing coming on another represents that person blessing another. Alternate translation: “He who was about to perish would bless me”

Quote: him who was about to perish
Note: This represents anyone who was about to die. Alternate translation: “those who were about to die”

Quote: I caused the widow’s heart to sing for joy
Note: Here “the widow’s heart” represents any widow. Alternate translation: “I caused widows to sing joyfully” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])

Quote: I put on righteousness, and it clothed me
Note: People often spoke of righteousness as if it were clothing. Alternate translation: “I did what was righteous, and it was like clothing that I put on”

Quote: my justice was like a robe and a turban
Note: People often spoke of justice as if it were clothing. Alternate translation: “I did what was just, and it was like a robe and a turban on me”

Quote: turban
Note: a long cloth that men wrap around their heads and wear as a hat

Quote: I was eyes to blind people
Note: This represents helping blind people. Alternate translation: “I was like eyes for blind people” or “I guided blind people”

Quote: I was feet to lame people
Note: This represents helping blind people. Alternate translation: “I was like feet for lame people” or “I supported lame people”

Quote: I was a father to needy people
Note: Here “I was a father” represents providing for people. Alternate translation: “I provided for needy people as a father provides for his children”
# General Information:\n\nIn verses 18–20 Job tells about the things he used to say before bad things happened to him.

Quote: I broke the jaws of … I plucked the victim
Note: Job speaks of unrighteous people who persecute others as if they were wild animals that attack their victims by picking them up between their teeth. Alternate translation: “I made unrighteous people stop persecuting people, like someone who breaks the jaw of a wild animal and rescues its victim from between its teeth”

Quote: I will die in my nest
Note: Here “nest” represents Job’s home and family. Job used to speak as if he were a bird that lived in a nest with his baby birds. Alternate translation: “I will die at home with my family” or “I will die in the safety of my home”

Quote: I will multiply my days like the grains of sand
Note: There are more grains of sand on the shore than anyone can count. To say that he would live more days than anyone could count is an exaggeration to express that he would live a very long time. Alternate translation: “I will live a very long time” or “I will live many years” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: My roots … my branches
Note: Job used to speak of his strength as if he were strong like a well-watered tree.

Quote: The honor in me is always fresh
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **honor**, you can express the same idea with the verb “honor.” Here “fresh” represents the honor being constantly given. Alternate translation: “People constantly give me honor” or “People always honor me”

Quote: the bow of my strength is always new in my hand
Note: A new bow is very strong. Job’s bow of strength in his hand represents his physical strength. Alternate translation: “I am always strong like a new bow”

Quote: my speech dropped like water on them
Note: Here “dropped like water on them” represents refreshing the people who heard him. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **speech**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “speak” or “say.” Alternate translation: “my speech refreshed their hearts as drops of water refresh people’s bodies” or “what I said to them refreshed them like drops of water” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: They always waited for me as they waited for rain
Note: People waited for Job patiently and expected to hear good things.

Quote: they opened their mouth wide to drink in my words
Note: This represents waiting eagerly for Job to speak in order to benefit from what said. Alternate translation: “they eagerly waited for me to speak in order to benefit from what I said”

Quote: as they would do for the latter rain
Note: Alternate translation: “as farmers wait eagerly for the latter rain”

Quote: the latter rain
Note: This refers to the large amount of rain that falls just before the dry season.

Quote: I smiled on them
Note: It can be stated clearly that the purpose of smiling was to encourage them. Alternate translation: “I smiled on them to encourage them”

Quote: the light of my face
Note: This represents the kindness they saw in Job’s face.

Quote: I selected their way
Note: Here “selected their way” represents deciding what they should do.

Quote: sat as their chief
Note: Here “sat” represents ruling or leading. Chiefs sat down when they made important decisions. Alternate translation: “led them as their chief”

Quote: sat as their chief
Note: Job was their chief. Alternate translation: “led them because I was their chief”

Quote: I lived like a king in his army
Note: Job speaks of how he led the people and how they obeyed him as if he were a king and they were his army.

Quote: like one who comforts mourners
Note: This phrase means that Job actually was one who comforted people. Alternate translation: “I comforted them when they mourned”

# Job 30 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s statement, but now it is directly addressed to Yahweh.

In this chapter, Job laments his current condition as others insult him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/lament]])

Quote: whose fathers I would have refused to allow to work beside the dogs of my flock
Note: This shows how much he despised those fathers. They were not even good enough to be with his dogs. Alternate translation: “whose fathers I despised and would not have allowed to work beside the dogs of my flock”

Quote: the dogs of my flock
Note: The dogs’ relationship to the flock can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “the dogs that guarded my flock”

Quote: Indeed, the strength of their fathers’ hands, how could it have helped me … perished?
Note: Job uses this question to mock the weakness of those men. Alternate translation: “The strength of their fathers’ hands could not have helped me … perished.”

Quote: men in whom the strength of their mature age had perished
Note: Their strength perishing is a metaphor that represents no longer being strong but weak. The phrase “mature age” refers to them being old. Alternate translation: “men who had become old and had no strength” or “men who had become old and weak”

Quote: They were thin from poverty and hunger
Note: The word “They” refers to the fathers of the young mockers.

Quote: They were thin from poverty and hunger
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **poverty**, you can express the same idea with another word such as “poor.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **hunger**, you can express the same idea with the words “hungry” or “starving.” Alternate translation: “They were very thin because they were poor and starving”

Quote: they gnawed at the dry ground
Note: This could mean: (1) “dry ground” is a metonym for the dry roots that grow in the ground. Alternate translation: “they chewed on the dry roots they found in the ground” or (2) “gnawed at the dried ground” is a metonym for eating whatever they could find in the dry ground.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to talk about the fathers of the mockers.

Quote: saltwort … bushes’ leaves … the roots of the broom tree
Note: These are plants that people would eat only if they could find nothing better.

Quote: the roots of the broom tree were their food
Note: This could mean: (1) the people ate the roots of the broom tree or (2) the people warmed themselves by burning the roots of broom trees.

Quote: They were driven out from among people who shouted after them as … a thief
Note: The phrase “were driven out” means “were forced to leave.” These phrases can be reordered and stated in active form. Alternate translation: “The people shouted after them as … a thief and forced them to leave”

Quote: shouted after them as one would shout after a thief
Note: Alternate translation: “shouted at them as though they were thieves”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to talk about the fathers of the mockers.

Quote: brayed like donkeys
Note: Job speaks of the men crying out in hunger as if they were wild donkeys making a loud noise. Alternate translation: “cried out like wild donkeys because they were hungry”

Quote: they gathered together under the nettles
Note: “Nettles” are bushes with sharp thorns. This implies that they did not have a home.

Quote: They were the sons of fools
Note: Here “were the sons of fools” represents having the characteristics fools. Alternate translation: “They were like fools” or “they were fools”

Quote: indeed, sons of nameless people
Note: The word “indeed” shows that what follows strengthens the previous thought. Here “sons of nameless people” represents having the characteristics of nameless people. Alternate translation: “indeed, they were nameless people” or “indeed, they were worthless”

Quote: nameless people
Note: Here being “nameless” represents having no honor or respect. It means that they are worthless. Alternate translation: “worthless people”

Quote: They were driven out of the land with whips
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This could mean: (1) the idea of whips implies that they were being treated like criminals. Alternate translation: “People treated them like criminals and forced them to leave the land” or (2) people actually used whips to force them out. Alternate translation: “People whipped them and forced them to leave the land”

Quote: They were driven out of the land
Note: Here “the land” refers to the land where they lived before they were forced to go out to the wilderness.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob speaks again about the people who were mocking him.

Quote: But now I have become the subject of their taunting song
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **song**, you can express the same idea with the verb “sing.” Alternate translation: “But now they sing songs about me to taunt me”

Quote: I have become a byword for them
Note: Here “byword” is a metonym for the person about whom people make cruel jokes. Alternate translation: “I am now one whom they make cruel jokes about” or “They joke and say cruel things about me”

Quote: they do not refrain from spitting in my face
Note: This can be stated positively. Alternate translation: “they even spit in my face”

Quote: God has unstrung the string to my bow
Note: A bow that is unstrung is not useful. The phrase “has unstrung the string of my bow” is a metaphor for making Job powerless. Alternate translation: “God has taken away my power to defend myself”

Quote: those who taunt me
Note: Alternate translation: “those who mock me”

Quote: cast off restraint before my face
Note: A restraint keeps a person from moving freely and doing what he wants. Here “restraint” represents refraining from doing something, and “cast off restraint” represents not refraining from doing something. In this case the mockers did not refrain from being cruel to Job. Alternate translation: “do not refrain from being cruel to me” or “do whatever cruel things they want to do to me” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
# General Information:\n\nJob speaks about the mockers treating him cruelly as if they were a mob and an army attacking him.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to speak about the people who were mocking him.

Quote: Upon my right hand rise the rabble
Note: “the rabble rise upon my right hand.” This could mean: (1) rising upon Job’s right hand represents attacking his strength. Alternate translation: “Gangs of young people attack my strength” or (2) rising upon Job’s right hand represents attacking his honor. Alternate translation: “Mobs attack my honor” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: they drive me away
Note: Alternate translation: “they force me to run away”

Quote: pile up against me their siege mounds
Note: Armies would pile up mounds of dirt along a city’s wall in order to climb over the wall and attack the city. Job speaks of the mockers preparing to attack him as if they were doing that. Alternate translation: “prepare to attack me like an army that prepares to attack a city”

Quote: They destroy my path
Note: This represents keeping Job from escaping their attack. Alternate translation: “They prevent me from escaping from them”

Quote: they push forward disaster for me
Note: Here “push forward disaster” represents trying to make disaster happen. Alternate translation: “they try to make disaster happen to me” or “they try to destroy me”

Quote: men who have no one to hold them back
Note: Here “hold them back” represents stopping them from doing something. Alternate translation: “men who have no one to stop them from attacking me”
# General Information:\n\nJob speaks about the mockers treating him cruelly as if they were an army attacking him.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues to speak about the people who were mocking him.

Quote: They come against me like an army through a wide hole in a city wall
Note: This represents attacking Job forcefully.

Quote: they roll themselves in on me
Note: This represents many coming to attack him at once, like giant ocean waves rolling in on him.

Quote: Terrors are turned upon me
Note: This could mean: (1) Job has become terrified or (2) things are happening to Job that make him afraid.

Quote: my honor is driven away as if by the wind
Note: Job speaks of suddenly having no honor as if the wind had blown it from him. Alternate translation: “Nobody honors me” or “I am now a person that people do not honor”

Quote: my prosperity passes away as a cloud
Note: Job speaks of his prosperity ending as if it were a cloud that was blown away. Here “prosperity” may refer to well-being or safety. Alternate translation: “I no longer prosper at all” or “I am no longer safe”

Quote: Now my life is pouring out from within me
Note: Job speaks as if his life were a liquid and his body were a container. He feels he is about to die. Alternate translation: “Now I am dying”

Quote: many days of suffering have laid hold on me
Note: Job speaks of his continuous suffering as if the days of suffering have grabbed hold of him. Alternate translation: “I suffer many days, and the suffering does not end”

Quote: my bones in me are pierced
Note: Job speaks of the pain in his bones as if his bones were being pierced. Alternate translation: “my bones ache terribly” or “I have sharp pain in my bones”

Quote: the pains that gnaw at me take no rest
Note: Job speaks of his constant pain as if it were alive and biting him and refuses to rest. Alternate translation: “the pains that cause me to suffer do not stop” or “I am in constant pain”

Quote: God’s great force has seized my clothing
Note: Job speaks of God using his force as if God’s force were actually doing something. Here “God’s … force” stands for “God.” Alternate translation: “God has seized my clothing by his great force”

Quote: God’s great force has seized my clothing
Note: The image of God’s force seizing Job is a metaphor. This could mean: (1) it represents Job’s pain. Alternate translation: “My pain feels like God has grabbed my clothing tightly” or (2) it represents God’s causing Job’s many problems. Alternate translation: “It is as though by his great force God has grabbed me by my clothes”

Quote: it wraps around me like the collar of my tunic
Note: The image of God’s force wrapping around Job is a metaphor. This could mean: (1) it represents Job’s pain. Alternate translation: “he wraps the collar of my tunic tightly around me” or (2) it represents God’s causing Job’s many problems. Alternate translation: “It is as though he grabs me by the collar of my tunic”

Quote: He has thrown me into the mud
Note: Job says that God has humiliated him. Alternate translation: “It is as though he has thrown me in the mud” or “He has humiliated me, like a person thrown in the mud”

Quote: I have become like dust and ashes
Note: This represents Job’s feeling of being worthless. Alternate translation: “I have become as worthless as dust and ashes”

Quote: cruel
Note: This word means unkind.

Quote: with the strength of your hand you persecute me
Note: The word “hand” represents God’s power. Alternate translation: “you persecute me with your power”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to God.

Quote: lift me up to the wind … throw me back and forth in a storm
Note: These expressions represent the extreme suffering that God made Job endure.

Quote: cause it to drive me along
Note: Alternate translation: “cause the wind to push me along”

Quote: you will bring me to death
Note: Here “bring me to death” represents causing Job to die. Alternate translation: “you will cause me to die”

Quote: the house appointed for all the living
Note: Job speaks of the world of the dead as if it were a house to which God has appointed all living things to go. Alternate translation: “the world of the dead, to which everything that has ever lived goes”

Quote: all the living
Note: That is, all things now alive, but that will die one day.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nJob continues speaking to God.

Quote: does no one reach out with his hand to beg for help when he falls? Does no one in trouble call out for help?
Note: Job uses these questions to justify himself for crying out to God for help. Alternate translation: “Everyone reaches out with his hand to beg for help when he falls. Everyone who is in trouble calls out for help.” or “I have fallen, and so God should not think I am doing wrong when I beg for his help. I am in trouble, so of course I call out for help!”

Quote: does no one reach out with his hand to beg for help when he falls? Does no one in trouble call out for help?
Note: Some versions interpret these questions as Job complaining that God has reached out with his hand to harm Job when Job was in trouble and crying out for help. Alternate translation: “Surely no one would reach out with his hand against someone who falls and calls out for help.”

Quote: Did not I weep … trouble? Did I not grieve … man?
Note: Job uses these questions to remind God of how Job had done good to others. A: “You know that I wept … trouble, and I grieved … man!”

Quote: When I hoped for good, then evil came
Note: Looking for good represents hoping for good things, and evil coming represents evil things happening.

Quote: I waited for light … darkness came
Note: Here “light” represents God’s blessing and favor and “darkness” represents trouble and suffering. Alternate translation: “I waited for the light of God’s blessing, but instead I experienced the darkness of suffering”

Quote: My heart is troubled and does not rest
Note: Job speaks of his heart as if it were a person. Alternate translation: “I am troubled in my heart and the feeling does not end”

Quote: days of affliction have come on me
Note: Days of affliction coming on Job represents Job experiencing affliction for many days. Alternate translation: “I experience affliction many days” or “I suffer every day”

Quote: I have gone about
Note: Here “have gone about” represents living. Alternate translation: “I have lived” or “I live”

Quote: like one who was living in the dark, but not because of the sun
Note: Here “living in the dark” is a metaphor that represents being extremely sad. The phrase “but not because of the sun” clarifies that “living in the dark” is a metaphor, that is, the darkness is not caused by the sun being hidden. Alternate translation: “like one who is terribly sad”

Quote: a brother to jackals, a companion of ostriches
Note: Being a brother to these animals is a metaphor for being like them. Alternate translation: “I am like jackals and ostriches that cry out in the wilderness”

Quote: my bones are burned with heat
Note: Here “bones” refers to the whole body, which suffers from fever.

Quote: my harp is tuned for songs of mourning
Note: Here “my harp” represents Job himself, and also represents his desire to sing only songs of mourning. Alternate translation: “I play only songs of mourning on my harp”

Quote: my flute for the singing of those who wail
Note: Here “my flute” represents Job himself, and also his desire to sing only songs of crying. Alternate translation: “I play only songs of wailing on my flute”

Quote: wail
Note: To wail is to cry very loudly because of terrible sadness or pain.

# Job 31 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This chapter is a continuation of Job’s statement and it is directly addressed to Yahweh.

In this chapter, Job presents his case to Yahweh that he is upright and not guilty of the sins he is being accused of. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/guilt]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

Quote: I have made a covenant with my eyes
Note: Job speaks of making a promise about what he would look at as though his eyes were a person and he made a covenant with them. Alternate translation: “I have made a firm promise about what I will look at” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: I have made a covenant with my eyes
Note: What job promised can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “I made a promise that I will not look lustfully on a virgin” or “I promised that I will not look lustfully on a virgin”

Quote: how then should I look with desire on a virgin?
Note: Job uses this question to emphasize that he would never break his promise. Alternate translation: “So I certainly will not look with lust at a virgin.”

Quote: For what is the portion from God above, the inheritance from the Almighty on high?
Note: Job speaks of God’s response to people’s behavior as if it were the portion of an inheritance that God gives. Alternate translation: “For how will God above respond to me? What will the Almighty on high do?” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: For what is the portion from God above, the inheritance from the Almighty on high?
Note: Possible meanings are Job uses this question to emphasize: (1) that God will not bless bad behavior. Alternate translation: “For if I look lustfully on a woman, God Almighty on high will not bless me.” or (2) that God will punish bad behavior. Alternate translation: “For if I look lustfully on a woman, God Almighty on high will certainly punish me.”

Quote: Does not God see my ways and count all my steps?
Note: Here “my ways” and “my steps” are metaphors for Job’s behavior. Here “see my ways” and “count all my steps” are metaphors for knowing everything Job does. Job uses this question to emphasize that God does know all he does. Alternate translation: “Certainly God watches me and knows everything that I do.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Does not God see my ways and count all my steps?
Note: Job may be implying that God should know that Job is righteous and does not deserve calamity and disaster.

Quote: If I have
Note: In 31:5–40 Job describes different situations in which he would deserve God’s punishment. But, he knows that they are not true and he is innocent.

Quote: walked with falsehood, if my foot has hurried to deceit
