Note: Here “walked” and “hurried” are metaphors that represent how Job lived. Alternate translation: “done anything false or purposely deceived anyone”

Quote: let me be weighed in an even balance
Note: People used balances to weigh items and to determine their value. This image represents judging honestly. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “let me be judged honestly” or “let God judge me honestly” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: If my step has turned aside from the way
Note: Here “my step” is a metaphor for Job’s behavior, and “turned out of the right way” is a metaphor for changing from living right. Alternate translation: “If I have changed from living right” or “If I have stopped doing what is right”

Quote: if my heart has gone after my eyes
Note: Here “my heart” and “my eyes” are metonyms for what Job desires and sees. The heart going after the eyes is a metaphor for desiring to do what he sees. It is implied that this refers to sinful things that Job sees. Alternate translation: “if I have wanted to do any sinful things that I see” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: if any spot has stuck to my hands
Note: This is a metaphor for being guilty. Alternate translation: “if I am guilty of any sin at all”

Quote: then let me sow, and let another eat, and let my crops be uprooted
Note: Job is saying that if he really has sinned, then this bad thing should happen to him. He would do the hard work of sowing his fields, but he would not be able to eat any of it.

Quote: let my crops be uprooted
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “let someone else come and take the harvest from my field”

Quote: If my heart has been deceived by a woman
Note: Here “my heart” represents Job. Here the word “deceived” expresses the idea of “enticed.” The word “woman” expresses the idea of “another man’s wife.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “If another man’s wife has enticed me” or “If I have desired another man’s wife” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: if I have lain in wait at my neighbor’s door
Note: It can be stated clearly why he was waiting at his neighbor’s door. Alternate translation: “if I have waited at my neighbor’s door so I could sleep with his wife”

Quote: then let my wife grind grain for another
Note: This could mean: (1) this is an euphemism which means Job is saying may his wife sleep with another man or (2) it means she will become a slave and work for another man.

Quote: For that would be a terrible crime
Note: The word “that” refers to Job sleeping with another woman.

Quote: it would be a crime to be punished by judges
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “it would be a crime for which judges would be right to punish me”

Quote: For that is a fire that consumes as far as Abaddon, and it would burn all my harvest to the root
Note: Job speaks of the harm that sleeping with another woman causes as if it were a fire that destroys everything. The words “that” and “it” refer to sleeping with another man’s wife. Alternate translation: “For adultery is like a fire that burns up everything from here to Abaddon and that would burn up all my harvest”

Quote: consumes as far as Abaddon
Note: These words are probably a metaphor for “destroys everything so I have nothing good for the rest of my life,” but you should probably translate this literally.

Quote: it would burn all my harvest to the root
Note: The word “it” here refers to the action sleeping with another man’s wife. This action is a metonym for the punishment that Job would suffer as a result of the action. A fire burning up his harvest is a synecdoche for losing everything he has worked for. Alternate translation: “those who punish me would take away everything I have worked for” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: what then would I do when God rises up to accuse me? When he comes to judge me, how would I answer him?
Note: Job uses these questions to emphasize that if God were to judge him, Job would not be able to make himself appear to be good. Alternate translation: “then there would be absolutely nothing I could say to defend myself when God comes to judge me.”

Quote: Did the one who made me in the womb not make them also? Did not the same one mold us all in the womb?
Note: Job uses these questions to emphasize that he is no different from his servants. He implies that God would be angry if Job were to treat his servants as less valuable than himself. Alternate translation: “The one who made me in the womb also made them. He formed us all in the womb.”

Quote: If I have withheld poor people from their desire
Note: Alternate translation: “If I have kept poor people from getting what they desire”

Quote: if I have caused the eyes of the widow to grow dim from crying
Note: Here “to grow dim” refers to the widow having bad eyesight from crying a lot. Alternate translation: “if I have caused a widow to cry in great sadness”

Quote: my morsel
Note: Alternate translation: “my food”

Quote: because from my youth the orphan grew up with me as with a father
Note: Here “the orphan” represents orphans in general. Job is describing how he truly treated orphans. Alternate translation: “because even when I was young I took care of orphans like a father”

Quote: because from my youth
Note: The phrase “But I have done none of those things” is understood from the context. Alternate translation: “But I have done none of those things, because from my youth”

Quote: I have guided his mother, a widow, from my own mother’s womb
Note: Job is describing how he truly treated widows. With the phrase “from my own mother’s womb” he uses exaggeration to emphasize that he did this all his life. Alternate translation: “all my life I have guided the orphan’s mother, a widow” or “all my life I have guided widows”

Quote: if his heart has not blessed me
Note: The phrase “his heart” represents the poor man who needs clothing. Alternate translation: “if he has not blessed me”

Quote: because he has not been warmed with the wool of my sheep
Note: Here “the wool of my sheep” represents blankets or clothing made from the wool of Job’s sheep. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “because the wool of my sheep has not warmed him” or “because I have not given him clothing made from the wool of my sheep” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: if I have lifted up my hand against fatherless people
Note: Lifting up the hand against someone represents threatening to harm him. Alternate translation: “if I have threatened to harm fatherless people”

Quote: I saw my support in the city gate
Note: Here “saw” is a metaphor for “knew,” “support” is a metaphor for “approval,” and “the city gate” is a metonym for the leaders who sit at the city gate. Alternate translation: “I knew that the leaders at the city gate would approve of me” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: in the city gate
Note: This is where the important men of the city would gather to make decisions.

Quote: then bring charges against me
Note: This phrase is not in the original language or in other versions of the Bible. It was added here to help preserve the meaning of Job’s statement in this long sentence.

Quote: then let my shoulder fall from the shoulder blade, and let my arm be broken from its joint
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “then let someone tear off my shoulder from the shoulder blade and break my arm from its joint”

Quote: For I dreaded … his majesty
Note: This is the reason that Job did not do any of the wicked things he spoke of in verses 7 through 21.

Quote: If I have made gold my hope
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **hope**, you can express the same idea with the verbs “trust” or “hope.” Alternate translation: “If I trusted in gold” or “If I hoped that having a lot of gold would make me secure”

Quote: if I have said to fine gold, ‘You are what I am confident in’
Note: This line means the same as the previous line.

Quote: my hand had gotten many possessions
Note: Here “my hand” represents Job’s ability to do things. Alternate translation: “I have gained many possessions by my own ability”

Quote: then bring charges against me
Note: This phrase is not in the original language or in other versions of the Bible. It was added here to help preserve the meaning of Job’s statement in this long sentence.

Quote: the moon walking
Note: Here “walking” represents moving slowly. Alternate translation: “the moon moving across the sky”

Quote: the moon walking in its brightness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **brightness**, you can express the same idea with the words “bright” or “brightly.” Alternate translation: “the bright moon moving across the sky” or “the moon moving brightly across the sky”

Quote: if my heart has been secretly attracted
Note: Here “my heart” represents Job. This phrase can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “if I have been secretly attracted to them” or “if I have secretly desired to worship them” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: so that my mouth has kissed my hand
Note: Here “my mouth” represents Job. This is a sign of love and devotion. Alternate translation: “so that I have kissed my hand”

Quote: to be punished by judges
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “for which judges would be right to punish me”

Quote: I would have denied the God who is above
Note: Alternate translation: “I would have been unfaithful to the God who is above”

Quote: at the destruction of anyone who hated me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **destruction**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “destroy.” Alternate translation: “when anyone who hated me was destroyed” or “when bad things happened to anyone who hated me”

Quote: when disaster overtook him
Note: Alternate translation: “when he experienced disasters”

Quote: then bring charges against me
Note: This phrase is not in the original language or in other versions of the Bible. It was added here to help preserve the meaning of Job’s statement in this long sentence.

Quote: Indeed, I have not even allowed my mouth to sin
Note: Here “my mouth” represents Job speaking. Alternate translation: “Truly I did not let myself sin” or “Truly, I did not sin”

Quote: by asking for his life with a curse
Note: Here “asking for his life with a curse” represents cursing someone’s life so that he will die. Alternate translation: “by cursing him so that he would die” or “by cursing his life”

Quote: the men of my tent
Note: The tent represents Job’s household. The men of his tent includes family members and servants. All of these knew Job well. Alternate translation: “the men of my household” or “my family members and servants”

Quote: Who can find one who has not been filled with Job’s food?
Note: Job’s men would have used this question to emphasize that Job was generous to everyone. Alternate translation: “Everyone has been filled with Job’s food!” or “Everyone we know of has eaten as much of Job’s food as he wanted!”

Quote: even the foreigner has never had to stay in the city square
Note: Job is explaining how he truly treated foreigners. Here “stay in the city square” represents sleeping overnight in the city square. Alternate translation: “foreigners have never had to sleep in the city square” or “foreigners have never had to sleep outside”

Quote: I have always opened my doors to the traveler
Note: Here “opened my doors to the traveler” represents welcoming the traveler into his home. Alternate translation: “I have always welcomed the traveler into my home”

Quote: and if that is not so, then bring charges against me
Note: This phrase is not in the original language or in other versions of the Bible. It was added here to help preserve the meaning of Job’s statement in this long sentence.

Quote: If … I have hidden my sins
Note: Here “have hidden my sins” represents trying to keep people from knowing that he had sinned. Alternate translation: “If … I have tried to keep my sins a secret”

Quote: by hiding my guilt inside my tunic
Note: This represents trying to keep people from knowing that he is guilty. Alternate translation: “by hiding the evidence of my guilt inside my tunic” or “like one who hides the evidence of his guilt inside his tunic”

Quote: because I feared the great multitude, because the contempt of families terrified me
Note: This would be the reason for hiding his sins. These mean the same thing. They emphasize that a person may hide his sin because he fears what other people may think about him.

Quote: then bring charges against me
Note: This phrase is not in the original language or in other versions of the Bible. It was added here to help preserve the meaning of Job’s statement in this long sentence.

Quote: Oh, if only I had someone to hear me!
Note: This exclamation expresses Job’s wish. Alternate translation: “I wish I had someone to hear me” or “I wish that someone would listen to me”

Quote: here is my signature
Note: Here “my signature” represents Job’s promise that everything he is saying is true. He speaks of his complaint as if he had written a legal document. Alternate translation: “I solemnly promise that all I have said is true”

Quote: let the Almighty answer me!
Note: Here an answer probably refers to telling Job what wrong he accuses Job of doing. Alternate translation: “let the Almighty tell me what I have done wrong” or “I wish the Almighty would say what I have done wrong”

Quote: If only I had the indictment that my opponent has written!
Note: This expresses Job’s wish. Job speaks as though his troubles are evidence that someone has written something accusing him of terrible sin. Alternate translation: “I wish I had the accusation that my opponent has written” or “If only I could read my opponent’s complaint against me”

Quote: my opponent
Note: This could mean: (1) this refers to God or (2) this refers to someone else.

Quote: Surely I would carry it openly on my shoulder; I would put it on like a crown
Note: This represents putting it where everyone could read it.

Quote: I would declare to him an accounting for my steps
Note: Here “my steps” represents Job’s actions. Alternate translation: “I would declare to him an accounting for all I have done” or “I would tell him everything I have done”

Quote: as a confident prince I would go up to him
Note: This means Job would approach God without any fear. Job implies that he could do this because he was not guilty. Alternate translation: “I would approach him boldly”
# General Information:\n\nThis concludes Job’s description of situations in which he would deserve God’s punishment, but he knows they are not true.

Quote: If my land ever cries out against me, and its furrows weep together
Note: Job speaks of being guilty as if his land were a person who cries out against Job because of the wrong Job has done to the land. Alternate translation: “If I have done wrong concerning my land” or “If I have stolen my land from someone”

Quote: to lose their lives
Note: This represents dying. Alternate translation: “to die”

Quote: weeds instead of barley
Note: The words “let” and “grow” are understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “let weeds grow instead of barley”

# Job 32 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Job’s friends give up on trying to convince him that he is being punished for sinning. This chapter introduces Elihu who was a witness to these interactions between Job and his friends. According to Elihu, instead of being punished for his sins, Job is sinning in the midst of these difficulties. This is the first of Elihu’s four statements. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/testimony]])

Some translations prefer to set apart extended quotations, prayers, or songs. The ULT and many other English translations set the lines of 32:6–22, which is an extended quotation, farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text. This quotation continues through the next chapter.

Quote: he was righteous in his own eyes
Note: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “he considered himself righteous”

Quote: Then was kindled the anger of Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram; it was kindled against Job
Note: This compares Elihu’s anger to someone starting a fire. Also, If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Then Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry with Job” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Elihu … Barakel … Ram
Note: These are names of men.

Quote: Buzite
Note: This is the name of a people-group.

Quote: he justified himself rather than God
Note: This means that he considered himself innocent and believed God had been wrong to punish him. Alternate translation: “he justified himself and claimed that God had been wrong to punish him”

Quote: Elihu’s anger was also kindled against his three friends
Note: This compares Elihu’s anger to someone starting a fire. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Elihu also became very angry with his three friends” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Now
Note: This word is used here to mark a break in the main story line. This tells background information about Elihu.

Quote: that there was no answer in the mouths of these three men
Note: This means that the men were done speaking to Job. This speaks of the men possibly having an answer as if the answer were an object that would be in their mouths. Alternate translation: “that these three men had nothing else to say” or “that these three men had no more answers to give Job”

Quote: his anger was kindled
Note: This compares Elihu’s anger to someone starting a fire. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he became very angry” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: you are very old
Note: Here “you” is plural and refers to Job and his three friends.

Quote: Length of days should speak; a multitude of years should teach wisdom
Note: These two lines mean the same thing. Elihu emphasizes that since older people are wiser than younger people, they should be the first to speak of what they know. Alternate translation: “He who has lived many years should speak; He would is older should teach wisdom” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: there is a spirit in a man; the breath of the Almighty
Note: Both phrases mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that a man’s wisdom comes from God. Alternate translation: “there is a spirit in a man, that is, the breath of the Almighty that”

Quote: the breath of the Almighty
Note: Here the spirit is represented by “breath.” Alternate translation: “the spirit of the Almighty”

Quote: See
Note: Elihu uses this word here to draw the mens’ attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: I waited for your words
Note: “I waited to hear what you would say.” The word “your” refers to Job’s friends.

Quote: who could respond to his words
Note: Here the word “respond” does not just mean to answer, but to answer with a helpful response.

Quote: We have found wisdom
Note: This means that they believe that they have figured out what is wise. Alternate translation: “We have discovered what is wise”

Quote: to defeat Job
Note: This speaks of God responding to Job and correcting him as if he were defeating him in battle. Alternate translation: “to refute Job” or “to answer Job”

Quote: with your words
Note: Alternate translation: “by saying what you have said”

Quote: dumbfounded
Note: amazed, unable to speak

Quote: Should I wait because they are not speaking, because they stand there silent and answer no more?
Note: Elihu uses a question to emphasize that he will not wait any longer to speak. Elihu answers this question himself in the next verse. Alternate translation: But because you do not speak, I certainly will not wait any longer; you merely stand there and do not reply anymore.

Quote: I also will answer on my part
Note: Alternate translation: “I will now take my turn to answer”

Quote: I am full of words
Note: Elihu speaks of having a lot to say as being full of words. Alternate translation: “I have so much to say”

Quote: the spirit in me compels me
Note: Alternate translation: “my spirit forces me to say it”

Quote: my breast is like fermenting wine that has no vent; like new wineskins, it is ready to burst
Note: While wine is fermenting, gas collects in the container. If the gas is not let out the container will burst. Elihu means that he has so much to say that if he does not speak he feels like he will burst. Also, these two phrases are parallel and have the same meaning. Alternate translation: “I feel like my breast is about to burst, like a container of fermenting wine that has no vent” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: my breast is
Note: This represents Elihu, specifically his spirit. Alternate translation: “my spirit is” or “I am”

Quote: I may be refreshed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I may feel better”

Quote: open my lips
Note: Here the “lips” represent the mouth. Alternate translation: “open my mouth”

Quote: neither will I give honorific titles to any man
Note: Alternate translation: “neither will I praise any man or give him titles of honor”

Quote: my Maker
Note: This is a name referring to God. Alternate translation: “God who made me”

Quote: take me away
Note: This means that he would destroy him. Alternate translation: “destroy me”

# Job 33 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

According to Elihu, instead of being punished for his sins, Job is sinning in the midst of these difficulties. This is a continuation of the first of Elihu’s four statements and it is addressed to Job. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/testimony]])

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. This quotation is a continuation of the previous chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### God’s mercy
While Job has been complaining about the lack of justice and response from Yahweh, Elihu shows Job that Yahweh has shown him great mercy along the way. He is still alive because of Yahweh’s mercy. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/mercy]])

Quote: hear my speech; listen to all my words
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that Job must listen carefully.

Quote: I have opened my mouth … my tongue has spoken in my mouth
Note: These mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that he is now ready to speak. His “tongue” speaking represents himself speaking. Alternate translation: “I have opened my mouth and I have begun to speak” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: My words come from the uprightness of my heart
Note: Here Elihu refers to himself by his “heart” as he speaks of being upright. Alternate translation: “I will speak with uprightness” or “I will speak with complete honesty”

Quote: my lips speak pure knowledge
Note: Here Elihu refers to himself by his “lips” to emphasize his speech. Alternate translation: “I will speak sincerely to you the things I know”

Quote: The Spirit of God … has given me life
Note: These two lines mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that God has made him and so gives authority to what he is saying.

Quote: set your words in order before me and stand up
Note: This speaks of Job preparing what he will say as if he were setting up and organizing physical objects. Alternate translation: “prepare what you will say, and stand up and answer me”

Quote: See
Note: Elihu uses this word here to draw Job’s attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: I am just as you are in God’s sight
Note: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “I am just as you are in God’s judgment” or “God judges me the same way that he judges you”

Quote: I also have been formed out of the clay
Note: Though people are not made out of clay, God has made everyone as a potter carefully makes things out of clay. Alternate translation: “God has made both of us just as a potter forms things from clay”

Quote: I also have been formed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God has also made me” or “God has formed both of us”

Quote: terror of me will not make you afraid
Note: Alternate translation: “you do not need to be afraid of me”

Quote: neither will my pressure be heavy upon you
Note: This means that he will not hinder Job or burden him. He speaks of emotional burden here as if it were a heavy physical burden. Alternate translation: “neither will I burden you” or “I will not oppress you with what I say”

Quote: in my hearing
Note: Alternate translation: “where I could hear you”

Quote: I have heard the sound of your words saying
Note: Alternate translation: “I have heard you say”

Quote: clean
Note: A person who God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if the person were physically clean.

Quote: there is no sin in me
Note: Alternate translation: “I have not sinned”

Quote: See
Note: The speaker uses this word here to draw attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: He puts my feet in stocks
Note: “Stocks” are wooden blocks a jailer puts around a prisoner’s feet to restrict his movement. Job speaks of feeling like he is a prisoner by saying that he is in stocks. Alternate translation: “I feel he has made me a prisoner”

Quote: my paths
Note: These words refer to where he goes. Here where he goes represents what he does. Alternate translation: “everything that I do”

Quote: I will answer you
Note: Elihu is speaking to Job.

Quote: Why do you struggle against him?
Note: Elihu uses this question to emphasize that Job should not struggle against God. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You should not struggle against God.” or “You should not try to argue with God.”

Quote: He does not account for any of his doings
Note: Alternate translation: “He does not have to explain to us anything he does”

Quote: God speaks once—yes, twice
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “God speaks again and again in different ways”

Quote: a dream … a vision of the night
Note: These phrases have the same meaning.

Quote: when deep sleep falls upon men, in slumber on the bed
Note: This speaks of people being in a deep sleep as if the sleep fell upon them or overcame them. Alternate translation: “when people are fully asleep on their bed”

Quote: then God opens the ears of men
Note: This speaks of God making people aware of things as if he were opening their ears so that they could hear. Alternate translation: “then God reveals things to people”

Quote: in order to pull man back from
Note: This speaks of God keeping someone from doing something as if he were physically pulling him away from harm. Alternate translation: “in order to keep him from”

Quote: God keeps man’s life back from the pit … his life from crossing over to death
Note: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “God saves people from the grave and from death”

Quote: the pit
Note: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as “the pit.” Alternate translation: “the place where dead people are”

Quote: man’s life back … his life
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “man from dying and … he keeps him”

Quote: from crossing over to death
Note: Here “death” represents the place where people go when they die, that is, sheol. Alternate translation: “from going to sheol”

Quote: Man is punished also
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God also punishes a person”

Quote: with pain on his bed
Note: This means that the person is experiencing such pain that he must lie in bed. Alternate translation: “with pain so that he must lie in bed”

Quote: so that his life abhors food, and his soul abhors delicacies
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing, that the person is in so much pain that he cannot even eat. The person is represented by his “life” and his “soul.” Alternate translation: “the result is that he does not desire any food, not even very special food” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: abhors delicacies
Note: Alternate translation: “hates even very special food”

Quote: His flesh is consumed away so that it cannot be seen; his bones, once not seen, now stick out
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. “His flesh” refers to his fat and muscles, not to his body’s outer skin. Alternate translation: “Disease makes his body weak and thin so that a person can see his bones”

Quote: his soul draws close to the pit
Note: Here a person is represented by his “soul.” Alternate translation: “he is close to going into the grave”

Quote: the pit
Note: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as “the pit.” Alternate translation: “the place where dead people are”

Quote: his life to those who wish to destroy it
Note: Here the person is represented by his “life.” The phrase “those who wish to destroy it” refers to the place where people go after they die. Alternate translation: “and he is close to going to the place where dead people go” or “and he will soon go to the place of the dead” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: for him
Note: This does not refer to a specific person. Elihu continues speaking about any person in general.

Quote: one out of a thousand
Note: In some languages it may be more natural to refer to “a great number” instead of “a thousand.” Alternate translation: “one from the great number of angels”

Quote: the pit
Note: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as “the pit.” Alternate translation: “the place where dead people are”

Quote: I have found a ransom for him
Note: This means that the angel has found a way to pay for the sins of the man so that he does not have to die. Alternate translation: “for I have found a way for you to keep him from dying”

Quote: Then
Note: This word is used here to mark what will happen if God grants the angel’s request. Alternate translation: “Then as a result” or “As a result of the angel’s request to God”

Quote: his flesh will become fresher than a child’s
Note: This speaks of the man being healed and his body growing strong again as if his body became new like a child’s body. Alternate translation: “the sick man’s body will become new again like a young person’s body”

Quote: fresher than a child’s
Note: In this comparison, the word “fresher” is an exaggeration. Alternate translation: “fresh like a child’s”

Quote: a child’s
Note: This refers to a child’s flesh. Alternate translation: “a child’s flesh”

Quote: it is restored to the days of his youth
Note: This speaks of the man’s flesh again being as strong as it was when he was young. Alternate translation: “it will become strong again, as it was when he was young”

Quote: he sees God’s face with joy
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “he joyfully worships God”

Quote: God’s face
Note: Here God is represented by his “face.” Alternate translation: “God”

Quote: God will give the person his triumph
Note: Alternate translation: “God will save the person” or “God will make things right for the person again”

Quote: but my sin was not punished
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “but God did not punish me for sinning”

Quote: rescued my soul from going down into the pit
Note: Here the person is referred to by his “soul.” Alternate translation: “rescued me from dying and going to the pit”

Quote: the pit
Note: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as “the pit.” Alternate translation: “the place where dead people are”

Quote: my life will continue to see light
Note: Here the person is represented by his “life.” Also, living is spoken of as seeing the light. Alternate translation: “I will continue to live and see the daylight” or “I will continue to live” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: See
Note: Elihu uses this word here to draw Job’s attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: twice, yes, even three times
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “again and again”

Quote: his soul
Note: The person is represented by his “soul.” Alternate translation: “him”

Quote: to bring his soul back from the pit
Note: This speaks of saving the man from dying as if he had died and was being brought back to life. Alternate translation: “to keep him from dying and going to the pit”

Quote: the pit
Note: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as “the pit.” Alternate translation: “the place where dead people are”

Quote: he may be enlightened with the light of life
Note: This is an idiom and may be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “he may be happy to still be alive” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Pay attention, Job, and listen to me
Note: These phrases mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “Listen carefully to me, Job”

Quote: that you are in the right
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “that you are innocent”

# Job 34 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

According to Elihu, instead of being punished for his sins, Job is sinning in the midst of these difficulties. This is the second of Elihu’s four statements and it is addressed first to Job’s friends and then to Job. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/testimony]])

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. Elihu uses many of Job’s statements against him. His attitude is not too different from Job’s friends.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s justice
Elihu defends the justice of Yahweh after Job claimed that Yahweh was being unjust. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/justice]])

Quote: Moreover, Elihu
Note: Alternate translation: “Then, Elihu”

Quote: Elihu
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Job 32:2](../32/02.md).

Quote: Listen to my words
Note: Alternate translation: “Listen to what I say”

Quote: you wise men … you who have knowledge
Note: Elihu is criticizing Job and his friends. He does not think they are actually wise.

Quote: For the ear tries words as the palate tastes food
Note: Elihu means people listen carefully to determine what is right or wrong just like we taste food to determine if it is good or bad. Here people are referred to by their “ear” and their “palate” to emphasize that they are tasting and hearing. Alternate translation: “For we listen to words to know what is good and bad, just as we taste foods to know what is good to eat” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: Let us
Note: Here “us” refers to Elihu, Job, and his three friends.

Quote: has taken away my rights
Note: Alternate translation: “refused to give me justice”

Quote: I am considered to be a liar
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God considers me to be a liar”

Quote: My wound is incurable
Note: Here Job’s sickness and suffering is spoken of as if it were a “wound.” Alternate translation: “I am sick and no one can heal me”

Quote: What man is like Job
Note: Elihu uses this rhetorical question to scold Job. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is no one else like Job”

Quote: who drinks up mockery like water
Note: Elihu is accusing Job of mocking others as often as a person drinks water. Alternate translation: “who mocks other people as frequently as he drinks water”

Quote: who walks with wicked men
Note: Here “walk” is an idiom for how a person acts. Alternate translation: “who behaves like wicked men”

Quote: you men of understanding
Note: Elihu is criticizing Job and his friends. He does not actually think they are wise.

Quote: far be it from God … far be it from the Almighty that he should commit sin
Note: These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that God would never do anything wrong. The phrase “far be it from” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “Almighty God would never consider doing anything that is wicked or wrong” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: For he pays back a person’s work
Note: This means that he gives to a person what he deserves for the work he has done. Here “work” is a metaphor for what a person does. Alternate translation: “For he gives to a person what he deserves in return for he does”

Quote: he makes every man come upon the reward of his own ways
Note: The phrase “his own ways” is an idiom for how a person lives his life. Elihu emphasizes that God gives to people what they deserve. Alternate translation: “he causes every man to receive the reward he deserves for how he lives”

Quote: Who put him in charge over the earth? Who put the whole world under him?
Note: Both of these rhetorical questions have the same meaning and emphasize that no one needed to grant God authority because it was already his. These questions can be written as statements. Alternate translation: “No one needed to give permission to God to take responsibility over all the earth. He is the rightful one to rule the world.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: If he ever
Note: Elihu is describing a situation that he does not believe would ever happen.

Quote: his spirit and his breath
Note: The “spirit” and “breath” of God are what makes all living things alive. Alternate translation: “his spirit and breath which give us life”

Quote: all flesh
Note: Here all living things are represented by their “flesh.” Alternate translation: “all living things”

Quote: mankind would return to dust again
Note: This means that all people would die and their bodies would decay and become soil. In the beginning God created man from the dust. Alternate translation: “the bodies of mankind would soon become soil again”

Quote: now
Note: Elihu uses this word to bring attention to something important he is about to say.

Quote: you have
Note: Here “you” is singular and refers to Job.

Quote: listen to the sound of my words
Note: “listen to what I say.” This means the same as the previous part of the sentence.

Quote: Can one who hates justice govern? Will you condemn God, who is righteous and mighty?
Note: Elihu uses this question to rebuke Job for implying that God hates justice. Alternate translation: “One who hates justice cannot be expected to rule over people. So you really cannot criticize God, who is righteous and powerful, and you cannot say that what he has done is wrong.”

Quote: Can one who hates justice govern?
Note: The implicit answer to this rhetorical question is “no.” This question implies that God could not rule the world if he hated justice. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “One who hates justice cannot govern the world.” or “God could certainly never hate what is right and still rule the world.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Will you condemn God, who is righteous and mighty?
Note: This rhetorical question is used to emphasize that Job does not have the authority or a reason to condemn God. Alternate translation: “You cannot condemn God, who is righteous and mighty!”

Quote: God, who says to a king, ‘You are vile,’ or says to nobles, ‘You are wicked’?
Note: This continues the rhetorical question from the previous verse, emphasizing to Job that he cannot condemn God. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “He says to some kings, ‘You are vile,’ and he says to some nobles, ‘You are wicked.’”

Quote: God, who says to a king
Note: This is part of the previous question. The understood words from the previous verse, “will you condemn God,” may be supplied. Alternate translation: “Will you condemn God, who says to a king”

Quote: vile
Note: Alternate translation: “evil” or “worthless”

Quote: for they all are the work of his hands
Note: Here “hands” refer to power. Alternate translation: “for God made them all”

Quote: at midnight
Note: Midnight is the time when one day ends and another begins. Here “midnight” is used as an idiom. Alternate translation: “at night” or “suddenly, at night”

Quote: people will be shaken and will pass away
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. The phrase “will be shaken” is an idiom that means to be “struck.” Alternate translation: “God strikes them and they die” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: mighty people will be taken away, but not by human hands
Note: This means that it is God who causes people to die, not people. Also, If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “it is God and not humans who cause mighty people to die” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: not by human hands
Note: Here people are represented by their “hands.” Alternate translation: “not by humans” or “not by people”

Quote: For God’s eyes are upon a person’s ways
Note: God’s “eyes” represent his sight. The phrase “a person’s ways” is an idiom for what he does and how he lives. Alternate translation: “For God watches everything a person does” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: he sees all his steps
Note: This means that he always knows where the person is and where he is going. Alternate translation: “he sees him wherever he goes”

Quote: no darkness, no thick gloom
Note: The words “thick gloom” mean basically the same thing as, and intensify, the word “darkness.”

Quote: in judgment
Note: Alternate translation: “so he may judge him” or “to be judged”

Quote: He breaks mighty men into pieces
Note: This speaks of God destroying these men as if he actually broke their bodies into pieces. Alternate translation: “He destroys mighty men” or “He destroys important people”

Quote: for their ways that need no further investigation
Note: He does not need to investigate what they have done because he already knows everything about them. Alternate translation: “without needing to do further investigation, because he already knows their ways”

Quote: their ways
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “the things they have done”

Quote: he puts others in their places
Note: This means that he appoints other people to rule in their positions. Alternate translation: “and he chooses other people to rule in their places”

Quote: in the night
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “when they are not expecting it”

Quote: they are destroyed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and destroys them”

Quote: In the open sight of others, he kills them for their wicked deeds like criminals
Note: This phrase compares the way that these people die to how criminals die. Alternate translation: “He kills them for their wicked deeds, in the open sight of others as if they were criminals”

Quote: In the open sight of others
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “In a place where everyone can see”

Quote: he kills them
Note: This speaks of God causing these people to die, though he does not actually strike them with a sword himself. He may cause someone else to kill them or disaster to come upon them. Alternate translation: “he causes them to die”

Quote: his ways
Note: This refers to God’s instructions for how people should behave.

Quote: they made the cry of poor people come to him
Note: The word “cry” can be expressed as a verb. This speaks of God hearing their cry as if the cry were a person that came to him. Alternate translation: “they made the poor people cry, and God heard them” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: When he stays silent, who can condemn him? If he hides his face, who can perceive him?
Note: These two questions speak of God not punishing wicked people as if he were being silent and hiding his face.

Quote: When he stays silent, who can condemn him?
Note: Elihu uses this rhetorical question to teach Job. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can criticize God if he decides to remain silent”

Quote: If he hides his face, who can perceive him?
Note: Elihu uses this rhetorical question to teach Job. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can go and see him if he decides to hide his face”

Quote: his face
Note: Here God is represented by his “face.” Alternate translation: “himself”

Quote: no one to entrap people
Note: This compares a godless ruler harming people as if he were a hunter trapping his prey. Alternate translation: “no one to harm the people”

Quote: teach me what I cannot see
Note: Here to “see” means to know. Alternate translation: “teach me what I have done wrong that I am not aware of”

Quote: Do you think that God will punish that person’s sin, since you dislike what God does?
Note: “Since you dislike what God does, do you think that God should punish this person’s sin?” Elihu uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that he should not think that God will not punish this man. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Even though you do not like what God does, surely even you do not think that God will punish this person”

Quote: that person’s sin
Note: Here punishing the person because of his sin is referred to as punishing the “person’s sin.” Alternate translation: “that person because of his sin”

Quote: since you dislike
Note: Alternate translation: “because you dislike”

Quote: what it is that you know
Note: Alternate translation: “what you are thinking about this”

Quote: who hears me
Note: Alternate translation: “who hears me speaking”

Quote: If only Job were put on trial in
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “If only we could put Job on trial in” or “If only we could take Job to court so a judge could listen to”

Quote: in the smallest details of his case
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “to listen to his case thoroughly” or “to hear all of the details of his case”

Quote: of his talking like wicked men
Note: Alternate translation: “of how he has spoken like a wicked man”

Quote: he adds rebellion
Note: This refers to rebellion against God. Alternate translation: “he adds rebellion against God”

Quote: he claps his hands in mockery in our midst
Note: In this accusation, this means that Job clapped his hands to strengthen his mockery of God. Alternate translation: “he claps his hands as he mocks God in our midst” or “he mocks God right in front of us” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: he piles up words against God
Note: Elihu speaks of “words” as if they were objects, and of speaking many words as if it were piling those objects one on top of the other. Alternate translation: “he speaks many words against God”

# Job 35 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

According to Elihu, instead of being punished for his sins, Job is sinning in the midst of these difficulties. This is the third of Elihu’s four statements and it is addressed first to Job’s friends and then to Job. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/testimony]])

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. Elihu uses many of Job’s statements against him.

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Elihu uses many different rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to try to convince Job. These questions help to build Elihu’s argument. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Ironic situation

Elihu explains the irony of Job’s claim. He claimed to be righteous and desired Yahweh to intervene. In this chapter, Elihu explains to Job that his claims of righteousness are prideful. This makes him unrighteous. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]])

Quote: Do you think this is just & ‘My right before God’?
Note: Elihu uses questions to challenge Job. Alternate translation: “You must think you are right … ‘My right before God.’” or “It is not just … ‘My right before God.’”

Quote: Do you think this is just when you say
Note: Alternate translation: “Do you think it is right for you to say”

Quote: Do you think
Note: Here “you” is singular and refers to Job.

Quote: My right before God
Note: This could mean: (1) Job is claiming to be innocent before God or (2) Job is claiming that he, rather than God, is right.

Quote: For you ask, ‘What use is it to me?’ and, ‘Would I be better off if I had sinned?’
Note: Elihu quotes Job as saying the these two rhetorical questions. Alternate translation: “For you say, ‘It does not benefit me’ and, ‘I am no better off than if I had sinned.’”

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nElihu continues speaking.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nElihu continues speaking.

Quote: If you have sinned … what do you do to him?
Note: These two lines share similar meanings. The second line intensifies the meaning of the first line.

Quote: If you have sinned, what harm do you do to God?
Note: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job’s sins cannot actually do anything to God. Alternate translation: “If you have sinned, you have not done any harm to God.”

Quote: If your transgressions pile up high, what do you do to him?
Note: Elihu speaks of “transgressions” as if they were objects, and of committing many transgressions as if it were piling those objects one on top of the other. He asks this question to emphasize that Job does nothing to God by his transgressions. Alternate translation: “If you committed a great many transgressions, you still do nothing to him.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: If you are righteous, what can you give to him? What will he receive from your hand?
Note: The two rhetorical questions mean basically the same thing, that Job’s righteousness adds nothing to God. Alternate translation: “If you are righteous, that does not enable you to give anything to him, and there is nothing that he will receive from your hand.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: receive from your hand
Note: Here the word “hand” represents Job. Alternate translation: “receive from you”

Quote: another son of man
Note: Alternate translation: “another human-being” or “another person”

Quote: Because of many acts of oppression
Note: The word “oppression” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “Because of the many things that people do to oppress others”

Quote: they call for help from the arms of mighty men
Note: Here “arms” refers to power or strength. Alternate translation: “they call for someone to deliver them from the power of mighty men”

Quote: who gives songs in the night
Note: Elihu speaks of God enabling people to have hope in troubling circumstances as if he were giving to them songs which they can sing during the night.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nElihu continues speaking.

Quote: they cry out
Note: Alternate translation: “the oppressed people cry out”

Quote: How much less will he answer you … that you are waiting for him!
Note: Since God will not hear the prayers of prideful, evil men, it is even less likely that he will hear Job, who is complaining against him. Alternate translation: “So he certainly will not answer you … that you are waiting for him!”

Quote: that your case is before him
Note: Alternate translation: “you have presented your case to him”

Quote: you are waiting for him
Note: Alternate translation: “you are waiting for him to respond”

Quote: Now you say that his anger does not punish, and he does not take even a litte notice of transgression
Note: Because Job is saying these things about God that are untrue, it is even less likely that God will answer Job’s prayers.

Quote: his anger does not punish
Note: Here “his anger” is a metonym for “him.” Alternate translation: “he never punishes anyone because he is angry”

Quote: he piles up words without knowledge
Note: Elihu speaks of “words” as if they were objects, and of speaking many words as if it were piling those objects one on top of the other. The word “knowledge” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “he speaks many words without knowing what he is talking about” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

# Job 36 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

According to Elihu, instead of being punished for his sins, Job is sinning in the midst of these difficulties. This is the last of Elihu’s four statements and it is addressed first to Job’s friends and then to Job. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/testimony]])

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. His attitude is not too different from Job’s friends.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s justice
This chapter focuses on the justice of Yahweh. It is important to remember that justice won’t always come in this life. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/justice]])

Quote: I will show you some things
Note: Elihu speaks of explaining things to Job as if he were going to show those things to Job. Alternate translation: “I will explain some things to you”

Quote: I will obtain my knowledge from far off
Note: Elihu speaks of having knowledge of many different subjects as if it were getting his knowledge from far away places. Alternate translation: “I will show you my great knowledge”

Quote: that righteousness belongs to my Maker
Note: Here the word “righteousness” can be translated with an adjective. Alternate translation: “that my Maker is righteous”

Quote: my words will not be false
Note: Alternate translation: “what I say will not be false”

Quote: someone who is mature in knowledge is with you
Note: The word “someone” refers to Elihu himself. He speaks of being very knowledgeable as if it were being mature in knowledge. Alternate translation: “I, who am with you, am very knowledgeable”

Quote: See
Note: Alternate translation: “Look” or “Listen” or “Pay attention to what I am about to tell you”

Quote: he is mighty in strength of understanding
Note: The phrase “mighty in strength” forms a doublet that means “very strong.” Elihu speaks of God understanding everything perfectly as if his understanding were very strong. Alternate translation: “he is very strong in understanding” or “he understands everything completely” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: He does not withdraw his eyes from righteous people
Note: Elihu speaks of God protecting righteous people as if God were watching them with his eyes, and of God ceasing to protect them as if he withdrew his eyes from them. Alternate translation: “He does not stop protecting the righteous people”

Quote: sets them on thrones like kings
Note: Elihu speaks of God honoring the righteous people as if God were causing them to sit on thrones like kings do.

Quote: they are lifted up
Note: Elihu speaks of God honoring the righteous people as if he lifted them up to a high place. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he lifts them up” or “he honors them” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: If they are bound in chains
Note: Here the word “they” refers righteous people whom God will discipline if they sin. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “If someone binds them in chains” or “If someone makes them a prisoner”

Quote: trapped in cords of suffering
Note: Elihu speaks of a person being made to suffer as if that person were trapped in ropes that cause suffering. Alternate translation: “someone causes them to suffer” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: their transgressions and their pride
Note: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “he reveals to them their transgressions and their pride”

Quote: He also opens their ears
Note: Elihu speaks of causing a person to listen as if it were opening that person’s ear. Alternate translation: “He also causes them to listen”

Quote: to his instruction
Note: The noun “instruction” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “to what he is instructing them”

Quote: to turn back from iniquity
Note: Elihu speaks of stopping an action as if it were turning back from it. Alternate translation: “to stop committing iniquity”

Quote: they will spend their days in prosperity, their years in contentment
Note: The words “days” and “years” both refer to the person’s lifetime. Alternate translation: “they will spend their lives in prosperity and contentment”

Quote: they will perish by the sword
Note: Elihu speaks of a person dying violently as if someone had killed them with a sword. Alternate translation: “they will die a violent death”

Quote: who are godless in heart
Note: Here the word “heart” refers to the thoughts and emotions. The phrase may indicate that the person stubbornly refuses to trust God. Alternate translation: “who refuse to trust in God”

Quote: store up their anger
Note: Elihu speaks of a person remaining angry as if that person stored up their anger like one would store up treasure. Alternate translation: “are always angry”

Quote: even when God ties them up
Note: Elihu speaks of God disciplining people as if God were tying them up with ropes. Alternate translation: “even when God punishes them”

Quote: their lives end among the cultic prostitutes
Note: Here “cultic prostitutes” refers to young men who served in pagan temples performing sexually immoral acts as part of their rituals. This phrase could mean: (1) the godless die because of their immoral behavior or (2) the godless die in shame and disgrace.

Quote: he opens their ears
Note: Elihu speaks of God causing a person to listen as if God were opening their ears. See how you translated this in [Job 36:10](../36/10.md). Alternate translation: “he causes them to listen”

Quote: into a broad place where there is no hardship
Note: Elihu speaks of living without trouble as if it were being in a wide-open space where there were no hardships.

Quote: where your table would be set with food full of fatness
Note: Elihu speaks of living prosperously as if it were having one’s table filled with the best foods.

Quote: your table would be set
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “your servants would set your table”

Quote: food full of fatness
Note: Meat that had plenty of fat on it was a sign of prosperity because the animals were healthy and well-fed. Alternate translation: “the very best food”

Quote: you are full of judgment on wicked people
Note: This could mean: (1) “God is punishing you as he would punish the wicked” or (2) “you are obsessed with the judgment that the wicked deserve.”

Quote: judgment and justice have laid hold of you
Note: Elihu speaks of God judging Job and giving him justice as if judgment and justice were people that have laid hold of Job. Alternate translation: “God has brought you to judgment and given you justice”

Quote: Do not let your anger entice you to mockery
Note: Some versions of the Bible translate this as “Beware that you are not enticed by wealth.”

Quote: Can your wealth benefit you, so that you will not be in distress, or can all the force of your strength help you?
Note: Elihu asks these questions to state that money and power will not be able to help Job if he acts unjustly. Alternate translation: “Your wealth cannot cause you to no longer be in distress, and all the force of your strength cannot help you.”

Quote: all the force of your strength
Note: Alternate translation: “all of your great strength” or “all of your mighty efforts”

Quote: when peoples are cut off in their place

Alternate translation: “when nations will perish”

Note: This could mean: (1) “God is extremely powerful” or (2) “people exalt God because he is powerful”

Note: Elihu asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one has ever taught God what to do. Alternate translation: “No one has ever instructed him about what he should do.”

Note: Elihu asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one can accuse God of having committed unrighteousness. Alternate translation: “No one can ever say to him, ‘You have committed unrighteousness.’”

Note: Elihu speaks of people not being fully able to understand God’s deeds as if people were only able to see those deeds from far away. Alternate translation: “they do not fully understand them”

Note: This refers to how long God has existed. Alternate translation: “people cannot know how long he has lived” or “people cannot know his age”

Note: The phrase “the extensive spread” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “how the clouds spread across the sky”

# Job 37 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

According to Elihu, instead of being punished for his sins, Job is sinning in the midst of these difficulties. This is a continuation of the previous chapter and the last of Elihu’s four statements, and it is addressed first to Job’s friends and then to Job. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/testimony]])

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. His attitude is not too different from Job’s friends.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s justice
This chapter focuses on the justice of Yahweh. It is important to remember that justice won’t always come in this life. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/justice]])

Quote: my heart trembles … it is moved out of its place
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his fear.

Quote: my heart trembles at this
Note: The word “this” refers to the storm in [Job 36:33](../36/33.md).

Quote: it is moved out of its place
Note: Elihu speaks of his heart beating violently as if it were to jump out of his chest. Alternate translation: “it moves out of its place” or “it beats violently” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the noise of his voice, the sound that goes out from his mouth
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Elihu speaks of the thunder as if it is God’s voice. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: to the edges of the earth
Note: Elihu speaks of the farthest places on the earth as if they were the earth’s borders. Alternate translation: “everywhere in the world”

Quote: A voice roars after it … the voice of his majesty
Note: Elihu continues to speak of the thunder as if it is God’s voice.

Quote: roars after it
Note: Alternate translation: “roars after the lightning”

Quote: the voice of his majesty
Note: Alternate translation: “his majestic voice”

Quote: when his voice is heard
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “when people hear his voice”

Quote: likewise to the rain shower
Note: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “likewise, he says to the rain shower”

Quote: He stops the hand of every man
Note: Here the word “hand” represents the entire person. Alternate translation: “He stops every man”

Quote: The storm comes from its chamber in the south and the cold from the scattering winds in the north
Note: In Israel, strong wind storms blow in from the south and cold weather approaches from the north.

Quote: The storm comes from its chamber in the south
Note: Elihu speaks of the storm blowing in from the south as if the storm has a place where it resides until it comes.

Quote: By the breath of God ice is given
Note: Elihu speaks of the cold north wind as if it were God’s breath. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God’s breath makes ice” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: frozen like metal
Note: Elihu compares the hardness of ice to the hardness of metal. Alternate translation: “frozen, as hard as metal”

Quote: he weighs down the thick cloud with moisture
Note: Elihu speaks of God causing the storm clouds to be full of water as if the moisture weighed heavily on the clouds. Alternate translation: “he causes the thick clouds to be full of moisture”

Quote: sometimes it happens for correction
Note: The word “correction” can be translated with a verbal phrase. The object of his “correction” is people. Alternate translation: “sometimes it happens to correct his people” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: sometimes for his land
Note: This means that the rain waters the ground and causes vegetation to grow. Alternate translation: “sometimes to water the land”

Quote: sometimes as acts of covenant faithfulness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithful” or “faithfully.” Alternate translation: “sometimes to act faithfully to his covenant” or “sometimes to be faithful to his people”

Quote: Do you know how God establishes the clouds and makes the lightning bolts to flash in them?
Note: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job cannot know this. Alternate translation: “You cannot understand how God establishes the clouds and makes the lightning bolts to flash in them.”

Quote: establishes the clouds
Note: Alternate translation: “controls the clouds” or “makes the clouds obey him”

Quote: Do you understand the floating of the clouds, the marvelous deeds of God, who is perfect in knowledge?
Note: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job does not know these things. Alternate translation: “You do not understand the floating of the clouds, the marvelous deeds of God, who is perfect in knowledge.”

Quote: the floating of the clouds
Note: Alternate translation: “how the clouds float”

Quote: the marvelous deeds of God
Note: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “or do you understand the marvelous deeds of God” or “and you do not understand the marvelous deeds of God”

Quote: Do you understand how your garments become hot … from the south?
Note: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job does not know these things. Alternate translation: “You do not understand how your garments become hot … from the south.”

Quote: how your garments become hot
Note: Alternate translation: “how you become hot in your clothes” or “how you sweat in your clothes”

Quote: because the wind comes from the south
Note: In Israel, hot winds blow in across the desert from the south and cause hot temperatures. Alternate translation: “because of the hot, dry wind blowing in from the south”

Quote: Can you spread out the sky … a mirror of cast metal?
Note: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job cannot do this. Alternate translation: “You cannot spread out the sky … a mirror of cast metal.”

Quote: as strong as a mirror of cast metal
Note: In biblical days, mirrors were made of metal. Elihu speaks of the sky giving no rain as if it were as hard as solid metal.

Quote: cast metal
Note: This refers to metal that is melted, poured into a mold, and then hardens as it cools.

Quote: Teach us what we should say to him
Note: Here the words “us” and “we” refer to Elihu, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar, but not to Job. Elihu uses this phrase sarcastically.

Quote: because of the darkness of our minds
Note: Elihu speaks of the inability to understand as if it were having darkness in one’s mind. Alternate translation: “because we do not understand”

Quote: Should he be told that I wish to speak with him?
Note: Elihu asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one can do this. Alternate translation: “I cannot have someone tell him that I wish to speak with him.”

Quote: Should he be told
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Should I have someone tell him”

Quote: Would a person wish to be swallowed up?
Note: Elihu asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one would want this to happen. Alternate translation: “No person would want to be swallowed up.”

Quote: to be swallowed up
Note: Elihu speaks of a person being destroyed as if the person were swallowed up. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “for God to destroy him” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: over God is fearsome majesty
Note: The word “fearsome” means that it causes fear. Elihu speaks of God’s majesty as if it were something that rests upon God. Alternate translation: “God’s majesty causes people to fear”

Quote: we cannot find him
Note: This could mean: (1) “we cannot approach him” or (2) this is a metaphor in which Elihu speaks of a person’s being unable to fully understand God as if he could not find God. Alternate translation: “we cannot comprehend him”

Quote: those who are wise in their own minds
Note: Here “minds” represents the person’s thoughts. Alternate translation: “those who are wise in their own thinking” or “those who consider themselves to be wise”

# Job 38 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. Yahweh finally speaks in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s greatness
Yahweh is far greater than any man. He is the creator of the earth, and his ways will not always be understood by men because their knowledge is always limited.

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Yahweh uses a series of rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to defend his character. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Then Yahweh called
Note: Here, the word “then” marks the beginning of a new part of the book. See if your language has a similar way to introduce a new scene. Alternate translation: “After all that had happened, Yahweh called.

Quote: called to Job
Note: Alternate translation: “answered Job” or “responded to Job”

Quote: out of a fierce storm
Note: Alternate translation: “from a powerful storm”

Quote: Who is this who brings darkness to plans by means of words without knowledge?
Note: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that Job spoke of things he did not know about. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You bring darkness to my plans by means of words without knowledge.”

Quote: Who is this who brings
Note: Alternate translation: “Who are you to bring”

Quote: brings darkness to plans
Note: “obscures my plans” or “confuses my purposes.” How Job confuses God’s plans is spoken of as if he were making God’s plans harder to see. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **darkness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “darkens.” Alternate translation: “darkens plans” or “makes plans hard to see” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: by means of words without knowledge
Note: Alternate translation: “by speaking of things about which you do not know”

Quote: words without knowledge
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **knowledge**, you can express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “unknowing words” or “ignorant words”

Quote: gird up your loins like a man
Note: “tie your robe up around your waist like a man.” Men tied up their robes around their waists so that their legs could move more freely as they did heavy work. The idiom “gird up your loins like a man” means to get ready to do something involving action such as work, a contest, or a battle. Job was to prepare for the hard work of answering God. Alternate translation: “get yourself ready for hard work”
# General Information:\n\nYahweh begins to challenge Job with a series of questions that emphasize he created the earth and Job did not.

Note: If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Tell me where you were when I laid the foundations of the earth, if you have so much understanding”

Note: Yahweh describes creating the earth as though he was building a structure.

Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **understanding**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “understand.” Alternate translation: “if you understand so much”

Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nYahweh continues to challenge Job.

Yahweh continues to challenge Job. He begins to ask a rhetorical question.

Note: This question expects a negative answer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have never … shaken the wicked out of it.”

If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. “You have never given … so that it might take hold … shaken the wicked out of it.”

Quote: take hold of the edges of the earth
Note: The light of dawn is spoken of as if it seizes the horizons of the earth. Alternate translation: “grasp the ends of the earth” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

# Job 39 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The ULT sets the lines of this chapter farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because it is a poem. Yahweh continues to speak in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s greatness
Yahweh is far greater than any man. He is the creator of the earth, and his ways will not always be understood by men because their knowledge is always limited. Since Job cannot understand creation, he cannot truly understand Yahweh.

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Yahweh uses a series of rhetorical questions in this chapter in order to defend his character. Many of these questions focus on nature because Yahweh is the creator of the heavens and the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/heaven]])
